verses.textEn: The wisdom of many great things has been revealed to us through the law, and the prophets, and the other books that followed these. Concerning these things, Israel ought to be praised, because of doctrine and wisdom. For it is necessary, not only for those who are speaking, but even for outsiders, to be skillful, both in speaking and in writing, so as to become very learned.
verses.textLa: Multorum nobis, et magnorum per legem, et prophetas, aliosque qui secuti sunt illos, sapientia demonstrata est: in quibus oportet laudare Israel doctrinæ et sapientiæ causa: quia non solum ipsos loquentes necesse est esse peritos, sed etiam extraneos posse et dicentes et scribentes doctissimos fieri.

verses.textEn: My grandfather Jesus, after he gave himself fully to a diligent reading of the law, and the prophets, and the other books that were handed down to us by our ancestors, also wanted to write something himself, about the things that pertain to doctrine and wisdom, so that those who desire to learn and to become skillful in these things would be more and more attentive in mind, and would be strengthened to live according to the law.
verses.textLa: Avus meus Iesus, postquam se amplius dedit ad diligentiam lectionis legis, et prophetarum, et aliorum librorum, qui nobis a parentibus nostris traditi sunt: voluit et ipse scribere aliquid horum, quæ ad doctrinam et sapientiam pertinent: ut desiderantes discere, et illorum periti facti, magis magisque attendant animo, et confirmentur ad legitimam vitam.

verses.textEn: And so, I exhort you to approach with benevolence, and to perform the reading with attentive study, and to be forbearing in these things when we may seem, while pursuing the image of wisdom, to fall short in the composition of words.
verses.textLa: Hortor itaque venire vos cum benevolentia, et attentiori studio lectionem facere, et veniam habere in illis, in quibus videmur sequentes imaginem sapientiæ deficere in verborum compositione.

verses.textEn: For the Hebrew words are deficient when they have been translated into another language.
verses.textLa: Nam deficiunt verba Hebraica, quando fuerint translata ad alteram linguam.

verses.textEn: And not only these words, but also the law itself, and the prophets, and the remainder of the books, have no small difference from when they have been spoken in their own language.
verses.textLa: Non autem solum hæc, sed et ipsa lex, et prophetæ, ceteraque aliorum librorum, non parvam habent differentiam, quando inter se dicuntur.

verses.textEn: For in the time of king Ptolemy Euergetes, in the thirty-eighth year after I had arrived in Egypt, after I had been there for a long time, I found, left behind there, books with a doctrine neither small nor contemptible.
verses.textLa: Nam in octavo et trigesimo anno temporibus Ptolemæi Evergetis regis, postquam perveni in Ægyptum: et cum multum temporis ibi fuissem, inveni ibi libros relictos, non parvæ, neque contemnendæ doctrinæ.

verses.textEn: And so I considered it to be both good and necessary for me to apply some significant diligence and labor in order to translate this book.
verses.textLa: Itaque bonum et necessarium putavi et ipse aliquam addere diligentiam et laborem interpretandi librum istum:

verses.textEn: Then, after much attentiveness to doctrine over a length of time, I brought to a close the things being considered, so as to offer this book for those who are willing to apply their mind and to learn how they ought to conduct their way of life,
verses.textLa: et multa vigilia attuli doctrinam in spatio temporis ad illa, quæ ad finem ducunt, librum istum dare, et illis qui volunt animum intendere, et discere quemadmodum oporteat instituere mores,
verses.notes: Translators must attend to doctrine, and not merely to words and history.

verses.textEn: for those who have decided to form their life in accord with the law of the Lord.
verses.textLa: qui secundum legem Domini proposuerint vitam agere.

verses.textEn: All wisdom is from the Lord God, and has always been with him, and is before all time.
verses.textLa: Omnis sapientia a Domino Deo est, et cum illo fuit semper, et est ante ævum.

verses.textEn: Who has numbered the sand of the sea, and the drops of the rain, and the days of the world? Who has measured the height of heaven, and the breadth of the earth, and the depth of the abyss?
verses.textLa: Arenam maris, et pluviæ guttas, et dies sæculi quis dinumeravit? Altitudinem cæli, et latitudinem terræ, et profundum abyssi quis dimensus est?

verses.textEn: Who has examined the wisdom of God, which precedes all things?
verses.textLa: Sapientiam Dei præcedentem omnia quis investigavit?

verses.textEn: Wisdom was created before all things, and the understanding of prudence is before all time.
verses.textLa: Prior omnium creata est sapientia, et intellectus prudentiæ ab ævo.

verses.textEn: The Word of God on high is the source of wisdom, whose steps are eternal commandments.
verses.textLa: Fons sapientiæ Verbum Dei in excelsis, et ingressus illius mandata æterna.

verses.textEn: To whom has the root of wisdom been revealed, and who has recognized her astuteness?
verses.textLa: Radix sapientiæ cui revelata est, et astutias illius quis agnovit?

verses.textEn: To whom has the discipline of wisdom been revealed and made manifest? And who has understood the multiplicity of her steps?
verses.textLa: Disciplina sapientiæ cui revelata est, et manifestata? Et multiplicationem ingressus illius quis intellexit?

verses.textEn: The most high omnipotent Creator is One, and he is the mighty King, and he is exceedingly to be feared, sitting upon his throne, and he is the sovereign God.
verses.textLa: Unus est altissimus Creator omnipotens, et Rex potens, et metuendus nimis, sedens super thronum illius et dominans Deus.

verses.textEn: He created wisdom through the Holy Spirit, and he saw her, and numbered her, and measured her.
verses.textLa: Ipse creavit illam in Spiritu Sancto, et vidit, et dinumeravit, et mensus est.

verses.textEn: And he poured her over all his works, and over all flesh, to the extent of his favor, and he has offered her to those who love him.
verses.textLa: Et effudit illam super omnia opera sua, et super omnem carnem secundum datum suum, et præbuit illam diligentibus se.

verses.textEn: The fear of the Lord is glory, and honor, and rejoicing, and a crown of exultation.
verses.textLa: Timor Domini gloria, et gloriatio, et lætitia, et corona exultationis.

verses.textEn: The fear of the Lord will delight the heart, and will give joy and gladness and length of days.
verses.textLa: Timor Domini delectabit cor, et dabit lætitiam, et gaudium, et longitudinem dierum.

verses.textEn: It will be well, in the very end, for him who fears the Lord, and on the day that he passes away, he will be blessed.
verses.textLa: Timenti Dominum bene erit in extremis, et in die defunctionis suæ benedicetur.

verses.textEn: The love of God is honorable wisdom.
verses.textLa: Dilectio Dei honorabilis sapientia.

verses.textEn: And those to whom she will appear for their consideration love her because of what they see and know of her great works.
verses.textLa: Quibus autem apparuerit in visu, diligunt eam in visione, et in agnitione magnalium suorum.

verses.textEn: The fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom, and was created with the faithful in the womb, and walks with elect women, and is known by the just and the faithful.
verses.textLa: Initium sapientiæ, timor Domini, et cum fidelibus in vulva concreatus est, cum electis feminis graditur, et cum iustis et fidelibus agnoscitur.

verses.textEn: The fear of the Lord is the sanctity of knowledge.
verses.textLa: Timor Domini, scientiæ religiositas.

verses.textEn: Sanctity will guard and justify the heart, and will bestow happiness and joy.
verses.textLa: Religiositas custodiet et iustificabit cor, iucunditatem atque gaudium dabit.

verses.textEn: It will be well with him who fears the Lord, and at the consummation of his days, he will be blessed.
verses.textLa: Timenti Dominum bene erit, et in diebus consummationis illius benedicetur.

verses.textEn: To fear God is the fullness of wisdom, and it is a fullness from its fruits.
verses.textLa: Plenitudo sapientiæ est timere Deum, et plenitudo a fructibus illius.

verses.textEn: She will fill her entire house from her offspring, and storehouses from her treasures.
verses.textLa: Omnem domum illius implebit a generationibus, et receptacula a thesauris illius.

verses.textEn: The fear of the Lord is the crown of wisdom, the completion of peace, and the fruit of salvation.
verses.textLa: Corona sapientiæ, timor Domini, replens pacem, et salutis fructum:

verses.textEn: And the fear of the Lord has seen and numbered wisdom; but both are gifts of God.
verses.textLa: et vidit, et dinumeravit eam: utraque autem sunt dona Dei.
verses.notes: The terms ‘fear of the Lord’ and ‘wisdom’ are used in place of the pronouns, for the sake of clarity.

verses.textEn: Wisdom will distribute knowledge and an understanding of prudence; and she lifts up the glory of those who hold to her.
verses.textLa: Scientiam, et intellectum prudentiæ sapientia compartietur: et gloriam tenentium se, exaltat.

verses.textEn: The root of wisdom is to fear the Lord, and its branches are long-lived.
verses.textLa: Radix sapientiæ est timere Dominum: et rami illius longævi.

verses.textEn: In the treasures of wisdom is understanding and the sanctity of knowledge. But to sinners, wisdom is an abomination.
verses.textLa: In thesauris sapientiæ intellectus, et scientiæ religiositas: execratio autem peccatoribus sapientia.

verses.textEn: The fear of the Lord expels sin.
verses.textLa: Timor Domini expellit peccatum:

verses.textEn: For he who is without fear is not able to be justified. For the disposition of his spirit is his undoing.
verses.textLa: nam qui sine timore est, non poterit iustificari: iracundia enim animositatis illius, subversio illius est.

verses.textEn: Those who are patient will suffer for a brief time, and afterwards, happiness will return.
verses.textLa: Usque in tempus sustinebit patiens, et postea redditio iucunditatis.

verses.textEn: A noble mind will hide his words for a brief time, and then the lips of many will declare his understanding.
verses.textLa: Bonus sensus usque in tempus abscondet verba illius, et labia multorum enarrabunt sensum illius.

verses.textEn: Among the treasures of wisdom is the outward sign of discipline.
verses.textLa: In thesauris sapientiæ significatio disciplinæ:

verses.textEn: But to those who sin, the worship of God is an abomination.
verses.textLa: execratio autem peccatori, cultura Dei.

verses.textEn: Son, if you desire wisdom, observe justice, and then God will offer her to you.
verses.textLa: Fili concupiscens sapientiam, conserva iustitiam, et Deus præbebit illam tibi.

verses.textEn: For the fear of the Lord is wisdom and discipline.
verses.textLa: Sapientia enim et disciplina timor Domini:

verses.textEn: And what pleases him is faith and meekness. And so shall he complete his treasures.
verses.textLa: et quod beneplacitum est illi, fides, et mansuetudo, et adimplebit thesauros illius.

verses.textEn: You should not be incredulous to the fear of the Lord. And you should not draw close to him with a duplicitous heart.
verses.textLa: Ne sis incredibilis timori Domini: et ne accesseris ad illum duplici corde.

verses.textEn: You should not be a hypocrite in the sight of men. And you should not scandalize with your lips.
verses.textLa: Ne fueris hypocrita in conspectu hominum, et non scandalizeris in labiis tuis.

verses.textEn: Attend to these things, otherwise you may fall and bring dishonor to your soul.
verses.textLa: Attende in illis, ne forte cadas, et adducas animæ tuæ inhonorationem,

verses.textEn: And then God may uncover your secrets, and he may cast you down forcefully in the midst of the congregation.
verses.textLa: et revelet Deus absconsa tua, et in medio synagogæ elidat te:

verses.textEn: For you drew near to the Lord wickedly, and your heart was filled with deceit and falseness.
verses.textLa: quoniam accessisti maligne ad Dominum, et cor tuum plenum est dolo et fallacia.

verses.textEn: Son, when you apply yourself to the service of God, stand in justice and in fear, and prepare your soul for temptation.
verses.textLa: Fili accedens ad servitutem Dei, sta in iustitia, et timore, et præpara animam tuam ad tentationem.

verses.textEn: Humble your heart, and persevere. Incline your ear, and accept words of understanding. And you should not hurry away in the time of distress.
verses.textLa: Deprime cor tuum, et sustine: inclina aurem tuam, et suscipe verba intellectus: et ne festines in tempore obductionis.

verses.textEn: Endure steadfastly for God. Join yourself to God, and persevere, so that your life may increase in the very end.
verses.textLa: Sustine sustentationes Dei: coniungere Deo, et sustine, ut crescat in novissimo vita tua.

verses.textEn: Accept everything that will happen to you, and persevere in your sorrow, and have patience in your humiliation.
verses.textLa: Omne, quod tibi applicitum fuerit, accipe: et in dolore sustine, et in humilitate tua patientiam habe:

verses.textEn: For gold and silver are tested in fire, yet truly, acceptable men are tested in the furnace of humiliation.
verses.textLa: quoniam in igne probatur aurum et argentum, homines vero receptibiles in camino humiliationis.

verses.textEn: Believe God, and he will restore you to health. And straighten your way, and hope in him. Observe his fear, and grow old in it.
verses.textLa: Crede Deo, et recuperabit te. Et dirige viam tuam, et spera in illum. Serva timorem illius, et in illo veterasce.

verses.textEn: You who fear the Lord, wait for his mercy. And do not turn away from him, lest you fall.
verses.textLa: Metuentes Dominum sustinete misericordiam eius: et non deflectatis ab illo ne cadatis.

verses.textEn: You who fear the Lord, believe in him. And your reward will not be taken away.
verses.textLa: Qui timetis Dominum, credite illi: et non evacuabitur merces vestra.

verses.textEn: You who fear the Lord, hope in him. And mercy will approach you, to your delight.
verses.textLa: Qui timetis Dominum, sperate in illum: et in oblectationem veniet vobis misericordia.

verses.textEn: You who fear the Lord, love him. And your hearts will be illuminated.
verses.textLa: Qui timetis Dominum diligite illum, et illuminabuntur corda vestra.

verses.textEn: My sons, consider the nations of men, and know that not one of them hoped in the Lord and was confounded.
verses.textLa: Respicite filii nationes hominum: et scitote quia nullus speravit in Domino, et confusus est.

verses.textEn: For who has remained in his commandment and been abandoned? Or who has called upon him, and yet he despised him?
verses.textLa: Quis enim permansit in mandatis eius, et derelictus est? Aut quis invocavit eum, et despexit illum?

verses.textEn: For God is upright and merciful, and he will forgive sins in the day of tribulation. And he is the Protector to all those who seek him in truth.
verses.textLa: Quoniam pius et misericors est Deus, et remittet in die tribulationis peccata: et Protector est omnibus exquirentibus se in veritate.

verses.textEn: Woe to the duplicitous heart, and to the wicked lips, and to the hands that do evil, and to the sinner who walks the earth by two ways!
verses.textLa: Væ duplici corde, et labiis scelestis, et manibus malefacientibus, et peccatori terram ingredienti duabus viis.

verses.textEn: Woe to the dissolute in heart, who do not trust God! For, as a result, they will not be protected by him.
verses.textLa: Væ dissolutis corde, qui non credunt Deo: et ideo non protegentur ab eo.
verses.notes: Both are viable translations: ‘who do not believe in God’ and ‘who do not believe God.’ Both meanings are correct.

verses.textEn: Woe to those who have lost endurance, and who have abandoned upright ways, and who have turned aside to depraved ways!
verses.textLa: Væ his, qui perdiderunt sustinentiam, et qui dereliquerunt vias rectas, et diverterunt in vias pravas.

verses.textEn: And what will they do when the Lord begins to examine them?
verses.textLa: Et quid facient, cum inspicere cœperit Dominus?

verses.textEn: Those who fear the Lord will not be unbelieving toward his Word. And those who love him will keep to his way.
verses.textLa: Qui timent Dominum, non erunt incredibiles Verbo illius: et qui diligunt illum, conservabunt viam illius.

verses.textEn: Those who fear the Lord will seek the things that are well-pleasing to him. And those who love him will be filled with his law.
verses.textLa: Qui timent Dominum, inquirent quæ beneplacita sunt ei: et qui diligunt eum, replebuntur lege ipsius.

verses.textEn: Those who fear the Lord will prepare their hearts, and they will sanctify their souls in his sight.
verses.textLa: Qui timent Dominum, præparabunt corda sua, et in conspectu illius sanctificabunt animas suas.

verses.textEn: Those who fear the Lord keep his commandments, and they will have patience even until his examination,
verses.textLa: Qui timent Dominum, custodiunt mandata illius, et patientiam habebunt usque ad inspectionem illius,

verses.textEn: saying: “If we do not do penance, then we will fall into the hands of the Lord, and not into the hands of men.”
verses.textLa: dicentes: Si pœnitentiam non egerimus, incidemus in manus Domini, et non in manus hominum.

verses.textEn: For according to his greatness, so also is his mercy with him.
verses.textLa: Secundum enim magnitudinem ipsius, sic et misericordia illius cum ipso est.

verses.textEn: The sons of wisdom are the Church of the just: and their generation is obedience and love.
verses.textLa: Filii sapientiæ, ecclesia iustorum: et natio illorum, obedientia et dilectio.

verses.textEn: Sons, listen to the judgment of your father, and act accordingly, so that you may be saved.
verses.textLa: Iudicium patris audite filii, et sic facite ut salvi sitis.

verses.textEn: For God has honored the father in the sons, and, when seeking the judgment of the mother, he has confirmed it in the children.
verses.textLa: Deus enim honoravit patrem in filiis: et iudicium matris exquirens, firmavit in filios.

verses.textEn: He who loves God will plead with him on behalf of sins, and will keep himself away from sin, and will be heeded in the prayers of his days.
verses.textLa: Qui diligit Deum, exorabit pro peccatis, et continebit se ab illis, et in oratione dierum exaudietur.

verses.textEn: And, like one who stores up treasure, so also is he who honors his mother.
verses.textLa: Et sicut qui thesaurizat, ita et qui honorificat matrem suam.

verses.textEn: He who honors his father will find happiness in his own children, and he will be heeded in the day of his prayer.
verses.textLa: Qui honorat patrem suum, iucundabitur in filiis, et in die orationis suæ exaudietur.

verses.textEn: He who honors his father will live a long life. And he who obeys his father will be a refreshment to his mother.
verses.textLa: Qui honorat patrem suum, vita vivet longiore: et qui obedit patri, refrigerabit matrem.

verses.textEn: He who fears the Lord honors his parents, and he will serve them as masters, for it is they who conceived him.
verses.textLa: Qui timet Dominum honorat parentes, et quasi dominis serviet his, qui se genuerunt.

verses.textEn: In word and deed, and in all things, honor your father with patience,
verses.textLa: In opere et sermone, et omni patientia honora patrem tuum,

verses.textEn: so that a blessing may come to you from him, and so that his blessing may remain to the very end.
verses.textLa: ut superveniat tibi benedictio ab eo, et benedictio illius in novissimo maneat.

verses.textEn: The blessing of the father strengthens the houses of the sons; but the curse of the mother uproots even its foundation.
verses.textLa: Benedictio patris firmat domos filiorum: maledictio autem matris eradicat fundamenta.

verses.textEn: Do not boast in the disgrace of your father; for his shame is not your glory.
verses.textLa: Ne glorieris in contumelia patris tui: non enim est tibi gloria, eius confusio.

verses.textEn: For the glory of a man is from the honor of his father, and a father without honor is a discredit to the son.
verses.textLa: Gloria enim hominis ex honore patris sui, et dedecus filii pater sine honore.

verses.textEn: Son, support your father in his old age, and do not grieve him in his life.
verses.textLa: Fili suscipe senectam patris tui, et non contristes eum in vita illius:

verses.textEn: And if his mind should fail, show kindness; and do not spurn him when you are in your strength. For almsgiving to the father will never be forgotten.
verses.textLa: et si defecerit sensu, veniam da, et ne spernas eum in virtute tua: eleemosyna enim patris non erit in oblivione.

verses.textEn: For even in return for the sin of the mother, good will be repaid to you.
verses.textLa: Nam pro peccato matris restituetur tibi bonum,

verses.textEn: And you will be built up in justice, and you will be remembered in the day of tribulation. And your sins will dissolve like ice in warm weather.
verses.textLa: et in iustitia ædificabitur tibi, et in die tribulationis commemorabitur tui: et sicut in sereno glacies solventur peccata tua.

verses.textEn: What an evil form has he who forsakes his father! And whoever exasperates his mother is accursed by God.
verses.textLa: Quam malæ famæ est, qui derelinquit patrem: et est maledictus a Deo, qui exasperat matrem.

verses.textEn: Son, perform your works in meekness, and you shall be loved beyond the glory of men.
verses.textLa: Fili in mansuetudine opera tua perfice, et super hominum gloriam diligeris.

verses.textEn: However great you may be, humble yourself in all things, and you will find grace in the presence of God.
verses.textLa: Quanto magnus es, humilia te in omnibus, et coram Deo invenies gratiam:

verses.textEn: For only the power of God is great, and he is honored by the humble.
verses.textLa: quoniam magna potentia Dei solius, et ab humilibus honoratur.

verses.textEn: You should not seek the things that are too high for you, and you should not examine the things that are beyond your ability. But as for the things that God has entrusted to you, consider these always. But you should not be curious in too many of his works.
verses.textLa: Altiora te ne quæsieris, et fortiora te ne scrutatus fueris: sed quæ præcepit tibi Deus, illa cogita semper, et in pluribus operibus eius ne fueris curiosus.

verses.textEn: For it is not necessary for you to see with your own eyes the things that are hidden.
verses.textLa: Non est enim tibi necessarium ea, quæ abscondita sunt, videre oculis tuis.

verses.textEn: In unnecessary matters, do not choose to be an examiner of many different things, and you should not be curious about too many of his works.
verses.textLa: In supervacuis rebus noli scrutari multipliciter, et in pluribus operibus eius non eris curiosus.

verses.textEn: For many things have been revealed to you, beyond the understanding of men.
verses.textLa: Plurima enim super sensum hominum ostensa sunt tibi.

verses.textEn: Yet uncertainty in these things has also undermined many persons and has detained their minds in vanity.
verses.textLa: Multos quoque supplantavit suspicio illorum, et in vanitate detinuit sensus illorum.

verses.textEn: A hardened heart will have evil in the very end, and he who loves peril will perish in it.
verses.textLa: Cor durum habebit male in novissimo: et qui amat periculum in illo peribit.

verses.textEn: A heart advancing in two directions will not have success, and the depraved heart will be scandalized in this way.
verses.textLa: Cor ingrediens duas vias, non habebit successus, et pravus corde in illis scandalizabitur.

verses.textEn: A wicked heart will be burdened with sorrows, and a sinner will add further sins.
verses.textLa: Cor nequam gravabitur in doloribus, et peccator adiiciet ad peccandum.

verses.textEn: The synagogue of the arrogant will not be healed. For the stalk of sinfulness will take root in them, and it will not be understood.
verses.textLa: Synagogæ superborum non erit sanitas: frutex enim peccati radicabitur in illis, et non intelligetur.

verses.textEn: The heart of the wise is understood by wisdom, and a good ear will listen to wisdom with all its desire.
verses.textLa: Cor sapientis intelligitur in sapientia, et auris bona audiet cum omni concupiscentia sapientiam.

verses.textEn: A wise and understanding heart will abstain from sins, and will have success in works of justice.
verses.textLa: Sapiens cor, et intelligibile abstinebit se a peccatis, et in operibus iustitiæ successus habebit.

verses.textEn: Water extinguishes a burning fire, and almsgiving withstands sins.
verses.textLa: Ignem ardentem extinguit aqua, et eleemosyna resistit peccatis:

verses.textEn: And God is the watchman for him who repays a kindness. He remembers him afterwards, and in the time of his fall, he will find a firm support.
verses.textLa: et Deus prospector est eius qui reddit gratiam: meminit eius in posterum, et in tempore casus sui inveniet firmamentum.

verses.textEn: Son, you should not cheat the poor out of alms, nor should you avert your eyes from a poor man.
verses.textLa: Fili eleemosynam pauperis ne defraudes, et oculos tuos ne transvertas a paupere.

verses.textEn: You should not despise the hungry soul, and you should not aggravate a poor man in his need.
verses.textLa: Animam esurientem ne despexeris: et non exasperes pauperem in inopia sua.

verses.textEn: You should not afflict the heart of the needy, and you should not delay an offer to someone in anguish.
verses.textLa: Cor inopis ne afflixeris, et non protrahas datum angustianti.

verses.textEn: You should not make requests of one who is greatly troubled, and you should not avert your face from the indigent.
verses.textLa: Rogationem contribulati ne abiicias: et non avertas faciem tuam ab egeno.

verses.textEn: You should not avert your eyes from the needy out of anger. And you should not abandon those who seek help from you, so that they speak curses behind your back.
verses.textLa: Ab inope ne avertas oculos tuos propter iram: et non relinquas quærentibus tibi retro maledicere:

verses.textEn: For the pleadings of him who speaks curses of you, in the bitterness of his soul, will be heeded. For the One who made him will heed him.
verses.textLa: maledicentis enim tibi in amaritudine animæ exaudietur deprecatio illius: exaudiet autem eum, qui fecit illum.

verses.textEn: Make yourself a friend to the congregation of the poor, and humble your soul before an elder, and humble your head before the great.
verses.textLa: Congregationi pauperum affabilem te facito, et presbytero humilia animam tuam, et magnato humilia caput tuum.

verses.textEn: Turn your ear without sadness toward the poor, and repay your debt, and respond to him peacefully in meekness.
verses.textLa: Declina pauperi sine tristitia aurem tuam, et redde debitum tuum, et responde illi pacifica in mansuetudine.

verses.textEn: Free him who suffers injury at the hand of the arrogant, and do not carry animosity in your soul.
verses.textLa: Libera eum, qui iniuriam patitur de manu superbi: et non acide feras in anima tua.

verses.textEn: In judging, be merciful to the orphan, like a father, and be merciful to their mother, like a husband.
verses.textLa: In iudicando esto pupillis misericors ut pater, et pro viro matri illorum:

verses.textEn: And then you shall be like an obedient son of the Most High, and he will take pity on you more than a mother would.
verses.textLa: et eris tu velut filius Altissimi obediens, et miserebitur tui magis quam mater.

verses.textEn: Wisdom breathes life into her sons, and she lifts up those who are seeking her, and she will precede them in the way of justice.
verses.textLa: Sapientia filiis suis vitam inspirat, et suscipit inquirentes se, et præibit in via iustitiæ.

verses.textEn: And he who loves her loves life. And those who watch for her shall embrace her delights.
verses.textLa: Et qui illam diligit, diligit vitam: et qui vigilaverint ad illam, complectentur placorem eius.

verses.textEn: Those who hold to her will inherit life. And whatever place she enters, God will bless.
verses.textLa: Qui tenuerint illam, vitam hereditabunt: et quo introibit, benedicet Deus.

verses.textEn: Those who serve her will yield to what is holy. And God loves those who love wisdom.
verses.textLa: Qui serviunt ei, obsequentes erunt sancto: et eos, qui diligunt illam, diligit Deus.

verses.textEn: He who listens to her shall judge the nations. And he who gazes upon her will remain secure.
verses.textLa: Qui audit illam, iudicabit gentes: et qui intuetur illam, permanebit confidens.

verses.textEn: If he believes in her, he will inherit her, and whatever arises from him will be confirmed.
verses.textLa: Si crediderit ei, hereditabit illam, et erunt in confirmatione creaturæ illius.

verses.textEn: For she walks with him through temptation, and she chooses him from the beginning.
verses.textLa: Quoniam in tentatione ambulat cum eo, et in primis eligit eum.

verses.textEn: She will lead fear and dread and trials over him, and she will crucify him with the tribulation of her doctrine, until she has tested him in his thoughts and she can trust in his soul.
verses.textLa: Timorem et metum, et probationem inducet super illum: et cruciabit illum in tribulatione doctrinæ suæ, donec tentet eum in cogitationibus suis, et credat animæ illius.

verses.textEn: And then she will strengthen him, and lead him along a straight path, and rejoice in him.
verses.textLa: Et firmabit illum, et iter adducet directum ad illum, et lætificabit illum,

verses.textEn: And she will disclose her secrets to him, and she will store up treasure, of the knowledge and understanding of justice, in him.
verses.textLa: et denudabit absconsa sua illi, et thesaurizabit super illum scientiam et intellectum iustitiæ.

verses.textEn: But if he has wandered astray, she will leave him behind, and she will deliver him into the hands of his enemy.
verses.textLa: Si autem oberraverit, derelinquet eum, et tradet eum in manus inimici sui.

verses.textEn: Son, be continually observant, and keep away from evil.
verses.textLa: Fili conserva tempus, et devita a malo.

verses.textEn: For the sake of your soul, you should not be ashamed to speak the truth.
verses.textLa: Pro anima tua ne confundaris dicere verum.

verses.textEn: For there is a shame that brings sin, and there is a shame that brings glory and grace.
verses.textLa: Est enim confusio adducens peccatum, et est confusio adducens gloriam et gratiam.

verses.textEn: You should not accept a face contrary to your own face, nor should you accept a lie contrary to your own soul.
verses.textLa: Ne accipias faciem adversus faciem tuam, nec adversus animam tuam mendacium.

verses.textEn: You should not enjoy the fall of your neighbor.
verses.textLa: Ne reverearis proximum tuum in casu suo:

verses.textEn: Neither should you withhold words at an opportunity for salvation. You should not conceal your wisdom in her beauty.
verses.textLa: nec retineas verbum in tempore salutis. Non abscondas sapientiam tuam in decore suo.

verses.textEn: For wisdom is discerned within speech. And understanding and knowledge and doctrine are discerned in the words of those who understand and by their steadfastness in the works of justice.
verses.textLa: In lingua enim sapientia dignoscitur: et sensus, et scientia, et doctrina in verbo sensati, et firmamentum in operibus iustitiæ.

verses.textEn: You should not contradict a word of truth in any way. Otherwise, by a falsehood born of ignorance, you will be confounded.
verses.textLa: Non contradicas verbo veritatis ullo modo, et de mendacio ineruditionis tuæ confundere.

verses.textEn: You should not be ashamed to confess your sins, but do not subject yourself to any man because of sin.
verses.textLa: Non confundaris confiteri peccata tua, et ne subiicias te omni homini pro peccato.

verses.textEn: Do not choose to stand against the face of the powerful, for you should not strive against the current of the river.
verses.textLa: Noli resistere contra faciem potentis, nec coneris contra ictum fluvii.

verses.textEn: Suffer for justice, on behalf of your soul, and struggle, even unto death, on behalf of justice, and God will fight against your enemies on your behalf.
verses.textLa: Pro iustitia agonizare pro anima tua, et usque ad mortem certa pro iustitia, et Deus expugnabit pro te inimicos tuos.

verses.textEn: Do not choose to be quick with your words, nor unproductive or neglectful in your works.
verses.textLa: Noli citatus esse in lingua tua: et inutilis, et remissus in operibus tuis.

verses.textEn: Do not choose to be like a lion in your house, distressing those of your household, and oppressing those who are subject to you.
verses.textLa: Noli esse sicut leo in domo tua, evertens domesticos tuos, et opprimens subiectos tibi.

verses.textEn: Do not let your hand be open when receiving, but closed when giving.
verses.textLa: Non sit porrecta manus tua ad accipiendum, et ad dandum collecta.

verses.textEn: Do not choose to seek iniquitous possessions, and you should not say: “I have all I need in life.” For it will be of no benefit to you in the time of retribution and darkness.
verses.textLa: Noli attendere ad possessiones iniquas, et ne dixeris: Est mihi sufficiens vita: nihil enim proderit in tempore vindictæ et obductionis.

verses.textEn: You should not pursue, in your strength, the desires of your heart.
verses.textLa: Ne sequaris in fortitudine tua concupiscentiam cordis tui:

verses.textEn: And you should not say: “How powerful am I?” or, “Who will cast me down because of my deeds?” For God will vindicate with vengeance.
verses.textLa: et ne dixeris: Quomodo potui? aut: Quis me subiiciet propter facta mea? Deus enim vindicans vindicabit.

verses.textEn: You should not say, “I sinned, and what grief has befallen me?” For the Most High is a patient recompensor.
verses.textLa: Ne dixeris: Peccavi, et quid mihi accidit triste? Altissimus enim est patiens redditor.

verses.textEn: Do not be willing to be without fear concerning a forgiven sin, and you should not add sin upon sin.
verses.textLa: De propitiatio peccato noli esse sine metu, neque adiicias peccatum super peccatum.

verses.textEn: And you should not say: “The compassion of the Lord is great; he will take pity on the multitude of my sins.”
verses.textLa: Et ne dicas: Miseratio Domini magna est, multitudinis peccatorum meorum miserebitur.

verses.textEn: For both mercy and wrath go forth quickly from him, and his wrath sets its gaze upon sinners.
verses.textLa: Misericordia enim, et ira ab illo cito proximant, et in peccatores respicit ira illius.

verses.textEn: You should not delay being converted to the Lord, and you should not set it aside from day to day.
verses.textLa: Non tardes converti ad Dominum, et ne differas de die in diem.

verses.textEn: For his wrath will approach suddenly, and in the time of vindication, he will destroy you.
verses.textLa: Subito enim veniet ira illius, et in tempore vindictæ disperdet te.

verses.textEn: Do not choose to be anxious for unjust wealth. For these things will not benefit you in the day of darkness and retribution.
verses.textLa: Noli anxius esse in divitiis iniustis: non enim proderunt tibi in die obductionis et vindictæ.

verses.textEn: You should not winnow in every wind, and you should not go forth into every path. For so is every sinner proven by his duplicitous tongue.
verses.textLa: Non ventiles te in omnem ventum, et non eas in omnem viam. Sic enim omnis peccator probatur in duplici lingua.

verses.textEn: Be steadfast in the way of the Lord and in the truth of your understanding and knowledge, and let words of peace and justice overtake you.
verses.textLa: Esto firmus in via Domini, et in veritate sensus tui et scientia, et prosequatur te verbum pacis et iustitiæ.

verses.textEn: Be meek when listening to a word, so that you may understand. And offer a true response in wisdom.
verses.textLa: Esto mansuetus ad audiendum verbum, ut intelligas: et cum sapientia proferas responsum verum.

verses.textEn: If you understand, then answer your neighbor. But if you do not, then let your hand be over your mouth, so that you are not caught by an inept word, and then confounded.
verses.textLa: Si est tibi intellectus, responde proximo: sin autem, sit manus tua super os tuum, ne capiaris in verbo indisciplinato, et confundaris.

verses.textEn: Honor and glory are in the words of those who understand, yet truly, the tongue of the imprudent man is his undoing.
verses.textLa: Honor et gloria in sermone sensati, lingua vero imprudentis subversio est ipsius.

verses.textEn: You should not be called a whisperer, and you should not be caught by your own tongue, and then confounded.
verses.textLa: Non appelleris susurro, et lingua tua ne capiaris, et confundaris.

verses.textEn: For confusion and remorse is upon a thief, and a wicked mark is upon the double-tongued; but for the whisperer, there is hatred and animosity and disgrace.
verses.textLa: Super furem enim est confusio et pœnitentia, et denotatio pessima super bilinguem: susurratori autem odium, et inimicitia, et contumelia.

verses.textEn: Justify the small and the great similarly.
verses.textLa: Iustifica pusillum, et magnum similiter.

verses.textEn: Do not be willing to become an enemy instead of a friend to your neighbor. For an evil man will inherit reproach and disgrace, as will every sinner who is envious and double-tongued.
verses.textLa: Noli fieri pro amico inimicus proximo: improperium enim et contumeliam malus hereditabit, et omnis peccator invidus et bilinguis.

verses.textEn: You should not extol yourself, like a bull, in the thoughts of your soul, lest perhaps your strength may be cast down through foolishness,
verses.textLa: Non te extollas in cogitatione animæ tuæ velut taurus: ne forte elidatur virtus tua per stultitiam,

verses.textEn: which would consume your leaves, and destroy your fruit, and leave you behind like a dry tree in the desert.
verses.textLa: et folia tua comedat, et fructus tuos perdat, et relinquaris velut lignum aridum in eremo.

verses.textEn: For a wicked soul will destroy the one who has it. For it gladly provides enemies to him, and it will lead him to the fate of the impious.
verses.textLa: Anima enim nequam disperdet qui se habet, et in gaudium inimicis dat illum, et deducet in sortem impiorum.

verses.textEn: A sweet word multiplies friends and mitigates enemies. And thankful words abound in a good man.
verses.textLa: Verbum dulce multiplicat amicos, et mitigat inimicos: et lingua eucharis in bono homine abundat.

verses.textEn: Allow many to be at peace with you, but allow one out of a thousand to be your counselor.
verses.textLa: Multi pacifici sint tibi, et consiliarius sit tibi unus de mille.

verses.textEn: If you would obtain a friend, test him before you accept him, and do not trust him readily.
verses.textLa: Si possides amicum, in tentatione posside eum, et ne facile credas ei.

verses.textEn: For there is a friend according to his own time, but he will not remain in the day of tribulation.
verses.textLa: Est enim amicus secundum tempus suum, et non permanebit in die tribulationis.

verses.textEn: And there is a friend who can be turned to animosity. And there is a friend who will reveal hatred and ridicule and insults.
verses.textLa: Et est amicus qui convertitur ad inimicitiam: et est amicus qui odium et rixam, et convitia denudabit.

verses.textEn: And there is a friend who is a companion at table, but he will not remain in a day of need.
verses.textLa: Est autem amicus socius mensæ, et non permanebit in die necessitatis.

verses.textEn: A friend, if he remains steadfast, will be to you as you are to yourself, and he will act with faithfulness among those of your household.
verses.textLa: Amicus si permanserit fixus, erit tibi quasi coæqualis, et in domesticis tuis fiducialiter aget:

verses.textEn: If he humbles himself before you and hides himself from your face, you shall have a noble and harmonious friendship.
verses.textLa: si humiliaverit se contra te, et a facie tua absconderit se, unanimem habebis amicitiam bonam.

verses.textEn: Distance yourself from your enemies, and pay attention to your friends.
verses.textLa: Ab inimicis tuis separare, et ab amicis tuis attende.

verses.textEn: A faithful friend is a strong shelter, and whoever has found one has found a treasure.
verses.textLa: Amicus fidelis, protectio fortis: qui autem invenit illum, invenit thesaurum.

verses.textEn: Nothing is comparable to a faithful friend, and no weight of silver or gold is worth more than the goodness of his fidelity.
verses.textLa: Amico fideli nulla est comparatio, et non est digna ponderatio auri et argenti contra bonitatem fidei illius.

verses.textEn: A faithful friend is a medicine for life and immortality; and those who fear the Lord will find one.
verses.textLa: Amicus fidelis, medicamentum vitæ et immortalitatis: et qui metuunt Dominum, invenient illum.

verses.textEn: He who fears God will have a similar good friendship, because his friend will be like him.
verses.textLa: Qui timet Deum, æque habebit amicitiam bonam: quoniam secundum illum erit amicus illius.

verses.textEn: Son, from your youth receive instruction, and then you will find wisdom, even to your grey hairs.
verses.textLa: Fili a iuventute tua excipe doctrinam, et usque ad canos invenies sapientiam.

verses.textEn: Approach wisdom like one who plows and sows, and then wait for her good fruits.
verses.textLa: Quasi is qui arat, et seminat, accede ad eam, et sustine bonos fructus illius.

verses.textEn: For in doing her work, you will labor a little, but you will soon eat from her produce.
verses.textLa: In opere enim ipsius exiguum laborabis, et cito edes de generationibus illius.

verses.textEn: How exceedingly harsh is wisdom to unlearned men! And so, the witless will not remain with her.
verses.textLa: Quam aspera est nimium sapientia indoctis hominibus, et non permanebit in illa excors.

verses.textEn: She will be to them like a great stone of trial, and they will cast her away from them without delay.
verses.textLa: Quasi lapidis virtus probatio erit in illis, et non demorabuntur proiicere illam.

verses.textEn: For the wisdom of doctrine is in accord with her name, and she is not manifest to many. But she continues with those by whom she is recognized, even in the sight of God.
verses.textLa: Sapientia enim doctrinæ secundum nomen est eius, et non est multis manifestata: quibus autem cognita est, permanet usque ad conspectum Dei.

verses.textEn: Listen, son, and accept an understanding counsel, for you should not discard my advice.
verses.textLa: Audi fili, et accipe consilium intellectus, et ne abiicias consilium meum.

verses.textEn: Set your feet in her fetters and your neck in her chains.
verses.textLa: Iniice pedem tuum in compedes illius, et in torques illius collum tuum:

verses.textEn: Incline your shoulder, and carry her, for you will not be grieved by her bindings.
verses.textLa: subiice humerum tuum, et porta illam, et ne acedieris vinculis eius.

verses.textEn: Approach her with all your soul, and serve her ways with all your strength.
verses.textLa: In omni animo tuo accede ad illam, et in omni virtute tua conserva vias eius.

verses.textEn: Examine her, and she will be revealed to you, and when you have obtained her, you should not abandon her.
verses.textLa: Investiga illam, et manifestabitur tibi, et continens factus ne derelinquas eam:

verses.textEn: For, in the very end, you will find rest in her, and she will turn into your delight.
verses.textLa: in novissimis enim invenies requiem in ea, et convertetur tibi in oblectationem.

verses.textEn: Then her fetters will be a strong protection and a firm foundation for you, and her chains will be a robe of glory.
verses.textLa: Et erunt tibi compedes eius in protectionem fortitudinis, et bases virtutis, et torques illius in stolam gloriæ:

verses.textEn: For in her is the beauty of life, and her bindings are a healing bandage.
verses.textLa: decor enim vitæ est in illa, et vincula illius alligatura salutaris.

verses.textEn: You will be clothed with her as with a robe of glory, and you will set her upon your head like a crown of rejoicing.
verses.textLa: Stolam gloriæ indues eam, et coronam gratulationis superpones tibi.

verses.textEn: Son, if you heed me, you will learn. And if you adapt your mind, you will be wise.
verses.textLa: Fili, si attenderis mihi, disces: et si accomodaveris animum tuum, sapiens eris.

verses.textEn: If you incline your ear, you will receive doctrine. And if you love to listen, you will be wise.
verses.textLa: Si inclinaveris aurem tuam, excipies doctrinam: et si dilexeris audire, sapiens eris.

verses.textEn: Stand among the multitude of prudent elders, and join yourself to their wisdom from the heart, so that you may be able to hear every discourse about God, and so that the proverbs of praise may not flee from you.
verses.textLa: In multitudine presbyterorum prudentium sta, et sapientiæ illorum ex corde coniungere, ut omnem narrationem Dei possis audire, et proverbia laudis non effugiant a te.

verses.textEn: And if you see a man of understanding, stand watch for him, and let your feet wear down the steps of his doors.
verses.textLa: Et si videris sensatum, evigila ad eum, et gradus ostiorum illius exterat pes tuus.

verses.textEn: Set your thoughts on the precepts of God, and be entirely constant in his commandments. And he himself will give a heart to you, and the desire of wisdom will be given to you.
verses.textLa: Cogitatum tuum habe in præceptis Dei, et in mandatis illius maxime assiduus esto: et ipse dabit tibi cor, et concupiscentia sapientiæ dabitur tibi.

verses.textEn: Do not choose to do evil, and evil will not take hold of you.
verses.textLa: Noli facere mala, et non te apprehendent.

verses.textEn: Withdraw from the iniquitous, and evil will withdraw from you.
verses.textLa: Discede ab iniquo, et deficient mala abs te.

verses.textEn: Son, do not sow evil in the furrows of injustice, and you will not reap them sevenfold.
verses.textLa: Fili, non semines mala in sulcis iniustitiæ, et non metes ea in septuplum.

verses.textEn: Do not seek a role of leadership from the Lord, and do not seek a seat of honor from the king.
verses.textLa: Noli quærere a Domino ducatum, neque a rege cathedram honoris.

verses.textEn: You should not justify yourself before God, for he is the Knower of hearts. And by no means should you wish to seem wise before the king.
verses.textLa: Non te iustifices ante Deum, quoniam agnitor cordis ipse est: et penes regem noli velle videri sapiens.

verses.textEn: Do not seek to become a judge, unless you have sufficient strength to shatter iniquities. Otherwise, you might fear the face of the powerful, and so establish a scandal within your integrity.
verses.textLa: Noli quærere fieri iudex, nisi valeas virtute irrumpere iniquitates: ne forte extimescas faciem potentis, et ponas scandalum in æquitate tua.

verses.textEn: You should not sin against the multitude of a city, nor should you cast yourself against the people.
verses.textLa: Non pecces in multitudinem civitatis, nec te immittas in populum,

verses.textEn: And you should not bind two sins together. For even in one sin, you will not go unpunished.
verses.textLa: neque alliges duplicia peccata: nec enim in uno eris immunis.

verses.textEn: Do not be cowardly in your soul.
verses.textLa: Noli esse pusillanimis in animo tuo:

verses.textEn: You should not be unwilling to beg, nor to give alms.
verses.textLa: exorare, et facere eleemosynam ne despicias.

verses.textEn: You should not say: “God will look with favor on the multitude of my gifts, and when I make an offering to the most high God, he will accept my gift.”
verses.textLa: Ne dicas: In multitudine munerum meorum respiciet Deus, et offerente me Deo altissimo, munera mea suscipiet.

verses.textEn: You should not ridicule a man in bitterness of soul. For there is One who humbles and who exalts: the all-seeing God.
verses.textLa: Non irrideas hominem in amaritudine animæ: est enim qui humiliat et exaltat, circumspector Deus.

verses.textEn: Do not love a lie against your brother, nor should you act the same toward your friend.
verses.textLa: Noli amare mendacium adversus fratrem tuum: neque in amicum similiter facias.

verses.textEn: Do not be willing to devise a lie of any kind. For the practice of lying is not good.
verses.textLa: Noli velle mentiri omne mendacium: assiduitas enim illius non est bona.

verses.textEn: Do not choose to be verbose among a multitude of elders, and you should not repeat the words of your prayers.
verses.textLa: Noli verbosus esse in multitudine presbyterorum, et non iteres verbum in oratione tua.

verses.textEn: You should not hate laborious works, nor the rustic life created by the Most High.
verses.textLa: Non oderis laboriosa opera, et rusticationem creatam ab Altissimo.

verses.textEn: You should not consider yourself to be among the multitude of the undisciplined.
verses.textLa: Non te reputes in multitudine indisciplinatorum.

verses.textEn: Remember wrath. For it will not be delayed.
verses.textLa: Memento iræ, quoniam non tardabit.

verses.textEn: Humble your spirit greatly. For the retribution against the flesh of the impious is with fire and worms.
verses.textLa: Humilia valde spiritum tuum: quoniam vindicta carnis impii, ignis et vermis.

verses.textEn: Do not betray your friend for the sake of money, and you should not spurn your dearest brother for the sake of gold.
verses.textLa: Noli prævaricari in amicum pecuniam differentem, neque fratrem charissimum auro spreveris.

verses.textEn: Do not choose to depart from a good and understanding wife, whom you have been allotted in the fear of the Lord. For the grace of her modesty is above gold.
verses.textLa: Noli discedere a muliere sensata et bona, quam sortitus es in timore Domini: gratia enim verecundiæ illius super aurum.

verses.textEn: You should not harm the servant whose works are honest, nor the hired hand who entrusts his life to you.
verses.textLa: Non lædas servum in veritate operantem, neque mercenarium dantem animam suam.

verses.textEn: Let an understanding servant be loved by you like your own soul. You should not cheat him out of freedom, nor abandon him to destitution.
verses.textLa: Servus sensatus sit tibi dilectus quasi anima tua, non defraudes illum libertate, neque inopem derelinquas illum.

verses.textEn: Are cattle yours? Tend to them. And if they are useful, let them remain with you.
verses.textLa: Pecora tibi sunt? Attende illis: et si sunt utilia, perseverent apud te.

verses.textEn: Are sons yours? Instruct them, and bow them down from their childhood.
verses.textLa: Filii tibi sunt? Erudi illos, et curva illos a pueritia illorum.

verses.textEn: Are daughters yours? Watch over their bodies. And you should not display a light-hearted attitude toward them.
verses.textLa: Filiæ tibi sunt? Serva corpus illarum, et non ostendas hilarem faciem tuam ad illas.
verses.notes: The word ‘hilarem’ is not mere cheerfulness, but has more of a negative connotation, something akin to silly or fatuous, or the like.

verses.textEn: Give your daughter in marriage, and give her to an understanding man, and you will be doing a great work.
verses.textLa: Trade filiam, et grande opus feceris, et homini sensato da illam.

verses.textEn: If a wife in accord with your soul is yours, you should not reject her. But do not entrust yourself to her who is hateful.
verses.textLa: Mulier si est tibi secundum animam tuam, non proiicias illam: et odibili non credas te.

verses.textEn: With your whole heart, honor your father. And you should not forget the complaints of your mother.
verses.textLa: In toto corde tuo, honora patrem tuum, et gemitus matris tuæ ne obliviscaris:

verses.textEn: Remember that you would not have been born except through them. And so, give back to them as they also have done for you.
verses.textLa: memento quoniam nisi per illos natus non fuisses: et retribue illis, quomodo et illi tibi.

verses.textEn: With all your soul, fear the Lord, and consider his priests to be holy.
verses.textLa: In tota anima tua time Dominum, et sacerdotes illius sanctifica.

verses.textEn: With all your strength, love him who made you, and you should not abandon his ministers.
verses.textLa: In omni virtute tua dilige eum qui te fecit: et ministros eius ne derelinquas.

verses.textEn: Honor God from your whole soul, and confer honor on the priests, and continue to purify yourself with your strength.
verses.textLa: Honora Deum ex tota anima tua, et honorifica sacerdotes, et propurga te cum brachiis.
verses.notes: Because of the prefix ‘pro’ in ‘propurga,’ the meaning is of continued purification.

verses.textEn: Give them their portion, just as it has been commanded of you, from the first-fruits and from the purifications. And for your ignorant offenses, purify yourself with a smaller offering.
verses.textLa: Da illis partem, sicut mandatum est tibi, primitiarum et purgationis: et de negligentia tua purga te cum paucis.

verses.textEn: You should offer to the Lord the gift of your strength, and the sacrifice of sanctification, and the first-fruits of what is holy.
verses.textLa: Datum brachiorum tuorum et sacrificium sanctificationis offeres Domino, et initia sanctorum:

verses.textEn: And reach out your hand to the poor, so that your atonement and your blessing may be perfected.
verses.textLa: et pauperi porrige manum tuam, ut perficiatur propitiatio, et benedictio tua.

verses.textEn: A gift has grace in the sight of all the living, but you should not prohibit grace for the dead.
verses.textLa: Gratia dati in conspectu omnis viventis, et mortuo non prohibeas gratiam.

verses.textEn: You should not fail to console those who are weeping, nor to walk with those who are mourning.
verses.textLa: Non desis plorantibus in consolatione, et cum lugentibus ambula.

verses.textEn: Do not let yourself be slow to visit the sick. For in this way, you will be confirmed in love.
verses.textLa: Non te pigeat visitare infirmum: ex his enim in dilectione firmaberis.

verses.textEn: In all your works, remember your very end, and so you will not sin, unto eternity.
verses.textLa: In omnibus operibus tuis memorare novissima tua, et in æternum non peccabis.

verses.textEn: You should not quarrel with a powerful man, lest perhaps you may fall into his hands.
verses.textLa: Non litiges cum homine potente, ne forte incidas in manus illius.

verses.textEn: You should not contend with a wealthy man, lest perhaps he may bring an action against you.
verses.textLa: Non contendas cum viro locuplete, ne forte contra te constituat litem tibi.

verses.textEn: For gold and silver have destroyed many, and have reached and corrupted even the hearts of kings.
verses.textLa: Multos enim perdidit aurum et argentum, et usque ad cor regum extendit, et convertit.

verses.textEn: You should not quarrel with a man who is full of words, for you should not cast wood upon his fire.
verses.textLa: Non litiges cum homine linguato, et non strues in ignem illius ligna.

verses.textEn: You should not confide in an ignorant man, lest he speak evil about your family.
verses.textLa: Non communices homini indocto, ne male de progenie tua loquatur.

verses.textEn: You should not despise a man who turns himself away from sin, nor reproach him with it. Remember that we are all subject to correction.
verses.textLa: Ne despicias hominem avertentem se a peccato, neque improperes ei. Memento quoniam omnes in correptione sumus.

verses.textEn: You should not spurn a man in his old age. For we are all subject to growing old.
verses.textLa: Ne spernas hominem in sua senectute: etenim ex nobis senescunt.

verses.textEn: Do not be willing to rejoice at the death of your enemy, knowing that we all die, and that we do not want others to rejoice over us.
verses.textLa: Noli de mortuo inimico tuo gaudere: sciens quoniam omnes morimur, et in gaudium nolumus venire.

verses.textEn: You should not despise the discourse of those who are old and wise; instead, ponder their proverbs.
verses.textLa: Ne despicias narrationem presbyterorum sapientium, et in proverbiis eorum conversare.

verses.textEn: For from them, you will learn wisdom and intelligent doctrine, so as to serve great men without blame.
verses.textLa: Ab ipsis enim disces sapientiam, et doctrinam intellectus, et servire magnatis sine querela.

verses.textEn: Do not allow the discourse of your elders to pass you by. For they have learned from their fathers.
verses.textLa: Non te prætereat narratio seniorum: ipsi enim didicerunt a patribus suis:

verses.textEn: And from them, you will learn understanding, and you will learn what response to give in a time of necessity.
verses.textLa: quoniam ab ipsis disces intellectum, et in tempore necessitatis dare responsum.

verses.textEn: You should not kindle the coals of sinners by arguing with them. For you might be scorched by the flame from the fire of their sins.
verses.textLa: Non incendas carbones peccatorum arguens eos, et ne incendaris flamma ignis peccatorum illorum.

verses.textEn: You should not stand against the face of a contemptuous person, otherwise he may sit down as if waiting in ambush against your words.
verses.textLa: Ne contra faciem stes contumeliosi, ne sedeat quasi insidiator ori tuo.

verses.textEn: You should not lend to a man who is stronger than you. But if you do lend, consider it lost.
verses.textLa: Noli fœnerari homini fortiori te: quod si fœneraveris, quasi perditum habe.

verses.textEn: You should not promise beyond your ability. But if you do promise, consider how to fulfill it.
verses.textLa: Non spondeas super virtutem tuam: quod si spoponderis, quasi restituens cogita.

verses.textEn: You should not judge against a judge. For he judges according to what is just.
verses.textLa: Non iudices contra iudicem: quoniam secundum quod iustum est iudicat.

verses.textEn: You should not go forth on the way with an audacious man, lest perhaps he may burden you with his evils. For he goes forth according to his own will, and you will perish with him in his folly.
verses.textLa: Cum audace non eas in via, ne forte gravet mala sua in te: ipse enim secundum voluntatem suam vadit, et simul cum stultitia illius peries.

verses.textEn: You should not start a conflict with an angry man, and you should not go into the desert with an audacious man. For shedding blood is nothing to him, and in a place where there is no help for you, he will overthrow you.
verses.textLa: Cum iracundo non facias rixam, et cum audace non eas in desertum: quoniam quasi nihil est ante illum sanguis, et ubi non est adiutorium, elidet te.

verses.textEn: You should not hold counsel with the foolish. For they are not able to love anything except what pleases them.
verses.textLa: Cum fatuis consilium non habeas: non enim poterunt diligere nisi quæ eis placent.

verses.textEn: You should not take counsel in the sight of an outsider. For you do not know what he will do next.
verses.textLa: Coram extraneo ne facias consilium: nescis enim quid pariet.

verses.textEn: You should not reveal your heart to every man, lest perhaps he may offer a false kindness to you, and then speak reproachfully about you.
verses.textLa: Non omni homini cor tuum manifestes: ne forte inferat tibi gratiam falsam, et convicietur tibi.

verses.textEn: You should not be jealous of the wife of your bosom, lest she reveal, because of you, the malice of a wicked lesson.
verses.textLa: Non zeles mulierem sinus tui, ne ostendat super te malitiam doctrinæ nequam.

verses.textEn: You should not give authority over your soul to a woman, lest she obtain your strength, and then you would be confounded.
verses.textLa: Non des mulieri potestatem animæ tuæ, ne ingrediatur in virtutem tuam, et confundaris.
verses.notes: Or: ‘power over your soul.’

verses.textEn: You should not look with favor on a woman with many desires, lest perhaps you may fall into her traps.
verses.textLa: Ne respicias mulierem multivolam: ne forte incidas in laqueos illius.

verses.textEn: You should not be continually in need of entertainment, nor should you be persuaded by it, lest perhaps you may perish by its effectiveness.
verses.textLa: Cum saltatrice ne assiduus sis: nec audias illam, ne forte pereas in efficacia illius.
verses.notes: This is not an condemnation of dancing or singing, but of the excessive use of entertainment in any form, lest perhaps the entertainment may have an excessive influence over you. The need to be constantly entertained is one of the fundamental flaws of modern secular society. A less literal translation is used here, in order to clarify the truth of this passage and to avoid misunderstanding.

verses.textEn: You should not stare at a virgin, lest perhaps you may be scandalized by her beauty.
verses.textLa: Virginem ne conspicias, ne forte scandalizeris in decore illius.

verses.textEn: You should not give your soul, in any way, to fornicators, lest you destroy yourself and your inheritance.
verses.textLa: Ne des fornicariis animam tuam in ullo: ne perdas te, et hereditatem tuam.

verses.textEn: Do not choose to look around in the streets of the city, nor should you wander along its thoroughfares.
verses.textLa: Noli circumspicere in vicis civitatis, nec oberraveris in plateis illius.

verses.textEn: Avert your face from an ornate woman, for you should not gaze upon strange beauty.
verses.textLa: Averte faciem tuam a muliere compta, et ne circumspicias speciem alienam.
verses.notes: The ornate woman is not merely a woman with some make-up and jewelry. This is a woman who is excessively and ostentatiously adorned. She does not use a modest adornment to complement and bring out her natural beauty, but instead she offers a beauty which is of the adornment itself. It is not her own beauty, but the beauty of another.

verses.textEn: Many have perished because of the beauty of a woman; and by this, desire is kindled like a fire.
verses.textLa: Propter speciem mulieris multi perierunt: et ex hoc concupiscentia quasi ignis exardescit.

verses.textEn: Every woman who is a fornicator will be trampled down, like the filth in the street.
verses.textLa: Omnis mulier, quæ est fornicaria, quasi stercus in via conculcabitur.

verses.textEn: Many, by admiring the beauty of the wife of another, have become reprobate. For familiarity with her flares up like a fire.
verses.textLa: Speciem mulieris alienæ multi admirati, reprobi facti sunt. Colloquium enim illius quasi ignis exardescit.

verses.textEn: You should not sit down at all with another man’s wife, nor recline with her on a couch.
verses.textLa: Cum aliena muliere ne sedeas omnino, nec accumbas cum ea super cubitum:

verses.textEn: And you should not argue with her over wine, lest perhaps your heart may turn toward her, and by your emotion, you would be toppled into perdition.
verses.textLa: et non alterceris cum illa in vino, ne forte declinet cor tuum in illam, et sanguine tuo labaris in perditionem.
verses.notes: If a man argues passionately with another man’s wife, while they are drinking wine, the passion of the argument might turn into the passion of the flesh, and then by his blood, i.e. his passion, he might commit adultery.

verses.textEn: You should not abandon an old friend. For a new one will not be similar to him.
verses.textLa: Ne derelinquas amicum antiquum: novus enim non erit similis illi.

verses.textEn: A new friend is like new wine. It will grow old, and then you will enjoy drinking it.
verses.textLa: Vinum novum, amicus novus: veterascet, et cum suavitate bibes illud.

verses.textEn: You should not envy the glory and wealth of a sinner. For you do not know what may be his undoing in the future.
verses.textLa: Non zeles gloriam, et opes peccatoris: non enim scis quæ futura sit illius subversio.

verses.textEn: The injury of the unjust should not please you, knowing that, until they are in hell, the impious will not please.
verses.textLa: Non placeat tibi iniuria iniustorum, sciens quoniam usque ad inferos non placebit impius.
verses.notes: The denizens of Hell are unable to sin and are compelled to acknowledge the whole truth about their lives and about God. Thus, in Hell, the wicked finally please.

verses.textEn: Keep yourself far from a man having the power to kill, and then you will not have the fear of death suspended over you.
verses.textLa: Longe abesto ab homine potestatem habente occidendi, et non suspicaberis timorem mortis.

verses.textEn: But if you do approach him, do nothing to offend, lest perhaps he may take away your life.
verses.textLa: Et si accesseris ad illum, noli aliquid committere, ne forte auferat vitam tuam.

verses.textEn: Know that this is a communion with death. For you would be entering the midst of snares, and walking upon the arms of the grieving.
verses.textLa: Communionem mortis scito: quoniam in medio laqueorum ingredieris, et super dolentium arma ambulabis.

verses.textEn: According to your ability, be cautious of your neighbor, and treat him as the wise and prudent would.
verses.textLa: Secundum virtutem tuam cave te a proximo tuo, et cum sapientibus et prudentibus tracta.

verses.textEn: Let just men be your companions, and let your glory be in the fear of God.
verses.textLa: Viri iusti sint tibi convivæ, et in timore Dei sit tibi gloriatio,

verses.textEn: And let the thought of God be in your mind, and let all your discourse be on the precepts of the Most High.
verses.textLa: et in sensu sit tibi cogitatus Dei, et omnis enarratio tua in præceptis Altissimi.

verses.textEn: Works will be praised for the hands of the artists, and a leader of the people will be praised for the wisdom of his words, yet truly, the word of the elders will be praised for its understanding.
verses.textLa: In manu artificum opera laudabuntur, et princeps populi in sapientia sermonis sui, in sensu vero seniorum verbum.

verses.textEn: A man full of words is a dread to his city, but one who speaks rashly will be hated for his word.
verses.textLa: Terribilis est in civitate sua homo linguosus: et temerarius in verbo suo odibilis erit.

verses.textEn: A wise judge will judge his people, and the leadership of an understanding man will be steadfast.
verses.textLa: Iudex sapiens iudicabit populum suum, et principatus sensati stabilis erit.

verses.textEn: As the judge of the people is, so also are his assistants. And whatever kind of man the ruler of a city is, of such a kind also are those who live in it.
verses.textLa: Secundum iudicem populi, sic et ministri eius: et qualis rector est civitatis, tales et inhabitantes in ea.

verses.textEn: A foolish king will be the ruin of his people. For cities will be inhabited through the understanding of those with power.
verses.textLa: Rex insipiens perdet populum suum: et civitates inhabitabuntur per sensum potentium.

verses.textEn: Power over the earth is in the hand of God, and, in due time, he will raise up a helpful leader over the earth.
verses.textLa: In manu Dei potestas terræ: et utilem rectorem suscitabit in tempus super illam.

verses.textEn: The prosperity of a man is in the hand of God, and he will place his honor above the face of the scribe.
verses.textLa: In manu Dei prosperitas hominis, et super faciem scribæ imponet honorem suum.

verses.textEn: You should forget all injury done to you by your neighbor, and you should do nothing among the works of injury.
verses.textLa: Omnis iniuriæ proximi ne memineris, et nihil agas in operibus iniuriæ.

verses.textEn: Arrogance is hateful in the sight of God and of men. And all iniquity among the nations is abominable.
verses.textLa: Odibilis coram Deo est et hominibus superbia: et execrabilis omnis iniquitas gentium.

verses.textEn: A kingdom is transferred from one people to another because of injustices, and injuries, and contempt, and every kind of deceit.
verses.textLa: Regnum a gente in gentem transfertur propter iniustitias, et iniurias, et contumelias, et diversos dolos.

verses.textEn: But nothing is more wicked than a greedy man. Why should that which is earth and ashes be arrogant?
verses.textLa: Avaro autem nihil est scelestius. Quid superbit terra et cinis?
verses.notes: Or: ‘dust and ashes’. Man was made out of dust from the earth.

verses.textEn: There is nothing more iniquitous than to love money. For such a one has sold even his own soul. For in his life, he casts aside his innermost being.
verses.textLa: Nihil est iniquius quam amare pecuniam. Hic enim et animam suam venalem habet: quoniam in vita sua proiecit intima sua.

verses.textEn: All power is of short life. A prolonged sickness is of grave concern to a physician.
verses.textLa: Omnis potentatus brevis vita. Languor prolixior gravat medicum.

verses.textEn: A physician causes a sickness to be shortened. So also, a king is here today, and tomorrow he will die.
verses.textLa: Brevem languorem præcidit medicus: sic et rex hodie est, et cras morietur.

verses.textEn: For when a man dies, he will inherit serpents, and wild beasts, and worms.
verses.textLa: Cum enim morietur homo, hereditabit serpentes, et bestias, et vermes.

verses.textEn: The beginning of the arrogance of man is apostasy from God.
verses.textLa: Initium superbiæ hominis, apostatare a Deo:

verses.textEn: For his heart has withdrawn from the One who made him. For arrogance is the beginning of all sin. Whoever holds to it, will be filled with evil words, and it will overthrow him in the end.
verses.textLa: quoniam ab eo, qui fecit illum, recessit cor eius. Quoniam initium omnis peccati est superbia: qui tenuerit illam, adimplebitur maledictis, et subvertet eum in finem.

verses.textEn: Because of this, the Lord has dishonored the gatherings of the evil, and he has destroyed them, even unto the end.
verses.textLa: Propterea exhonoravit Dominus conventus malorum, et destruxit eos usque in finem.

verses.textEn: God has destroyed the seats of arrogant leaders, and he has caused the meek to be seated in their place.
verses.textLa: Sedes ducum superborum destruxit Deus, et sedere fecit mites pro eis.

verses.textEn: The roots of arrogant nations, God has dried up, and the humble among these nations, he has planted.
verses.textLa: Radices gentium superbarum arefecit Deus, et plantavit humiles ex ipsis gentibus.

verses.textEn: The Lord has overthrown the lands of the Gentiles, and he has utterly destroyed them, even to their foundation.
verses.textLa: Terras gentium evertit Dominus, et perdidit eas usque ad fundamentum.

verses.textEn: He has dried up some of them, and he has utterly destroyed them, and he has caused their memory to depart from the earth.
verses.textLa: Arefecit ex ipsis, et disperdidit eos, et cessare fecit memoriam eorum a terra.

verses.textEn: God has abolished the memory of the arrogant, and he has left behind only the memory of those who are humble in mind.
verses.textLa: Memoria superborum perdidit Deus, et reliquit memoriam humilium sensu.

verses.textEn: Arrogance was not created for men, nor was an angry temperament created for the gender of women.
verses.textLa: Non est creata hominibus superbia: neque iracundia nationi mulierum.

verses.textEn: Those who fear God among the offspring of men will be honored. But those among the offspring who ignore the commandments of the Lord will be dishonored.
verses.textLa: Semen hominum honorabitur hoc, quod timet Deum: semen autem hoc exhonorabitur, quod præterit mandata Domini.

verses.textEn: In the midst of his brothers, a ruler has honor. And those who fear the Lord will have honor in his eyes.
verses.textLa: In medio fratrum rector illorum in honore: et qui timent Dominum, erunt in oculis illius.

verses.textEn: The fear of God is the glory of the wealthy, and of the honorable, and of the poor.
verses.textLa: Gloria divitum, honoratorum, et pauperum, timor Dei est:

verses.textEn: Do not choose to despise a just man who is poor, and do not choose to magnify a sinful man who is rich.
verses.textLa: noli despicere hominem iustum pauperem, et noli magnificare virum peccatorem divitem.

verses.textEn: The great man, and the judge, and the powerful have honor. But no one is greater than he who fears God.
verses.textLa: Magnus, et iudex, et potens est in honore: et non est maior illo, qui timet Deum.

verses.textEn: Those who are free will serve an understanding servant. And a prudent and disciplined man will not murmur at correction. But an ignorant man will not be honored.
verses.textLa: Servo sensato liberi servient: et vir prudens et disciplinatus non murmurabit correptus, et inscius non honorabitur.

verses.textEn: Do not choose to extol yourself in doing your work, and do not be unproductive during the time of distress.
verses.textLa: Noli extollere te in faciendo opere tuo, et noli cunctari in tempore angustiæ.

verses.textEn: He who works, and so abounds in all things, is better than he who boasts, and so lacks bread.
verses.textLa: Melior est qui operatur, et abundat in omnibus, quam qui gloriatur, et eget pane.

verses.textEn: Son, preserve your soul in meekness, and give it honor according to its merit.
verses.textLa: Fili in mansuetudine serva animam tuam, et da illi honorem secundum meritum suum.

verses.textEn: Who will justify one who sins in his soul? And who will honor one who dishonors his soul?
verses.textLa: Peccantem in animam suam quis iustificabit? Et quis honorificabit exhonorantem animam suam?

verses.textEn: The poor man is glorified by his discipline and fear. And there is a man who is honored because of his substance.
verses.textLa: Pauper gloriatur per disciplinam et timorem suum: et est homo qui honorificatur propter substantiam suam.

verses.textEn: But if someone is glorified in poverty, how much more in substance? And whoever is glorified in substance, let him fear poverty.
verses.textLa: Qui autem gloriatur in paupertate, quanto magis in substantia? Et qui gloriatur in substantia, paupertatem vereatur.

verses.textEn: The wisdom of one who is humble will exalt his head, and will cause him to sit down in the midst of great men.
verses.textLa: Sapientia humiliati exaltabit caput illius, et in medio magnatorum consedere illum faciet.

verses.textEn: You should not praise a man for his beauty, and you should not despise a man for his appearances.
verses.textLa: Non laudes virum in specie sua, neque spernas hominem in visu suo.

verses.textEn: The bee is small among flying things, but its fruit holds the summit of sweetness.
verses.textLa: Brevis in volatilibus est apis, et initium dulcoris habet fructus illius.

verses.textEn: You should not glory in clothing at any time, and you should not let yourself be extolled in the day of your honor. For the works of the Most High alone are wondrous; and glorious and hidden and unseen are his works.
verses.textLa: In vestitu ne glorieris umquam, nec in die honoris tui extollaris: quoniam mirabilia opera Altissimi solius, et gloriosa, et absconsa, et invisa opera illius.

verses.textEn: Many tyrants have sat upon a throne, and one whom no one would admire has worn a diadem.
verses.textLa: Multi tyranni sederunt in throno, et insuspicabilis portavit diadema.

verses.textEn: Many powerful men have been powerfully cast down, and the illustrious have been handed over into the hands of others.
verses.textLa: Multi potentes oppressi sunt valide, et gloriosi traditi sunt in manus alterorum.

verses.textEn: Before you inquire, you should not place blame on anyone; and when you have inquired, reprove justly.
verses.textLa: Priusquam interroges, ne vituperes quemquam: et cum interrogaveris, corripe iuste.

verses.textEn: Before you listen, you should not respond a word; and you should not interrupt in the middle of a discourse.
verses.textLa: Priusquam audias, ne respondeas verbum: et in medio sermonum ne adiicias loqui.

verses.textEn: You should not contend in a matter which does not concern you, and you should not sit in judgment together with sinners.
verses.textLa: De ea re, quæ te non molestat, ne certeris: et in iudicio peccantium ne consistas.

verses.textEn: Son, you should not be involved in many matters. And if you become rich, you will not be free from transgression. For if you pursue, you will not apprehend; and if you run ahead, you will not escape.
verses.textLa: Fili ne in multis sint actus tui: et si dives fueris, non eris immunis a delicto. Si enim secutus fueris, non apprehendes: et non effugies, si præcucurreris.
verses.notes: If you strive to follow the right path while rich, you will not reach this goal; and if you flee from transgression, but are rich, you will not escape transgression.

verses.textEn: There is an impious man who labors and hurries and grieves, but all the more will he be without abundance.
verses.textLa: Est homo laborans, et festinans, et dolens impius, et tanto magis non abundabit.

verses.textEn: There is a debilitated man in need of recovery, who is lacking in strength and abundant in poverty.
verses.textLa: Est homo marcidus egens recuperatione, plus deficiens virtute, et abundans paupertate:

verses.textEn: Yet the eye of God has looked with favor upon him for his benefit, and he has lifted him up from his humiliation, and he has exalted his head. And many have wondered at him, and they have honored God.
verses.textLa: et oculus Dei respexit illum in bono, et erexit eum ab humilitate ipsius, et exaltavit caput eius: et mirati sunt in illo multi, et honoraverunt Deum.

verses.textEn: Good things and misfortune, life and death, poverty and wealth, are from God.
verses.textLa: Bona et mala, vita et mors, paupertas et honestas a Deo sunt.

verses.textEn: Wisdom, and discipline, and knowledge of the law are with God. Love and the ways of good things are with him.
verses.textLa: Sapientia et disciplina, et scientia legis apud Deum. Dilectio, et viæ bonorum apud ipsum.

verses.textEn: Error and darkness have been created by sinners. And those who exult in evil, grow old in evil.
verses.textLa: Error et tenebræ peccatoribus concreata sunt: qui autem exultant in malis, consenescunt in malo.

verses.textEn: The gift of God remains with the just man, and his advancement will have success unto eternity.
verses.textLa: Datio Dei permanet iustis, et profectus illius successus habebit in æternum.

verses.textEn: There is one who is enriched by spending sparingly, and this is the extent of his reward.
verses.textLa: Est qui locupletatur parce agendo, et hæc est pars mercedis illius.

verses.textEn: About this, he says: “I have found rest for myself, and now I alone will eat from my goods.”
verses.textLa: In eo quod dicit: Inveni requiem mihi, et nunc manducabo de bonis meis solus:

verses.textEn: But he does not know how much time will pass before death approaches, and then he must leave everything behind to others and die.
verses.textLa: et nescit quod tempus præteriet, et mors appropinquet, et relinquat omnia aliis, et morietur.

verses.textEn: Stand fast in your covenant, and become familiar with it, and grow old in the work of your commandments.
verses.textLa: Sta in testamento tuo, et in illo colloquere, et in opere mandatorum tuorum veterasce.

verses.textEn: You should not spend time in the works of sinners. Instead, trust in God and remain in your own place.
verses.textLa: Ne manseris in operibus peccatorum. Confide autem in Deo, et mane in loco tuo.
