verses.textEn: For it is easy, in the eyes of God, to make a pauper suddenly rich.
verses.textLa: Facile est enim in oculis Dei subito honestare pauperem.

verses.textEn: The blessing of God hurries to reward the just man, and in a fleeting hour his advancement bears fruit.
verses.textLa: Benedictio Dei in mercedem iusti festinat, et in hora veloci processus illius fructificat.

verses.textEn: You should not say: “What do I need?” or, “What good will there be for me in this?”
verses.textLa: Ne dicas: Quid est mihi opus, et quæ erunt mihi ex hoc bona?

verses.textEn: You should not say: “I have enough for myself,” or, “What could be worse than this?”
verses.textLa: Ne dicas: Sufficiens mihi sum: et quid ex hoc pessimabor?

verses.textEn: In a day of good things, you should not be forgetful of misfortunes. And in a day of misfortunes, you should not be forgetful of good things.
verses.textLa: In die bonorum ne immemor sis malorum: et in die malorum ne immemor sis bonorum:

verses.textEn: For it is easy, in the sight of God, on the day of one’s passing, to repay each one according to his ways.
verses.textLa: quoniam facile est coram Deo in die obitus retribuere unicuique secundum vias suas.

verses.textEn: The affliction of an hour causes one to forget great delights, and in the end of a man is the uncovering of his works.
verses.textLa: Malitia horæ oblivionem facit luxuriæ magnæ, et in fine hominis denudatio operum illius.

verses.textEn: You should not praise any man before death. For a man is known by his children.
verses.textLa: Ante mortem ne laudes hominem quemquam, quoniam in filiis suis agnoscitur vir.

verses.textEn: You should not bring every man into your house. For many are the snares of the deceitful.
verses.textLa: Non omnem hominem inducas in domum tuam: multæ enim sunt insidiæ dolosi.

verses.textEn: For as a stomach with a bad smell vomits, and as a partridge is led into a cage, and like a deer led into a snare, so also is the heart of the arrogant. And it is like a bystander watching his neighbor fall.
verses.textLa: Sicut enim eructant præcordia fœtentium, et sicut perdix inducitur in caveam, et ut caprea in laqueum: sic et cor superborum, et sicut prospector videns casum proximi sui.
verses.notes: The heart of the arrogant does not help him, as it ought to, so it is like an uninvolved bystander, watching a man fall to his ruin.

verses.textEn: For it lies in ambush, and then turns good into evil, and it will place the blame on the elect.
verses.textLa: Bona enim in mala convertens insidiatur, et in electis imponet maculam.

verses.textEn: From one spark, a great fire grows; and from one deceitful man, much blood flows. But a very sinful man lies in ambush for blood.
verses.textLa: A scintilla una augetur ignis, et ab uno doloso augetur sanguis: homo vero peccator sanguini insidiatur.

verses.textEn: Pay close attention to yourself before a harmful man, for he fabricates evils. Otherwise, he may lead over you a whispered reproach unceasingly.
verses.textLa: Attende tibi a pestifero, fabricat enim mala: ne inducat super te subsannationem in perpetuum.

verses.textEn: Receive a stranger to yourself, and he will overthrow you with a whirlwind, and he will alienate you from what is your very own.
verses.textLa: Admitte ad te alienigenam, et subvertet te in turbine, et abalienabit te a tuis propriis.

verses.textEn: If you do good, know to whom you do it, and there will be many thanks for your good deeds.
verses.textLa: Si benefeceris, scito cui feceris, et erit gratia in bonis tuis multa.

verses.textEn: Do good to the just, and you will find great recompense, and if not from him, certainly from the Lord.
verses.textLa: Benefac iusto, et invenies retributionem magnam: et si non ab ipso, certe a Domino.

verses.textEn: For there is no good for someone who is always occupied in evil, or who does not give alms. For the Most High holds hatred for sinners, but he takes pity on the repentant.
verses.textLa: Non est enim ei bene qui assiduus est in malis, et eleemosynas non danti: quoniam et Altissimus odio habet peccatores, et misertus est pœnitentibus.

verses.textEn: Give to the merciful, and you should not assist the sinner. For the impious and the sinner will be repaid with the vengeance being held for them on the day of retribution.
verses.textLa: Da misericordi, et ne suscipias peccatorem: et impiis et peccatoribus reddet vindictam, custodiens eos in diem vindictæ.

verses.textEn: Give to the good, but you should not receive from a sinner.
verses.textLa: Da bono, et non receperis peccatorem.

verses.textEn: Do good to the humble, but you should not give to the impious; withhold your bread, do not give it to him, otherwise he may overpower you with it.
verses.textLa: Benefac humili, et non dederis impio: prohibe panes illi dari ne in ipsis potentior te sit:

verses.textEn: For you will find twice the evil for all the good you will have done to him. For the Most High also holds hatred for sinners, and he will repay vengeance to the impious.
verses.textLa: nam duplicia mala invenies in omnibus bonis, quæcumque feceris illi: quoniam et Altissimus odio habet peccatores, et impiis reddet vindictam.

verses.textEn: A friend will not be known in good times, and an enemy will not be hidden in adversity.
verses.textLa: Non agnoscetur in bonis amicus, et non abscondetur in malis inimicus.

verses.textEn: By the good fortune of a man, his enemies are grieved; and by his misfortune, a friend is revealed.
verses.textLa: In bonis viri, inimici illius in tristitia: et in malitia illius, amicus agnitus est.

verses.textEn: You should never trust your enemy. For his wickedness rusts like a brass pot.
verses.textLa: Non credas inimico tuo in æternum: sicut enim æramentum, æruginat nequitia illius:

verses.textEn: And if he humbles himself and goes about bowed down, increase your alertness and guard yourself from him.
verses.textLa: et si humiliatus vadat curvus, adiice animum tuum, et custodi te ab illo.

verses.textEn: You should not sit down anywhere near him, nor should you allow him to sit at your right hand, lest perhaps he may turn toward your place, and seek your seat, and then, in the very end, you would understand my words and be stung by my sermon.
verses.textLa: Non statuas illum penes te, nec sedeat ad dexteram tuam, ne forte conversus in locum tuum, inquirat cathedram tuam: et in novissimo agnosces verba mea, et in sermonibus meis stimuleris.

verses.textEn: Who will take pity on an enchanter struck by a serpent, or on someone who draws near to wild beasts? And so it is with one who keeps company with an iniquitous man and is involved in his sins.
verses.textLa: Quis miserebitur incantatori a serpente percusso, et omnibus, qui appropiant bestiis? Et sic qui comitatur cum viro iniquo, et obvolutus est in peccatis eius.

verses.textEn: For one hour, he will abide with you. But if you begin to turn aside, he will not permit it.
verses.textLa: Una hora tecum permanebit: si autem declinaveris, non supportabit.

verses.textEn: An enemy speaks sweetly with his lips, but in his heart, he waits in ambush, so that he may throw you into a pit.
verses.textLa: In labiis suis indulcat inimicus, et in corde suo insidiatur ut subvertat te in foveam.

verses.textEn: An enemy has tears in his eyes. But if he finds an opportunity, he will not be satisfied with blood.
verses.textLa: In oculis suis lacrymatur inimicus: et si invenerit tempus, non satiabitur sanguine:

verses.textEn: And if misfortunes happen upon you, you will find him there first.
verses.textLa: et si incurrerint tibi mala, invenies eum illic priorem.

verses.textEn: An enemy has tears in his eyes, but while pretending to help you, he will dig under your feet.
verses.textLa: In oculis suis lacrymatur inimicus, et quasi adiuvans suffodiet plantas tuas.

verses.textEn: He will shake his head, and clap his hands, and whisper much, and change his expression.
verses.textLa: Caput suum movebit, et plaudet manu, et multa susurrans commutabit vultum suum.

verses.textEn: Whoever touches pitch will be contaminated by it. And whoever associates with the arrogant will be clothed by arrogance.
verses.textLa: Qui tetigerit picem, inquinabitur ab ea: et qui communicaverit superbo, induet superbiam.

verses.textEn: Whoever associates with those more honorable than himself sets a burden on himself. And so, you should have no fellowship with someone who is wealthier than you.
verses.textLa: Pondus super se tollat qui honestiori se communicat. Et ditiori te ne socius fueris.

verses.textEn: What will the cooking pot have in common with the earthen vessel? And when they collide with one another, one will be broken.
verses.textLa: Quid communicabit cacabus ad ollam? Quando enim se colliserint, confringetur.

verses.textEn: The rich man has suffered no injustice, and yet he fumes. But the poor man, though he has been wounded, will remain silent.
verses.textLa: Dives iniuste egit, et fremet: pauper autem læsus tacebit.

verses.textEn: If you are generous, he will take you up; and when you have nothing, he will cast you aside.
verses.textLa: Si largitus fueris, assumet te: et si non habueris, derelinquet te.

verses.textEn: If you possess, he will feast with you, and he will empty you, and he will not grieve over you.
verses.textLa: Si habes, convivet tecum, et evacuabit te, et ipse non dolebit super te.

verses.textEn: If he has need of you, he will deceive you; and while smiling, he will give you hope. He will converse with you pleasantly, and he will say: “What is it that you need?”
verses.textLa: Si necessarius illi fueris, supplantabit te, et subridens spem dabit, narrans tibi bona, et dicet: Quid opus est tibi?

verses.textEn: And he will impress you with his foods, until he has drained you two or three times, and in the very end, he will ridicule you. And afterward, when he sees you, he will abandon you, and he will shake his head at you.
verses.textLa: Et confundet te in cibis suis, donec te exinaniat bis, et ter: et in novissimo deridebit te: et postea videns derelinquet te, et caput suum movebit ad te.

verses.textEn: Humble yourself before God, and wait for his hands.
verses.textLa: Humiliare Deo, et expecta manus eius.

verses.textEn: Be careful. Otherwise, having been seduced into foolishness, you will be humiliated.
verses.textLa: Attende ne seductus in stultitiam humilieris.

verses.textEn: Do not choose to be low in your wisdom, otherwise, having been brought low, you will be seduced into foolishness.
verses.textLa: Noli esse humilis in sapientia tua, ne humiliatus in stultitiam seducaris.

verses.textEn: If you are invited by someone who is more powerful than you, you should decline. Otherwise, he will invite you all the more.
verses.textLa: Advocatus a potentiore discede: ex hoc enim magis te advocabit.

verses.textEn: You cannot be rude to him, lest you be pushed away. And you cannot stray far from him, lest you be forgotten.
verses.textLa: Ne improbus sis, ne impingaris: et ne longe sis ab eo, ne eas in oblivionem.

verses.textEn: You cannot hold a discussion with him as with an equal. You should not trust his many words. For by much talking, he will probe you, and while smiling, he will question you about your secrets.
verses.textLa: Ne retineas ex æquo loqui cum illo: nec credas multis verbis illius. Ex multa enim loquela tentabit te, et subridens interrogabit te de absconditis tuis.

verses.textEn: His cruel mind will store up your words; and he will not spare you from affliction, nor from prison.
verses.textLa: Immitis animus illius conservabit verba tua: et non parcet de malitia, et de vinculis.

verses.textEn: Be cautious of yourself, and attend diligently to what you are hearing. For you are walking toward your own destruction.
verses.textLa: Cave tibi, et attende diligenter auditui tuo: quoniam cum subversione tua ambulas.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, while listening to these things, consider it as if it were a dream, and you will awaken.
verses.textLa: Audiens vero illa quasi in somnis vide, et vigilabis.

verses.textEn: Love God for your entire life, and call upon him for your salvation.
verses.textLa: Omni vita tua dilige Deum, et invoca illum in salute tua.

verses.textEn: Every animal loves its own kind; so also every man loves those closest to himself.
verses.textLa: Omne animal diligit simile sibi: sic et omnis homo proximum sibi.

verses.textEn: All flesh will join with whatever is similar to itself, and every man will associate with whomever is similar to himself.
verses.textLa: Omnis caro ad similem sibi coniungetur, et omnis homo simili sui sociabitur.

verses.textEn: If a wolf would at any time have fellowship with a lamb, so also would a sinner have fellowship with the just.
verses.textLa: Si communicabit lupus agno aliquando, sic peccator iusto.

verses.textEn: What fellowship does a holy man have with a dog? Or what portion do the wealthy have with the poor?
verses.textLa: Quæ communicatio sancto homini ad canem? Aut quæ pars diviti ad pauperem?

verses.textEn: In the desert, the wild donkey is the prey of the lion. So also are the poor the pasture of the rich.
verses.textLa: Venatio leonis onager in eremo: sic et pascua divitum, sunt pauperes.

verses.textEn: And just as humility is an abomination to the arrogant, so also does the rich man abhor the poor man.
verses.textLa: Et sicut abominatio est superbo humilitas: sic et execratio divitis pauper.

verses.textEn: When a wealthy man has been shaken, he is strengthened by his friends. But when a lowly man has fallen, he is expelled even by those who know him well.
verses.textLa: Dives commotus confirmatur ab amicis suis: humilis autem cum ceciderit expelletur et a notis.

verses.textEn: When a rich man has been deceived, many will help him recover; he has spoken arrogantly, and yet they justify him.
verses.textLa: Diviti decepto multi recuperatores: locutus est superbia, et iustificaverunt illum.

verses.textEn: When a poor man has been deceived, in addition he is rebuked; he has spoken with understanding, and no place is given to him.
verses.textLa: Humilis deceptus est, insuper et arguitur: locutus est sensate, et non est datus ei locus.

verses.textEn: The rich man has spoken, and all remain silent, and they repeat his words, even to the clouds.
verses.textLa: Dives locutus est, et omnes tacuerunt, et verbum illius usque ad nubes perducent.

verses.textEn: The poor man has spoken, and they say: “Who is this?” And if he stumbles, they will overthrow him.
verses.textLa: Pauper locutus est, et dicunt: Quis est hic? Et si offenderit, subvertent illum.

verses.textEn: Substance is good for him who has no sin on his conscience. And poverty is called very wicked by the mouth of the impious.
verses.textLa: Bona est substantia, cui non est peccatum in conscientia: et nequissima paupertas in ore impii.

verses.textEn: The heart of a man changes his face, either for better or for worse.
verses.textLa: Cor hominis immutat faciem illius, sive in bona, sive in mala.

verses.textEn: You will find, with difficulty and much labor, the sign of a good heart and a good face.
verses.textLa: Vestigium cordis boni, et faciem bonam difficile invenies, et cum labore.

verses.textEn: Blessed is the man who has not slipped because of a word from his mouth, and who has not been stung by grief because of an offense.
verses.textLa: Beatus vir, qui non est lapsus verbo ex ore suo, et non est stimulatus in tristitia delicti.

verses.textEn: Happy is he who does not have sadness in his mind, and who has not fallen away from his hope.
verses.textLa: Felix, qui non habuit animi sui tristitiam, et non excidit a spe sua.

verses.textEn: Substance is senseless for a greedy and stingy man. And what would a spiteful man do with gold?
verses.textLa: Viro cupido et tenaci sine ratione est substantia, et homini livido ad quid aurum?

verses.textEn: Whoever acquires unjustly, according to his own mind, gathers for others. For another will spend his goods lavishly.
verses.textLa: Qui acervat ex animo suo iniuste, aliis congregat, et in bonis illius alius luxuriabitur.

verses.textEn: Whoever is wicked to himself, to whom will he be good? For he will not take enjoyment in his own goods.
verses.textLa: Qui sibi nequam est, cui alii bonus erit? Et non iucundabitur in bonis suis.

verses.textEn: Whoever has ill will toward himself, nothing is more worthless than he is. But such is the reward of his wickedness.
verses.textLa: Qui sibi invidet, nihil est illo nequius, et hæc redditio est malitiæ illius:

verses.textEn: And if he does good, he does it ignorantly and unwillingly. And in the very end, he realizes his own malice.
verses.textLa: Et si bene fecerit, ignoranter, et non volens facit: et in novissimo manifestat malitiam suam.

verses.textEn: The eye of the spiteful man is wicked, and he averts his face and despises his own soul.
verses.textLa: Nequam est oculus lividi, et avertens faciem suam, et despiciens animam suam.

verses.textEn: The eye of the greedy man is insatiable in his portion of iniquity. He will not be satisfied until he has consumed his own soul, withering it away.
verses.textLa: Insatiabilis oculus cupidi in parte iniquitatis: non satiabitur donec consumat arefaciens animam suam.

verses.textEn: An evil eye is directed at evil things. And he will not be satisfied by bread; instead, he will be needy and grieving at his own table.
verses.textLa: Oculus malus ad mala: et non saturabitur pane, sed indigens et in tristitia erit super mensam suam.

verses.textEn: Son, if you have anything, do good to yourself, and offer worthy oblations to God.
verses.textLa: Fili si habes, benefac tecum, et Deo dignas oblationes offer.

verses.textEn: Remember that death has not been delayed, and that the covenant of the grave has been revealed to you. For the covenant of this world will pass away in death.
verses.textLa: Memor esto quoniam mors non tardat, et testamentum inferorum quia demonstratum est tibi: testamentum enim huius mundi morte morietur.
verses.notes: From the context, ‘inferorum’ does not refer to Hell, but to dying and the grave. The word ‘inferorum’ has a broader meaning, sometimes referring to Hell itself, sometimes to death under adverse circumstances, and some times merely to death or the grave.

verses.textEn: Do good to your friend before you die. And according to your ability, extend your hand and give to the poor.
verses.textLa: Ante mortem benefac amico tuo, et secundum vires tuas exporrigens da pauperi.

verses.textEn: Do not cheat yourself out of a good day, and do not let the smallest good gift pass you by.
verses.textLa: Non defrauderis a die bono, et particula boni doni non te prætereat.

verses.textEn: Should you not leave it to others to divide your sorrows and labors by lot?
verses.textLa: Nonne aliis relinques dolores et labores tuos in divisione sortis?

verses.textEn: Give, and receive, and justify your soul.
verses.textLa: Da, et accipe, et iustifica animam tuam.

verses.textEn: Before your passing, accomplish justice. For in death, there is no food to be found.
verses.textLa: Ante obitum tuum operare iustitiam: quoniam non est apud inferos invenire cibum.

verses.textEn: All flesh grows old like the grass, and like the foliage that springs forth from a green tree.
verses.textLa: Omnis caro sicut fœnum veterascet, et sicut folium fructificans in arbore viridi.

verses.textEn: Some spring up, and others fall away. Such is the generation of flesh and blood. One is finished, and another is born.
verses.textLa: Alia generantur, et alia deiiciuntur: sic generatio carnis et sanguinis, alia finitur, et alia nascitur.

verses.textEn: Every corruptible work will fail in the end. And its worker will go with it.
verses.textLa: Omne opus corruptibile in fine deficiet: et qui illud operatur, ibit cum illo.

verses.textEn: But every excellent work will be justified. And whoever worked it will be honored by it.
verses.textLa: Et omne opus electum iustificabitur: et qui operatur illud, honorabitur in illo.

verses.textEn: Blessed is the man who will abide in wisdom, and who will meditate on her righteousness, and who, in his mind, will consider the circumspection of God.
verses.textLa: Beatus vir, qui in sapientia morabitur, et qui in iustitia sua meditabitur, et in sensu cogitabit circumspectionem Dei.

verses.textEn: He considers her ways in his heart, and he finds understanding in her secrets. He goes after her like an investigator, and he is constant in her ways.
verses.textLa: Qui excogitat vias illius in corde suo, et in absconditis suis intelligens, vadens post illam quasi investigator, et in viis illius consistens:

verses.textEn: He gazes through her windows, and he listens at her door.
verses.textLa: qui respicit per fenestras illius, et in ianuis illius audiens:

verses.textEn: He rests next to her house, and, fastening a peg in her walls, he sets up his cottage by her hands. And so, good things will find rest in his cottage as time passes.
verses.textLa: qui requiescit iuxta domum illius, et in parietibus illius figens palum statuet casulam suam ad manus illius, et requiescent in casula illius bona per ævum:

verses.textEn: He will station his sons under her covering, and he will abide under her branches.
verses.textLa: statuet filios suos sub tegmine illius, et sub ramis eius morabitur.

verses.textEn: He will be protected by her covering from the heat, and he will rest in her glory.
verses.textLa: Protegetur sub tegmine illius a fervore, et in gloria eius requiescet.

verses.textEn: Whoever fears God will do good. And whoever holds to justice will obtain it.
verses.textLa: Qui timet Deum, faciet bona: et qui continens est iustitiæ, apprehendet illam,

verses.textEn: And like an honorable mother, she will meet him, and like a virgin bride, she will receive him.
verses.textLa: et obviabit illi quasi mater honorificata, et quasi mulier a virginitate suscipiet illum.

verses.textEn: She will feed him with the bread of life and understanding. And she will give him to drink from the water of salvific wisdom. And she will be confirmed in him, and he will not waver.
verses.textLa: Cibabit illum pane vitæ et intellectus, et aqua sapientiæ salutaris potabit illum: et firmabitur in illo, et non flectetur:

verses.textEn: And she will hold to him, and he will not be confounded. And she will exalt him, along with those closest to him.
verses.textLa: et continebit illum, et non confundetur: et exaltabit illum apud proximos suos,

verses.textEn: And in the midst of the Church, she will open his mouth, and she will fill him with the spirit of wisdom and understanding, and she will clothe him with a robe of glory.
verses.textLa: et in medio Ecclesiæ aperiet os eius, et adimplebit illum spiritu sapientiæ et intellectus, et stola gloriæ vestiet illum.

verses.textEn: She will store up in him a treasure of rejoicing and exultation, and she will cause him to inherit an everlasting name.
verses.textLa: Iucunditatem et exultationem thesaurizabit super illum, et nomine æterno hereditabit illum.

verses.textEn: But foolish men will not take hold of her. And though understanding men will meet her, foolish men will not catch sight of her. For she is far from arrogance and deceit.
verses.textLa: Homines stulti non apprehendent illam, et homines sensati obviabunt illi, homines stulti non videbunt eam: longe enim abest a superbia et dolo.

verses.textEn: Lying men will be wary of her. But men who speak the truth will be found with her, and they will have success, even when examined by God.
verses.textLa: Viri mendaces non erunt illius memores: et viri veraces invenientur in illa, et successum habebunt usque ad inspectionem Dei.

verses.textEn: Praise is not beautiful in the mouth of a sinner.
verses.textLa: Non est speciosa laus in ore peccatoris:

verses.textEn: For wisdom was sent from God. And praise will stand before the wisdom of God, and praise will abound in the mouths of the faithful, and the sovereign Lord will give praise to wisdom.
verses.textLa: quoniam a Deo profecta est sapientia. Sapientiæ enim Dei astabit laus, et in ore fideli abundabit, et Dominator dabit eam illi.

verses.textEn: You should not say: “It is because of God that wisdom is absent.” For you should not do what he detests.
verses.textLa: Non dixeris: Per Deum abest: quæ enim odit ne feceris.

verses.textEn: You should not say: “He has led me astray.” For the impious are of no use to him.
verses.textLa: Non dicas: Ille me implanavit: non enim necessarii sunt ei homines impii.

verses.textEn: The Lord hates all abominable error, and those who fear him will not love such things.
verses.textLa: Omne execramentum erroris odit Dominus, et non erit amabile timentibus eum.

verses.textEn: God established man from the beginning, and he left him in the hand of his own counsel.
verses.textLa: Deus ab initio constituit hominem, et reliquit illum in manu consilii sui.

verses.textEn: He added his commandments and precepts.
verses.textLa: Adiecit mandata et præcepta sua:

verses.textEn: If you choose to keep the commandments, and if, having chosen them, you fulfill them with perpetual fidelity, they will preserve you.
verses.textLa: si volueris mandata servare, conservabunt te, et in perpetuum fidem placitam facere.

verses.textEn: He has set water and fire before you. Extend your hand to whichever one you would choose.
verses.textLa: Apposuit tibi aquam et ignem: ad quod volueris, porrige manum tuam.

verses.textEn: Before man is life and death, good and evil. Whichever one he chooses will be given to him.
verses.textLa: Ante hominem vita et mors, bonum et malum: quod placuerit ei, dabitur illi:

verses.textEn: For the wisdom of God is manifold. And he is strong in power, seeing all things without ceasing.
verses.textLa: quoniam multa sapientia Dei, et fortis in potentia, videns omnes sine intermissione.

verses.textEn: The eyes of the Lord are upon those who fear him, and he knows each one of the works of man.
verses.textLa: Oculi Domini ad timentes eum, et ipse agnoscit omnem operam hominis.

verses.textEn: He has commanded no one to act impiously, and he has given no one permission to sin.
verses.textLa: Nemini mandavit impie agere, et nemini dedit spatium peccandi:

verses.textEn: For he does not desire a multitude of unfaithful and useless sons.
verses.textLa: non enim concupiscit multitudinem filiorum infidelium et inutilium.

verses.textEn: You should not rejoice in impious children, if they are successful; nor should you take delight in them, if the fear of God is not in them.
verses.textLa: Ne iucunderis in filiis impiis, si multiplicentur: nec oblecteris super ipsos, si non est timor Dei in illis.

verses.textEn: You should not approve of their life, nor should you look with favor on their labors.
verses.textLa: Non credas vitæ illorum, et ne respexeris in labores eorum.

verses.textEn: For one child who fears God is better than one thousand impious children.
verses.textLa: Melior est enim unus timens Deum, quam mille filii impii:

verses.textEn: And it is better to die without children, than to leave behind impious children.
verses.textLa: Et utile est mori sine filiis quam relinquere filios impios.

verses.textEn: By means of one person with understanding, a country will be inhabited. The tribe of the impious will become desolate.
verses.textLa: Ab uno sensato inhabitabitur patria, tribus impiorum deseretur.

verses.textEn: Many such things my eyes have seen, and greater things than these my ear has heard.
verses.textLa: Multa talia vidit oculis meus, et fortiora horum audivit auris mea.

verses.textEn: In the synagogue of sinners, a fire will blaze forth; and amid an unbelieving people, wrath will flare up.
verses.textLa: In synagoga peccantium exardebit ignis, et in gente incredibili exardescet ira.
verses.notes: This verse is a figure of the Antichrist, who will obtain support from sinful Jews, and of the false prophetess, who will obtain support from unbelieving Christians.

verses.textEn: The giants of antiquity did not obtain pardon for their sins; they were destroyed by trusting in their own abilities.
verses.textLa: Non exoraverunt pro peccatis suis antiqui gigantes, qui destructi sunt confidentes suæ virtuti:

verses.textEn: And he did not spare the place of Lot’s sojourn, and he abhorred them because of the arrogance of their words.
verses.textLa: et non pepercit peregrinationi Lot, et execratus est eos præ superbia verbi illorum.

verses.textEn: He did not take pity on them, destroying an entire people, who even extolled themselves concerning their sins.
verses.textLa: Non misertus est illis, gentem totam perdens, et extollentem se in peccatis suis.

verses.textEn: And this was so with six hundred thousand men, who were gathered together in the hardness of their hearts. And if even a single obstinate person had escaped unpunished, it would be a wonder.
verses.textLa: Et sicut sexcenta millia peditum, qui congregati sunt in duritia cordis sui: et si unus fuisset cervicatus, mirum si fuisset immunis.

verses.textEn: For mercy and wrath are with him. He is powerful in forgiveness, and he pours forth wrath.
verses.textLa: Misericordia enim et ira est cum illo. Potens exoratio, et effundens iram:

verses.textEn: As is his mercy, so also is his correction; he judges a man according to his works.
verses.textLa: secundum misericordiam suam, sic correptio illius homines secundum opera sua iudicat.

verses.textEn: The sinner, in his violations, will not escape; but the patience of the One who shows mercy will not be diminished.
verses.textLa: Non effugiet in rapina peccator, et non retardabit sufferentia misericordiam facientis.

verses.textEn: Every mercy will make a place for each man, according to the merit of his works, and according to the understanding of his sojourn.
verses.textLa: Omnis misericordia faciet locum unicuique secundum meritum operum suorum, et secundum intellectum peregrinationis ipsius.

verses.textEn: You should not say: “I am hidden from God,” or, “Who, from on high, will take note of me?”
verses.textLa: Non dicas: A Deo abscondar, et ex summo quis mei memorabitur?

verses.textEn: or, “Among a great number of people, I will not be noticed. For what is my soul amid such an immense creation?”
verses.textLa: In populo magno non agnoscar: quæ est enim anima mea in tam immensa creatura?

verses.textEn: Behold: the heavens, and the heaven of the heavens, the abyss, and the entire earth, and the things that are within these, will be shaken by his gaze,
verses.textLa: Ecce cælum, et cæli cælorum, abyssus, et universa terra, et quæ in eis sunt, in conspectu illius commovebuntur;

verses.textEn: together with mountains and hills, and the foundations of the earth. When God casts his gaze upon them, they will be struck with trembling.
verses.textLa: montes simul, et colles, et fundamenta terræ: cum conspexerit illa Deus, tremore concutientur.

verses.textEn: And concerning all these things, the heart is without understanding; but every heart is understood by him.
verses.textLa: Et in omnibus his insensatum est cor: et omne cor intelligitur ab illo:

verses.textEn: And who will understand his ways, or the tempest, which no eye of man will see?
verses.textLa: Et vias illius quis intelligit, et procellam, quam nec oculus videbit hominis?

verses.textEn: For many of his works are concealed. But who will announce the works of his justice? Or who will endure them? For the testament is far from some persons, and the examination of each thing is in its end.
verses.textLa: Nam plurima illius opera sunt in absconsis: sed opera iustitiæ eius quis enunciabit? Aut quis sustinebit? Longe enim est testamentum a quibusdam, et interrogatio omnium in consummatione est.

verses.textEn: Whoever diminishes the heart, thinks empty thoughts. For the imprudent and erring man thinks up foolishness.
verses.textLa: Qui minoratur corde, cogitat inania: et vir imprudens, et errans cogitat stulta.

verses.textEn: Listen to me, son, and learn the discipline of understanding, and attend to my words in your heart.
verses.textLa: Audi me fili, et disce disciplinam sensus, et in verbis meis attende in corde tuo,

verses.textEn: And I will speak with equity about discipline, and I will strive to announce wisdom. So attend to my words in your heart, and I will speak with equity of spirit, about the virtues that God has set within his works from the beginning, and I will announce his knowledge in truth.
verses.textLa: et dicam in æquitate disciplinam, et scrutabor enarrare sapientiam: et in verbis meis attende in corde tuo, et dico in æquitate spiritus virtutes, quas posuit Deus in opera sua ab initio, et in veritate enuncio scientiam eius.

verses.textEn: With the judgment of God, his works have been done from the beginning; and from their institution, he himself distinguished their parts and set their beginnings, in their kinds.
verses.textLa: In iudicio Dei opera eius ab initio, et ab institutione ipsorum distinxit partes illorum, et initia eorum in gentibus suis.

verses.textEn: He has beautified their works unto eternity. They have neither hungered, nor labored, and they have not ceased from their works.
verses.textLa: Ornavit in æternum opera illorum, nec esurierunt, nec laboraverunt, et non destiterunt ab operibus suis.

verses.textEn: Neither will any one of them cause anguish to his neighbor, forever.
verses.textLa: Unusquisque proximum sibi non angustiabit in æternum.

verses.textEn: You should not be incredulous at his word.
verses.textLa: Non sis incredibilis verbo illius.

verses.textEn: Afterward, God looked with favor upon the earth, and he filled it with his goodness.
verses.textLa: Post hæc Deus in terram respexit, et implevit illam bonis suis.

verses.textEn: The soul of every living thing brought word from before his face, and their return again is to him.
verses.textLa: Anima omnis vitalis denunciavit ante faciem ipsius, et in ipsam iterum reversio illorum.

verses.textEn: God created man from the earth, and he made him according to his own image.
verses.textLa: Deus creavit de terra hominem, et secundum imaginem suam fecit illum.

verses.textEn: And he returned him again to it, and he clothed him with virtue according to himself.
verses.textLa: Et iterum convertit illum in ipsam, et secundum se vestivit illum virtute.

verses.textEn: He gave him the number and time of his days, and he gave him authority over all the things that are upon the earth.
verses.textLa: Numerum dierum, et tempus dedit illi, et dedit illi potestatem eorum, quæ sunt super terram.

verses.textEn: He placed the fear of him over all flesh, and he had dominion over wild beasts and flying things.
verses.textLa: Posuit timorem illius super omnem carnem, et dominatus est bestiarum et volatilium.

verses.textEn: He created from him a helper, similar to himself. He gave them counsel, and language, and sight, and hearing, and a heart, in order to think. And he filled them with the discipline of understanding.
verses.textLa: Creavit ex ipso adiutorium simile sibi: consilium, et linguam, et oculos, et aures, et cor dedit illis excogitandi: et disciplina intellectus replevit illos.

verses.textEn: He created within them the knowledge of the spirit. He filled their heart with understanding, and he showed them both good and evil.
verses.textLa: Creavit illis scientiam spiritus, sensu implevit cor illorum, et mala et bona ostendit illis.

verses.textEn: He set his eye upon their hearts, to reveal to them the greatness of his works,
verses.textLa: Posuit oculum suum super corda illorum ostendere illis magnalia operum suorum,

verses.textEn: so that they might highly praise the name of sanctification, and give glory to his wonders, so that they might declare the greatness of his works.
verses.textLa: ut nomen sanctificationis collaudent: et gloriari in mirabilibus illius, ut magnalia enarrent operum eius.

verses.textEn: In addition, he gave them discipline and the law of life, as their inheritance.
verses.textLa: Addidit illis disciplinam, et legem vitæ hereditavit illos.

verses.textEn: He established an eternal covenant with them, and he revealed to them his justice and judgments.
verses.textLa: Testamentum æternum constituit cum illis, et iustitiam et iudicia sua ostendit illis.

verses.textEn: And their eye saw the greatness of his honor, and their ears heard the honor of his voice, and he said to them: “Beware of all iniquity.”
verses.textLa: Et magnalia honoris eius vidit oculus illorum, et honorem vocis audierunt aures illorum, et dixit illis: Attendite ab omni iniquo.

verses.textEn: And he commanded each one concerning his neighbor.
verses.textLa: Et mandavit illis unicuique de proximo suo.

verses.textEn: Their ways are always in his sight; they are not hidden from his eyes.
verses.textLa: Viæ illorum coram ipso sunt semper, non sunt absconsæ ab oculis ipsius.

verses.textEn: Over each and every people, he has appointed a ruler.
verses.textLa: In unamquamque gentem præposuit rectorem:

verses.textEn: And Israel was made to be the manifest portion of God.
verses.textLa: et pars Dei, Israel facta est manifesta.

verses.textEn: And in the sight of God, all their works are like the sun. And his eyes, without ceasing, inspect their ways.
verses.textLa: Et omnia opera illorum velut sol in conspectu Dei: et oculi eius sine intermissione inspicientes in viis eorum.

verses.textEn: The covenants are not hidden by their iniquity, and all their iniquities are in the sight of God.
verses.textLa: Non sunt absconsa testamenta per iniquitatem illorum, et omnes iniquitates eorum in conspectu Dei.

verses.textEn: The almsgiving of a man is like a seal upon him, which will guard the grace of a man like the pupil of an eye.
verses.textLa: Eleemosyna viri quasi signaculum cum ipso, et gratiam hominis quasi pupillam conservabit:

verses.textEn: And afterward, it will rise up and repay them their reward, each one upon his head, and it will return to the hidden places of the earth.
verses.textLa: et postea resurget, et retribuet illis retributionem, unicuique in caput ipsorum, et convertet in interiores partes terræ.

verses.textEn: Now, to the repentant, he has given the way of justice, and he has strengthened those lacking in patience, and he has fastened them to a destiny of truth.
verses.textLa: Pœnitentibus autem dedit viam iustitiæ, et confirmavit deficientes sustinere, et destinavit illis sortem veritatis.

verses.textEn: Convert to the Lord, and relinquish your sins.
verses.textLa: Convertere ad Dominum, et relinque peccata tua:

verses.textEn: Make supplication before the face of the Lord, and diminish your offenses.
verses.textLa: precare ante faciem Domini, et minue offendicula.

verses.textEn: Return to the Lord, and turn away from your injustice, and have immense hatred for abomination.
verses.textLa: Revertere ad Dominum, et avertere ab iniustitia tua, et nimis odito execrationem:

verses.textEn: And acknowledge the justices and judgments of God, and stand firm in the circumstances set before you and in prayer to the most high God.
verses.textLa: et cognosce iustitias et iudicia Dei, et sta in sorte propositionis, et orationis altissimi Dei.

verses.textEn: Go to the side of the holy generation, to those who live in order to give praise to God.
verses.textLa: In partes vade sæculi sancti, cum vivis et dantibus confessionem Deo.

verses.textEn: You should not linger in the error of the impious; confess before death. Confession perishes from the dead as if it were nothing.
verses.textLa: Non demoreris in errore impiorum, ante mortem confitere. A mortuo quasi nihil, perit confessio.

verses.textEn: Confess while living; you should give thanks while you are still alive and healthy. And you should praise God and glory in his compassion.
verses.textLa: Confiteberis vivens, vivus et sanus confiteberis: et laudabis Deum, et gloriaberis in miserationibus illius.

verses.textEn: How great is the mercy of the Lord, and his forgiveness, for those who convert to him!
verses.textLa: Quam magna misericordia Domini, et propitiatio illius convertentibus ad se!

verses.textEn: For not all things can be in men, because the son of man is not immortal, and because they are pleased by the emptiness of malice.
verses.textLa: Nec enim omnia possunt esse in hominibus, quoniam non est immortalis filius hominis, et in vanitate malitiæ placuerunt.

verses.textEn: What is brighter than the sun? Yet this will fail. Or what is more wicked than that which flesh and blood has invented? And this will be reproved.
verses.textLa: Quid lucidius sole? Et hic deficiet. Aut quid nequius quam quod excogitavit caro et sanguis? Et hoc arguetur.

verses.textEn: He beholds the power of the heights of heaven. And all men are earth and ashes.
verses.textLa: Virtutem altitudinis cæli ipse conspicit: et omnes homines terra et cinis.

verses.textEn: The One who dwells in eternity created all things together. God alone will be justified, and he remains an invincible King for eternity.
verses.textLa: Qui vivet in æternum, creavit omnia simul. Deus solus iustificabitur, et manet invictus Rex in æternum.

verses.textEn: Who is able to declare his works?
verses.textLa: Quis sufficit enarrare opera illius?

verses.textEn: For who can examine his greatness?
verses.textLa: Quis enim investigabit magnalia eius?

verses.textEn: And who will announce the power of his magnitude? Or who would be able to describe his mercy?
verses.textLa: Virtutem autem magnitudinis eius quis enunciabit? Aut quis adiiciet enarrare misericordiam eius?

verses.textEn: There is no diminishing, and no increasing, and there is no discovering, the greatness of God.
verses.textLa: Non est minuere, neque adiicere, nec est invenire magnalia Dei.

verses.textEn: When man has reached the end, then he will begin. And when he ceases, he will be in need.
verses.textLa: Cum consummaverit homo, tunc incipiet: et cum quieverit, aporiabitur.

verses.textEn: What is man, and what is his grace? And what is his good, or what is his evil?
verses.textLa: Quid est homo, et quæ est gratia illius? Et quid bonum, aut quid nequam illius?

verses.textEn: The number of the days of men are as many as one hundred years. Like a drop of water in the ocean, so they are considered to be. And like a grain of sand on the shore, so do these few years compare to the days of all time.
verses.textLa: Numerus dierum hominum ut multum centum anni: quasi gutta aquæ maris deputati sunt: et sicut calculus arenæ, sic exigui anni in die ævi.

verses.textEn: For this reason, God is patient with them, and he pours forth his mercy upon them.
verses.textLa: Propter hoc patiens est Deus in illis, et effundit super eos misericordiam suam.

verses.textEn: He has seen that the presumption of their heart is evil, and he knows that their rebelliousness is wicked.
verses.textLa: Vidit præsumptionem cordis eorum quoniam mala est, et cognovit subversionem illorum quoniam nequam est.
verses.notes: The word ‘subversionem’ often refers to an overthrow or rebellion, such as when a king is overthrown. But in the context of God and his people, it refers to rebelliousness against God.

verses.textEn: Therefore, he has bestowed his forgiveness on them, and he has revealed to them the way of equity.
verses.textLa: Ideo adimplevit propitiationem suam in illis, et ostendit eis viam æquitatis.

verses.textEn: The compassion of man is toward those closest to him. But the mercy of God is upon all flesh.
verses.textLa: Miseratio hominis circa proximum suum: misericordia autem Dei super omnem carnem.

verses.textEn: He is merciful, and he teaches and corrects, like a shepherd with his flock.
verses.textLa: Qui misericordiam habet, docet, et erudit quasi pastor gregem suum.

verses.textEn: He takes pity on those who accept the doctrine of compassion, and he applies his judgments promptly.
verses.textLa: Miseretur excipientis doctrinam miserationis, et qui festinat in iudiciis eius.

verses.textEn: Son, in your good works, you should not complain, and in giving anything, you should not cause grief with evil words.
verses.textLa: Fili in bonis non des querelam, et in omni dato non des tristitiam verbi mali.

verses.textEn: Is heat not refreshed by the dew? So also is a good word better than a gift.
verses.textLa: Nonne ardorem refrigerabit ros? Sic et verbum melius quam datum.

verses.textEn: Behold, is a word not greater than a gift? But both are with a justified man.
verses.textLa: Nonne ecce verbum super datum bonum? Sed utraque cum homine iustificato.

verses.textEn: The foolish place blame sharply. And a gift from the undisciplined causes the eyes to fail.
verses.textLa: Stultus acriter improperabit: et datus indisciplinati tabescere facit oculos.

verses.textEn: Before you judge, put justice in order within yourself, and before you speak, learn.
verses.textLa: Ante iudicium para iustitiam tibi, et antequam loquaris disce.

verses.textEn: Before you become sick, obtain medicine. And before you judge, examine yourself. And then you will find forgiveness in the sight of God.
verses.textLa: Ante languorem adhibe medicinam, et ante iudicium interroga teipsum, et in conspectu Dei invenies propitiationem.

verses.textEn: Before you become weak, humble yourself; and in a time of infirmity, show your way of life.
verses.textLa: Ante languorem humilia te, et in tempore infirmitatis ostende conversationem tuam.

verses.textEn: Let nothing impede you from praying always. And then you will not dread to be justified, even unto death. For the reward of God dwells in eternity.
verses.textLa: Non impediaris orare semper, et ne verearis usque ad mortem iustificari: quoniam merces Dei manet in æternum.

verses.textEn: Before you pray, prepare your soul. And do not choose to be like a man who tempts God.
verses.textLa: Ante orationem præpara animam tuam: et noli esse quasi homo qui tentat Deum.

verses.textEn: Remember the wrath that will be on the day of consummation, and remember the time of retribution, when he will turn away his face.
verses.textLa: Memento iræ in die consummationis, et tempus retributionis in conversatione faciei.

verses.textEn: Remember poverty in a time of abundance, and remember the deficiency of poverty in a day of riches.
verses.textLa: Memento paupertatis in tempore abundantiæ, et necessitatum paupertatis in die divitiarum.

verses.textEn: From morning until evening, the time will be changed, and all these are swift in the eyes of God.
verses.textLa: A mane usque ad vesperam immutabitur tempus, et hæc omnia citata in oculis Dei.

verses.textEn: A wise man will be cautious in all things, and during a time of many offenses, he will be attentive against inaction.
verses.textLa: Homo sapiens in omnibus metuet, et in diebus delictorum attendet ab inertia.

verses.textEn: Anyone who is astute recognizes wisdom, and he will acknowledge anyone who finds it.
verses.textLa: Omnis astutus agnoscit sapientiam, et invenienti eam dabit confessionem.

verses.textEn: Those who show understanding with words also have acted wisely themselves, and they have understood truth and justice, and they have fulfilled proverbs and judgments.
verses.textLa: Sensati in verbis et ipsi sapienter egerunt: et intellexerunt veritatem et iustitiam, et impleverunt proverbia et iudicia.

verses.textEn: You should not go after your desires; instead, turn away from your own will.
verses.textLa: Post concupiscentias tuas non eas, et a voluntate tua avertere.

verses.textEn: If you offer your desires to your soul, this will cause you to become a joy to your enemies.
verses.textLa: Si præstes animæ tuæ concupiscentias eius, faciat te in gaudium inimicis tuis.

verses.textEn: Take no delight in disorderly gatherings, whether large or small. For their commission of offenses is unceasing.
verses.textLa: Ne oblecteris in turbis nec in modicis: assidua enim est commissio illorum.
verses.notes: The word ‘turbis’ indicates a disorderly large gathering, and the word ‘modicis’ refers to something small; in the context of the previous word ‘turbis’, the word ‘modicis’ refers to a small disorderly gathering.

verses.textEn: You should not be reduced by the contention of borrowing, even if there is nothing in your purse. For you would be contending against your own life.
verses.textLa: Ne fueris mediocris in contentione ex fœnore, et est tibi nihil in sacculo: eris enim invidus vitæ tuæ.

verses.textEn: An inebriated worker will not be wealthy. And whoever despises littleness will fall a little at a time.
verses.textLa: Operarius ebriosus non locupletabitur: et qui spernit modica, paulatim decidet.

verses.textEn: Wine and women cause wise men to fall away, and then they will complain against those who understand.
verses.textLa: Vinum et mulieres apostatare faciunt sapientes, et arguent sensatos:

verses.textEn: And whoever joins himself to fornicators will become wicked. Decay and worms will inherit him, and he will be denounced as the greater example, and his soul will be deducted from the number.
verses.textLa: et qui se iungit fornicariis, erit nequam: putredo et vermes hereditabunt illum, et extolletur in exemplum maius, et tolletur de numero anima eius.

verses.textEn: Whoever is quick to believe has a trivial heart and will be diminished. And whoever offends against his own soul will have even less.
verses.textLa: Qui credit cito, levis corde est, et minorabitur: et qui delinquit in animam suam, insuper habebitur.
verses.notes: Or: ‘will be diminished even more.’

verses.textEn: Whoever rejoices in iniquity will be condemned. And whoever hates correction will have less in life. But whoever hates excessive talk extinguishes evil.
verses.textLa: Qui gaudet iniquitate, denotabitur: et qui odit correptionem, minuetur vita: et qui odit loquacitatem, extinguit malitiam.

verses.textEn: Whoever sins against his own soul will be punished. And whoever rejoices in malice will be condemned.
verses.textLa: Qui peccat in animam suam, pœnitebit: et qui iucundatur in malitia, denotabitur.

verses.textEn: You should not repeat a wicked and harsh word, and then you will not be diminished.
verses.textLa: Ne iteres verbum nequam et durum, et non minoraberis.

verses.textEn: Do not reveal your mind to friend or foe. And if there is a sin within you, do not disclose it.
verses.textLa: Amico et inimico noli narrare sensum tuum: et si est tibi delictum, noli denudare.

verses.textEn: For he will listen to you and watch you, and while pretending to defend your sin, he will despise you, and so he will be whenever he is with you.
verses.textLa: Audiet enim te, et custodiet te, et quasi defendens peccatum odiet te, et sic aderit tibi semper.

verses.textEn: Have you heard a word against your neighbor? Let it die within you, trusting that it will not burst forth from you.
verses.textLa: Audisti verbum adversus proximum tuum? Commoriatur in te, fidens quoniam non te dirumpet.

verses.textEn: Before the face of a word, a foolish man labors, like a woman groaning as she gives birth to a child.
verses.textLa: A facie verbi parturit fatuus, tamquam gemitus partus infantis.

verses.textEn: Like an arrow fixed in the flesh of the thigh, so is a word in the heart of a foolish man.
verses.textLa: Sagitta infixa femori carnis, sic verbum in corde stulti.

verses.textEn: Correct a friend, though perhaps there was a misunderstanding, and he may say, “I did not do it.” Or, if he did do it, correct him, so that he may not do it again.
verses.textLa: Corripe amicum, ne forte non intellexerit, et dicat: Non feci: aut si fecerit, ne iterum addat facere.

verses.textEn: Correct your neighbor, for perhaps he did not say it. But if he did say it, correct him, so that he may not say it again.
verses.textLa: Corripe proximum, ne forte non dixerit: et si dixerit, ne forte iteret.

verses.textEn: Correct your friend. For often a fault has been committed.
verses.textLa: Corripe amicum: sæpe enim fit commissio.

verses.textEn: And do not believe every word. There is one who slips with his word, but not with his heart.
verses.textLa: Et non omni verbo credas. Est qui labitur lingua, sed non ex animo.

verses.textEn: For who is there who has not offended with his words? Correct your neighbor before you reprimand him.
verses.textLa: Quis est enim qui non deliquerit in lingua sua? Corripe proximum antequam commineris.

verses.textEn: And make a place for the fear of the Most High. For all wisdom is fear of God, and it is wise to fear God, and in all wisdom is the orderly disposition of the law.
verses.textLa: Et da locum timori Altissimi: quia omnis sapientia timor Dei, et in illa timere Deum, et in omni sapientia dispositio legis.

verses.textEn: But the discipline of wickedness is not wisdom. And there is no prudence in the thoughts of sinners.
verses.textLa: Et non est sapientia nequitiæ disciplina: et non est cogitatus peccatorum prudentia.

verses.textEn: There is a wickedness, and in it there is abomination. And there is a foolish man who has been diminished in wisdom.
verses.textLa: Est nequitia, et in ipsa execratio: et est insipiens qui minuitur sapientia.

verses.textEn: Better is a man who has been diminished in wisdom because his mind is failing, but with the fear of God, than he who abounds in intelligence, but with transgression against the law of the Most High.
verses.textLa: Melior est homo, qui minuitur sapientia, et deficiens sensu in timore, quam qui abundat sensu, et transgreditur legem Altissimi.

verses.textEn: There is a certain cleverness, and it is unjust.
verses.textLa: Est solertia certa, et ipsa iniqua.

verses.textEn: And there is one who utters a careful word, explaining away the truth. There is one who humbles himself wickedly, for his interior is filled with deceit.
verses.textLa: Et est qui emittit verbum certum enarrans veritatem. Est qui nequiter humiliat se, et interiora eius plena sunt dolo:

verses.textEn: And there is one who lowers himself excessively with a great debasement. And there is one who inclines his face downward, and pretends as if he did not see what has not been made known.
verses.textLa: et est qui se nimium submittit a multa humilitate: et est qui inclinat faciem suam, et fingit se non videre quod ignoratum est:

verses.textEn: And if he is prevented from sinning by a lack of ability, and then finds an opportunity for evildoing, he will do evil.
verses.textLa: et si ab imbecillitate virium vetetur peccare, si invenerit tempus malefaciendi, malefaciet.

verses.textEn: A man is recognized by his appearances. But when you meet an understanding man, he is recognized by his face.
verses.textLa: Ex visu cognoscitur vir, et ab occursu faciei cognoscitur sensatus.

verses.textEn: The clothing of the body, and the laughter of the teeth, and the walk of a man, give a report about him.
verses.textLa: Amictus corporis, et risus dentium, et ingressus hominis enunciant de illo.

verses.textEn: There is a lying correction in the anger of a contemptuous man. And there is a judgment which does not prove to be good. But there is one who is silent, and the same is prudent.
verses.textLa: Est correptio mendax in ira contumeliosi: et est iudicium, quod non probatur esse bonum: et est tacens, et ipse est prudens.

verses.textEn: How much better is it to reprove, than to become angry, so as not to hinder him who may confess in prayer.
verses.textLa: Quam bonum est arguere, quam irasci, et confitentem in oratione non prohibere!

verses.textEn: The lust of an eunuch will deflower a young maiden;
verses.textLa: Concupiscentia spadonis devirginabit iuvenculam:

verses.textEn: similar is he who by violence gives an iniquitous judgment.
verses.textLa: sic qui facit per vim iudicium iniquum.

verses.textEn: How good it is, when you are corrected, to show contrition! For in this way, you will escape deliberate sin.
verses.textLa: Quam bonum est correptum manifestare pœnitentiam! Sic enim effugies voluntarium peccatum.

verses.textEn: There is one who, by remaining silent, is found to be wise. And there is another who is hateful and who provokes by speaking out.
verses.textLa: Est tacens, qui invenitur sapiens: et est odibilis, qui procax est ad loquendum.

verses.textEn: There is one who, not having the understanding to speak, remains silent. And there is another who remains silent, knowing the proper time.
verses.textLa: Est tacens non habens sensum loquelæ: et est tacens sciens tempus aptum.

verses.textEn: A wise man will remain silent until the proper time. But an unrestrained and imprudent person will not heed the times.
verses.textLa: Homo sapiens tacebit usque ad tempus: lascivus autem, et imprudens non servabunt tempus.

verses.textEn: Whoever uses many words will wound his own soul. And whoever unjustly takes authority upon himself will be hated.
verses.textLa: Qui multis utitur verbis, lædet animam suam: et qui potestatem sibi sumit iniuste, odietur.

verses.textEn: There is advancement in evil for an undisciplined man, and there is a plan which turns to his detriment.
verses.textLa: Est processio in malis viro indisciplinato, et est inventio in detrimentum.

verses.textEn: There is a gift which is not helpful, and there is a gift, the repayment for which is double.
verses.textLa: Est datum, quod non est utile: et est datum, cuius retributio duplex.

verses.textEn: There is a loss for the sake of boasting, and there is one who will lift up his head from lowliness.
verses.textLa: Est propter gloriam minoratio: et est qui ab humilitate levabit caput.

verses.textEn: There is one who buys much for a small price, and who pays it back sevenfold.
verses.textLa: Est qui multa redimat modico pretio, et restituens ea in septuplum.

verses.textEn: Anyone wise in words makes himself loved. But the graces of the foolish will be poured away.
verses.textLa: Sapiens in verbis seipsum amabilem facit: gratiæ autem fatuorum effundentur.

verses.textEn: A gift from the unwise will not benefit you. For his gaze is divided, sevenfold.
verses.textLa: Datus insipientis non erit utilis tibi: oculi enim illius septemplices sunt.

verses.textEn: He will give little, and reproach much. And the opening of his mouth is like a burning flame.
verses.textLa: Exigua dabit, et multa improperabit: et apertio oris illius inflammatio est.

verses.textEn: There is one who lends today and demands repayment tomorrow. A man such as this is hateful.
verses.textLa: Hodie fœneratur quis, et cras expetit: odibilis est homo huiusmodi.

verses.textEn: A foolish man will not have a friend, and there will be no thanks for his good deeds.
verses.textLa: Fatuo non erit amicus, et non erit gratia bonis illius.

verses.textEn: For those who eat his bread have a false tongue. How often and how many are those who will ridicule him!
verses.textLa: Qui enim edunt panem illius: falsæ linguæ sunt. Quoties, et quanti irridebunt eum!

verses.textEn: For what he possesses, he does not distribute with correct understanding. And he acts similarly with what he does not possess.
verses.textLa: Neque enim quod habendum erat, directo sensu distribuit: similiter et quod non erat habendum.

verses.textEn: The slip of a false tongue is like someone who falls upon pavement. Such a fall for the wicked will arrive quickly.
verses.textLa: Lapsus falsæ linguæ, quasi qui in pavimento cadens: sic casus malorum festinanter veniet.

verses.textEn: A disagreeable man is like a pointless fable; it will be continually in the mouth of the undisciplined.
verses.textLa: Homo acharis quasi fabula vana, in ore indisciplinatorum assidua erit.

verses.textEn: A parable from the mouth of a fool will be rejected. For he does not speak it at the proper time.
verses.textLa: Ex ore fatui reprobabitur parabola: non enim dicit illam in tempore suo.

verses.textEn: There is one who is prevented from sinning by poverty, and in his rest, he will be vexed.
verses.textLa: Est qui vetatur peccare præ inopia, et in requie sua stimulabitur.

verses.textEn: There is one who will lose his own soul because of pretense, and he will lose it by an example of imprudence. For by seeking the approval of another, he will destroy himself.
verses.textLa: Est qui perdet animam suam præ confusione, et ab imprudenti persona perdet eam: personæ autem acceptione perdet se.
verses.notes: This verse refers to someone who follows the imprudent example of another, in order to please that person (because that person has an undeserved reputation); this individual destroys his own soul by seeking to please someone other than God.

verses.textEn: There is one who, for the sake of what others think, makes a promise to a friend, and so he gains him as an enemy for no reason.
verses.textLa: Est qui præ confusione promittit amico, et lucratus est eum inimicum gratis.

verses.textEn: A lie is a wicked disgrace to a man, and yet lies will be continually in the mouths of those without discipline.
verses.textLa: Opprobrium nequam in homine mendacium, et in ore indisciplinatorum assidue erit.

verses.textEn: A thief is better than a man who constantly lies. But both of them will inherit perdition.
verses.textLa: Potior fur quam assiduitas viri mendacis. Perditionem autem ambo hereditabunt.

verses.textEn: The habits of lying men are without honor. And their shame is with them without ceasing.
verses.textLa: Mores hominum mendacium sine honore: et confusio illorum cum ipsis sine intermissione.

verses.textEn: A wise man will benefit himself by his own words, and a prudent man will please the powerful.
verses.textLa: Sapiens in verbis producet seipsum, et homo prudens placebit magnatis.

verses.textEn: Whoever works his land will raise high a stockpile of grain. And whoever works justice will himself be raised high. Yet truly, whoever pleases the powerful will escape unfair treatment.
verses.textLa: Qui operatur terram suam, inaltabit acervum frugum: et qui operatur iustitiam, ipse exaltabitur: qui vero placet magnatis, effugiet iniquitatem.

verses.textEn: Presents and gifts blind the eyes of judges, and silence their mouths, turning them aside from their task of correction.
verses.textLa: Xenia et dona excæcant oculos iudicum, et quasi mutus in ore avertit correptiones eorum.

verses.textEn: Wisdom hidden, and treasure unseen: of what use is either of these?
verses.textLa: Sapientia absconsa et thesaurus invisus: quæ utilitas in utrisque?

verses.textEn: He who hides his foolishness is better than a man who conceals his wisdom.
verses.textLa: Melior est qui celat insipientiam suam, quam homo qui abscondit sapientiam suam.

verses.textEn: Son, have you sinned? You should not add further sins. Then too, for your former sins, pray so that they may be forgiven you.
verses.textLa: Fili peccasti? Non adiicias iterum: sed et de pristinis deprecare ut tibi dimittantur.

verses.textEn: Flee from sins, as if from the face of a serpent. For if you approach them, they will take hold of you.
verses.textLa: Quasi a facie colubri fuge peccata: et si accesseris ad illa, suscipient te.

verses.textEn: Their teeth are like the teeth of a lion, bringing death to the souls of men.
verses.textLa: Dentes leonis, dentes eius, interficientes animas hominum.

verses.textEn: All iniquity is like a two-edged spear; there is no healing in its wound.
verses.textLa: Quasi romphæa bis acuta omnis iniquitas, plagæ illius non est sanitas.

verses.textEn: Reproach and injury will make resources useless. And a house that is exceedingly wealthy will become powerless through pride. In this way, the resources of the arrogant will be eradicated.
verses.textLa: Obiurgatio et iniuriæ annullabunt substantiam: et domus quæ nimis locuples est, annullabitur superbia: sic substantia superbi eradicabitur.

verses.textEn: Supplications from the mouth of the pauper will reach all the way to the ears of God, and judgment will come to him quickly.
verses.textLa: Deprecatio pauperis ex ore usque ad aures eius perveniet, et iudicium festinato adveniet illi.

verses.textEn: Whoever hates correction is walking in the steps of a sinner. But whoever fears God will convert within his heart.
verses.textLa: Qui odit correptionem, vestigium est peccatoris: et qui timet Deum, convertetur ad cor suum.

verses.textEn: He who has power by means of a bold tongue will be known from far away. But an understanding man knows to slip past him.
verses.textLa: Notus a longe potens lingua audaci: et sensatus scit labi se ab ipso.

verses.textEn: Whoever builds his house, paid for by another, is like one who gathers his building stones in winter.
verses.textLa: Qui ædificat domum suam impendiis alienis, quasi qui colligat lapides suos in hyeme.

verses.textEn: The synagogue of sinners is like stubble piled up; for the end of them both is a burning fire.
verses.textLa: Stupa collecta synagoga peccantium, et consummatio illorum flamma ignis.

verses.textEn: The way of sinners is paved and level, and at their end is hell and darkness and punishments.
verses.textLa: Via peccatorum complanata lapidibus, et in fine illorum inferi, et tenebræ, et pœnæ.

verses.textEn: Whoever observes justice will obtain an understanding of it.
verses.textLa: Qui custodit iustitiam, continebit sensum eius.

verses.textEn: The consummation of the fear of God is wisdom and understanding.
verses.textLa: Consummatio timoris Dei, sapientia et sensus.

verses.textEn: One who is not wise in goodness will not accept instruction.
verses.textLa: Non erudietur qui non est sapiens in bono.

verses.textEn: Now there is a wisdom which abounds in evil. But there is no understanding where there is bitterness.
verses.textLa: Est autem sapientia, quæ abundat in malo: et non est sensus ubi est amaritudo.

verses.textEn: The knowledge of the wise will increase like a flood, and his counsel will continue like a fountain of life.
verses.textLa: Scientia sapientis tamquam inundatio abundabit, et consilium illius sicut fons vitæ permanet.

verses.textEn: The heart of the foolish is like a broken vessel, for it will not hold any wisdom.
verses.textLa: Cor fatui quasi vas confractum, et omnem sapientiam non tenebit.

verses.textEn: A knowledgeable man will praise any wise word he hears, and he will apply it to himself. The self-indulgent man has heard it, and it displeases him, and so he casts it behind his back.
verses.textLa: Verbum sapiens quodcumque audierit scius laudabit, et ad se adiiciet: audivit luxuriosus, et displicebit illi, et proiiciet illud post dorsum suum.

verses.textEn: The talk of the foolish is like a burden on a journey. But in the lips of the understanding, grace will be found.
verses.textLa: Narratio fatui quasi sarcina in via. Nam in labiis sensati invenietur gratia.

verses.textEn: The mouth of the prudent is sought in the Church, and they will consider his words in their hearts.
verses.textLa: Os prudentis quæritur in Ecclesia, et verba illius cogitabunt in cordibus suis.

verses.textEn: Like a house which has been demolished, so is wisdom to the foolish. And the knowledge of the unwise is like meaningless words.
verses.textLa: Tamquam domus exterminata, sic fatuo sapientia: et scientia insensati inenarrabilia verba.

verses.textEn: Doctrine to the senseless is like fetters on the feet, and like chains on the right hand.
verses.textLa: Compedes in pedibus, stulto doctrina, et quasi vincula manuum super manum dextram.

verses.textEn: A foolish man lifts up his voice in laughter. But a wise man will not even laugh quietly to himself.
verses.textLa: Fatuus in risu exaltat vocem suam: vir autem sapiens vix tacite ridebit.

verses.textEn: Doctrine is to the prudent like a gold ornament, and like an armband on the right arm.
verses.textLa: Ornamentum aureum prudenti doctrina, et quasi brachiale in brachio dextro.

verses.textEn: The feet of the foolish step easily into his neighbor’s house. But an experienced man will be apprehensive in the presence of the powerful.
verses.textLa: Pes fatui facilis in domum proximi: et homo peritus confundetur a persona potentis.

verses.textEn: A senseless man will gaze through a window into the house. But a man who has been well-taught will stand outside.
verses.textLa: Stultus a fenestra respiciet in domum: vir autem eruditus foris stabit.

verses.textEn: It is foolish for a man to listen through the door. And a prudent man will be grieved at this disgrace.
verses.textLa: Stultitia hominis auscultare per ostium: et prudens gravabitur contumelia.

verses.textEn: The lips of the imprudent will describe senseless things. But the words of the prudent will be weighed on a balance.
verses.textLa: Labia imprudentium stulta narrabunt: verba autem prudentium statera ponderabuntur.

verses.textEn: The hearts of the foolish are in their mouths. But the mouths of the wise are with their hearts.
verses.textLa: In ore fatuorum cor illorum: et in corde sapientium os illorum.

verses.textEn: Whenever the impious curse the devil, they curse their own soul.
verses.textLa: Dum maledicit impius diabolum, maledicit ipse animam suam.

verses.textEn: Those who whisper accusations defile their own souls, and they will be hated by all. And whoever abides with them will be hateful. The silent and understanding man will be honored.
verses.textLa: Susurro coinquinabit animam suam, et in omnibus odietur: et qui cum eo manserit, odiosus erit: tacitus et sensatus honorabitur.

verses.textEn: The lazy man is pelted with a dirty stone, and all will speak about his rejection.
verses.textLa: In lapide luteo lapidatus est piger, et omnes loquentur super aspernationem illius.

verses.textEn: The lazy man is pelted with the dung of oxen, and all who touch him will brush off their hands.
verses.textLa: De stercore boum lapidatus est piger: et omnis, qui tetigerit eum, excutiet manus.

verses.textEn: An undisciplined son is the shame of his father, but an undisciplined daughter will be to his degradation.
verses.textLa: Confusio patris est de filio indisciplinato: filia autem in deminoratione fiet.
verses.notes: The two halves of this verse are parallel; the term undisciplined is stated in the first part and implied in the second part.

verses.textEn: A prudent daughter brings an inheritance to her husband. But she who causes shame will be a disgrace to him who conceived her.
verses.textLa: Filia prudens hereditas viro suo. Nam quæ confundit, in contumeliam fit genitoris.

verses.textEn: She who is bold shames her father and her husband, and she will not be less offensive to the impious. For she will be held in dishonor by both.
verses.textLa: Patrem et virum confundit audax, et ab impiis non minorabitur: ab utrisque autem inhonorabitur.

verses.textEn: An untimely explanation is like music in a time of mourning. But the sharp correction and doctrine of wisdom are ever timely.
verses.textLa: Musica in luctu importuna narratio: flagella et doctrina in omni tempore sapientia.

verses.textEn: Whoever teaches the foolish is like someone who glues together a broken pot.
verses.textLa: Qui docet fatuum, quasi qui conglutinat testam.
verses.notes: There were no effective glues, and no water-proof glues, in the time in which this verse was written. So gluing a pot together was futile.

verses.textEn: Whoever explains a word to one who is not listening is like someone who suddenly awakens a sleeping person from a deep sleep.
verses.textLa: Qui narrat verbum non audienti, quasi qui excitat dormientem de gravi somno.

verses.textEn: Whoever explains wisdom to the senseless is like one speaking to a sleeping person. And at the end of the explanation, he says: “Who is this?”
verses.textLa: Cum dormiente loquitur qui enarrat stulto sapientiam: et in fine narrationis dicit: Quis est hic?

verses.textEn: Weep over the dead, for his light has failed. And weep over the foolish, for his understanding has failed.
verses.textLa: Supra mortuum plora, defecit enim lux eius: et supra fatuum plora, defecit enim sensus.

verses.textEn: Weep only a little over the dead, for he is at rest.
verses.textLa: Modicum plora super mortuum, quoniam requievit.

verses.textEn: But the wicked life of a wicked fool is worse than death.
verses.textLa: Nequissimi enim nequissima vita super mortem fatui.

verses.textEn: The mourning for the dead is seven days; but for the foolish and the impious, it is all the days of their life.
verses.textLa: Luctus mortui septem dies: fatui autem et impii omnes dies vitæ illorum.

verses.textEn: You should not talk at length with the foolish, and you should not go with the senseless.
verses.textLa: Cum stulto ne multum loquaris, et cum insensato ne abieris.

verses.textEn: Keep yourself from him, so that you may not have problems, and so that you will not be polluted by his sin.
verses.textLa: Serva te ab illo, ut non molestiam habeas, et non coinquinaberis peccato illius.

verses.textEn: Turn away from him, and you will find rest, and you will not be discouraged by his foolishness.
verses.textLa: Deflecte ab illo, et invenies requiem, et non acediaberis in stultitia illius.

verses.textEn: What is heavier than lead? And what else can he be called but foolish?
verses.textLa: Super plumbum quid gravabitur? Et quod illi aliud nomen quam fatuus?

verses.textEn: Sand, and salt, and an iron weight are each easier to bear than an imprudent man, who is both foolish and impious.
verses.textLa: Arenam, et salem, et massam ferri facilius est ferre quam hominem imprudentem, et fatuum, et impium.

verses.textEn: A bundle of wood strapped together in the foundation of a building will not be loosened. And similar is the heart that has been strengthened by thoughtful counsel.
verses.textLa: Loramentum ligneum colligatum in fundamento ædificii non dissolvetur: sic et cor confirmatum in cogitatione consilii.

verses.textEn: The thoughts of one who is understanding will not be corrupted by fear in any situation.
verses.textLa: Cogitatus sensati in omni tempore, metu non depravabitur.

verses.textEn: Just as chaff in a high place, or a wall made of mortar without stones set within, will not continue against the face of the wind,
verses.textLa: Sicut pali in excelsis, et cæmenta sine impensa posita contra faciem venti non permanebunt:
verses.notes: The word ‘pali’ refers to chaff, not to a pole or a fence; for some reason the Latin puts the word in the second declension (masculine), rather than in the first declension (feminine). The phrase ‘cæmenta sine impensa posita’ refers to a wall, which would usually be made of stones and mortar, but which is made ‘sine impensa posita’ without (sine) heavy or weighed things (impensa), i.e. stones, set within it (posita).

verses.textEn: so also a timid heart, and the thoughts of the senseless, will not withstand the forcefulness of fear.
verses.textLa: sic et cor timidum in cogitatione stulti contra impetum timoris non resistet.

verses.textEn: Despite a cowardly heart, the thoughts of the foolish will not fear any situation; yet neither will one who continues always in the precepts of God.
verses.textLa: Sicut cor trepidum in cogitatione fatui, omni tempore non metuet, sic et qui in præceptis Dei permanet semper.
verses.notes: The foolish man does not think that his nervous heart will dread any situation; he reaches this incorrect conclusion because of his foolishness. But those who keep the precepts of God truly do not need to dread any situation.

verses.textEn: He who jabs an eye produces tears. And he who jabs the heart produces understanding.
verses.textLa: Pungens oculum deducit lacrymas: et qui pungit cor, profert sensum.

verses.textEn: He who throws a stone at birds will drive them away. So also, he who accuses his friend dissolves the friendship.
verses.textLa: Mittens lapidem in volatilia, deiiciet illa: sic et qui conviciatur amico, dissolvit amicitiam.

verses.textEn: But if you have drawn a sword against a friend, you should not despair; for there may be a way back.
verses.textLa: Ad amicum et si produxeris gladium, non desperes: est enim regressus.

verses.textEn: If you have opened a harsh mouth against a friend, you should not fear; for there may be a reconciliation. However, if there are accusations, or abuse, or arrogance, or the revealing of secrets, or a wound from deceitfulness, in all these cases, a friend will flee away.
verses.textLa: Ad amicum si aperueris os triste, non timeas: est enim concordatio: excepto convitio, et improperio, et superbia, et mysterii revelatione, et plaga dolosa: in his omnibus effugiet amicus.

verses.textEn: Hold to faithfulness with a friend in his poverty, so that you may also rejoice in his prosperity.
verses.textLa: Fidem posside cum amico in paupertate illius, ut et in bonis illius læteris.

verses.textEn: In the time of his tribulation, remain faithful to him, so that you may also be an heir with him in his inheritance.
verses.textLa: In tempore tribulationis illius permane illi fidelis, ut et in hereditate illius coheres sis.

verses.textEn: Just as the steam from an oven, or the smoke from a fire, rises up before a flame, so also do curses and insults and threats rise up before bloodshed.
verses.textLa: Ante ignem camini vapor, et fumus ignis inaltatur: sic et ante sanguinem maledicta, et contumeliæ, et minæ.

verses.textEn: I shall not be ashamed to greet a friend, nor shall I hide myself from his face. And if misfortunes befall me because of him, I will endure.
verses.textLa: Amicum salutare non confundar, a facie illius non me abscondam: et si mala mihi evenerint per illum, sustinebo.

verses.textEn: Anyone who hears of this will be wary around him.
verses.textLa: Omnis qui audiet, cavebit se ab eo.

verses.textEn: Who will provide a keeper for my mouth, and a reliable seal over my lips, so that I may not fall because of them, and so that my tongue does not destroy me?
verses.textLa: Quis dabit ori meo custodiam, et super labia mea signaculum certum, ut non cadam ab ipsis, et lingua mea perdat me?

verses.textEn: Lord, Father and Ruler of my life: may you not abandon me to their counsel, nor permit me to fall by them.
verses.textLa: Domine Pater, et Dominator vitæ meæ ne derelinquas me in consilio eorum: nec sinas me cadere in illis.

verses.textEn: They would impose scourges over my thoughts and over the discipline of wisdom in my heart. And they would not spare me from their ignorances, nor would they allow their own offenses to become apparent.
verses.textLa: Quis superponet in cogitatu meo flagella, et in corde meo doctrinam sapientiæ, ut ignorationibus eorum non parcant mihi, et non appareant delicta eorum,

verses.textEn: And they intend that my ignorances would increase, and my offenses be multiplied, and my sins abound. And so I would fall in the sight of my adversaries, and be rejoiced over by my enemy.
verses.textLa: et ne adincrescant ignorantiæ meæ, et multiplicentur delicta mea, et peccata mea abundent, et incidam in conspectu adversariorum meorum, et gaudeat super me inimicus meus?

verses.textEn: Lord, Father and God of my life: may you not abandon me to their plans.
verses.textLa: Domine pater, et Deus vitæ meæ, ne derelinquas me in cogitatu illorum.

verses.textEn: Do not leave me with the haughtiness of my eyes. And avert all desire from me.
verses.textLa: Extollentiam oculorum meorum ne dederis mihi, et omne desiderium averte a me.

verses.textEn: Take the desire of the body from me, and do not allow sexual desire to take hold of me, and do not permit an irreverent and senseless mind within me.
verses.textLa: Aufer a me ventris concupiscentias, et concubitus concupiscentiæ ne apprehendant me, et animæ irreverenti et infrunitæ ne tradas me.

verses.textEn: O sons: listen to the doctrine of my mouth. For those who observe it will not perish by the lips, nor be scandalized into wicked works.
