verses.textLa: Doctrinam oris audite filii: et qui custodierit illam, non periet labiis, nec scandalizabitur in operibus nequissimis.

verses.textEn: A sinner is held by his own emptiness. And the arrogant and those who speak evil will be scandalized by these things.
verses.textLa: In vanitate sua apprehenditur peccator, et superbus et maledicus scandalizabitur in illis.

verses.textEn: Do not allow your mouth to become accustomed to swearing oaths. For in this, there are many pitfalls.
verses.textLa: Iurationi non assuescat os tuum, multi enim casus in illa.

verses.textEn: Truly, do not allow the naming of God to be continually in your mouth, and do not treat as if common the names of the holy ones. For you will not escape punishment by them.
verses.textLa: Nominatio vero Dei non sit assidua in ore tuo, et nominibus sanctorum non admiscearis: quoniam non erit immunis ab eis.

verses.textEn: Just as a servant, continually interrogated, will not be without a bruise, so everyone who swears oaths and takes God’s name will not be entirely free from sin.
verses.textLa: Sicut enim servus interrogatus assidue, a livore non minuitur: sic omnis iurans, et nominans, in toto a peccato non purgabitur.

verses.textEn: A man who swears many oaths will be filled with iniquity, and scourges will not depart from his house.
verses.textLa: Vir multum iurans implebitur iniquitate, et non discedet a domo illius plaga.

verses.textEn: And if he fails to fulfill it, his offense will be over him, and if he pretends he fulfilled it, he offends doubly.
verses.textLa: Et si frustraverit, delictum illius super ipsum erit: et si dissimulaverit, delinquit dupliciter:

verses.textEn: And if he swears an oath insincerely, he will not be justified. For his house will be filled with retribution for him.
verses.textLa: et si in vacuum iuraverit, non iustificabitur: replebitur enim retributione domus illius.

verses.textEn: There is yet another kind of talk which faces death; let it not be found in the inheritance of Jacob.
verses.textLa: Est et alia loquela contraria morti, non inveniatur in hereditate Iacob.

verses.textEn: For all these things will be taken away from the merciful, and they shall not wallow in offenses.
verses.textLa: Etenim a misericordibus omnia hæc auferentur, et in delictis non volutabuntur.

verses.textEn: Do not allow your mouth to become accustomed to undisciplined speech. For in this, there is the sin of words.
verses.textLa: Indisciplinatæ loquelæ non assuescat os tuum: est enim in illa verbum peccati.

verses.textEn: When you sit in the midst of great men, remember your father and mother.
verses.textLa: Memento patris et matris tuæ, in medio enim magnatorum consistis:

verses.textEn: Otherwise, God may forget you, when you are in their sight, and then you would be repeatedly ridiculed and would suffer disgrace, and you might wish that you had never been born, and you might curse the day of your nativity.
verses.textLa: ne forte obliviscatur te Deus in conspectu illorum, et assiduitate tua infatuatus, improperium patiaris, et maluisses non nasci, et diem nativitatis tuæ maledicas.

verses.textEn: The man who is accustomed to disgraceful words will not accept instruction, all the days of his life.
verses.textLa: Homo assuetus in verbis improperii, in omnibus diebus suis non erudietur.

verses.textEn: Two kinds of persons abound in sins, and a third adds wrath and perdition.
verses.textLa: Duo genera abundant in peccatis, et tertium adducit iram, et perditionem.

verses.textEn: A desirous soul is like a burning fire, it will not be quenched, until it devours something.
verses.textLa: Anima calida quasi ignis ardens non extinguetur donec aliquid glutiat:

verses.textEn: And a man who is wicked in the desires of his flesh will not desist until he has kindled a fire.
verses.textLa: et homo nequam in ore carnis suæ non desinet donec incendat ignem.

verses.textEn: To a man of fornication, all bread is sweet; he will not tire of transgression, to the very end.
verses.textLa: Homini fornicario omnis panis dulcis, non fatigabitur transgrediens usque ad finem.

verses.textEn: Every man who transgresses his own bed has contempt for his own soul. And so he says: “Who can see me?
verses.textLa: Omnis homo qui transgreditur lectum suum, contemnens in animam suam, et dicens: Quis me videt?

verses.textEn: Darkness surrounds me, and the walls enclose me, and no one catches sight of me. Whom should I fear? The Most High will not remember my offenses.”
verses.textLa: Tenebræ circumdant me, et parietes cooperiunt me, et nemo circumspicit me: quem vereor? Delictorum meorum non memorabitur Altissimus.

verses.textEn: And he does not understand that God’s eye sees all things. For fear within a man such as this drives away from him both the fear of God and the eyes of those men who fear God.
verses.textLa: Et non intelligit quoniam omnia videt oculus illius, quoniam expellit a se timorem Dei huiusmodi hominis timor, et oculi hominum timentes illum:

verses.textEn: And he does not acknowledge that the eyes of the Lord are much brighter than the sun, keeping watch over all the ways of men, even to the depths of the abyss, and gazing into the hearts of men, even to the most hidden parts.
verses.textLa: et non cognovit quoniam oculi Domini multo plus lucidiores sunt super solem, circumspicientes omnes vias hominum, et profundum abyssi, et hominum corda intuentes in absconditas partes.

verses.textEn: For all things, before they were created, were known to the Lord God. And even after their completion, he beholds all things.
verses.textLa: Domino enim Deo antequam crearentur, omnia sunt agnita: sic et post perfectum respicit omnia.

verses.textEn: This man will be punished in the streets of the city, and he will be chased like a young horse. And in a place that he does not suspect, he will be captured.
verses.textLa: Hic in plateis civitatis vindicabitur, et quasi pullus equinus fugabitur: et ubi non speravit, apprehendetur.

verses.textEn: And because he did not understand the fear of the Lord, he will be in disgrace before all men,
verses.textLa: Et erit dedecus omnibus, eo quod non intellexerit timorem Domini.

verses.textEn: as will be every woman, too, who abandons her husband and establishes an inheritance by marriage to another man.
verses.textLa: Sic et mulier omnis relinquens virum suum, et statuens hereditatem ex alieno matrimonio:

verses.textEn: For first, she was unbelieving of the law of the Most High. Second, she offended against her husband. Third, she fornicated by adultery, and so established her children by another man.
verses.textLa: primo enim in lege Altissimi incredibilis fuit: secundo in virum suum deliquit: tertio in adulterio fornicata est, et ex alio viro filios statuit sibi.

verses.textEn: This woman will be led into the assembly, and she will be stared at by her children.
verses.textLa: Hæc in ecclesiam adducetur, et in filios eius respicietur.

verses.textEn: Her children will not take root, and her branches will not produce fruit.
verses.textLa: Non tradent filii eius radices, et rami eius non dabunt fructum.

verses.textEn: She will leave behind her memory as a curse, and her infamy will not be wiped away.
verses.textLa: Derelinquet in maledictum memoriam eius, et dedecus illius non delebitur.

verses.textEn: And those who are left behind will acknowledge that there is nothing better than the fear of God, and that there is nothing sweeter than to have respect for the commandments of the Lord.
verses.textLa: Et agnoscent qui derelicti sunt, quoniam nihil melius est quam timor Dei: et nihil dulcius, quam respicere in mandatis Domini.

verses.textEn: It is a great glory to follow the Lord. For length of days will be received from him.
verses.textLa: Gloria magna est sequi Dominum: longitudo enim dierum assumetur ab eo.

verses.textEn: Wisdom will praise her own mind, and she will be honored by God, and she will be glorified in the midst of her people.
verses.textLa: Sapientia laudabit animam suam, et in Deo honorabitur, et in medio populi sui gloriabitur,

verses.textEn: And she will open her mouth in the churches of the Most High, and she will be glorified in the sight of his virtue.
verses.textLa: et in ecclesiis Altissimi aperiet os suum, et in conspectu virtutis illius gloriabitur,

verses.textEn: And in the midst of her own people, she will be exalted. And she will be admired by the holy assembly.
verses.textLa: et in medio populi sui exaltabitur, et in plenitudine sancta admirabitur,

verses.textEn: And she will have praise within the multitude of the elect. And she will be blessed among the blessed. And she will say:
verses.textLa: et in multitudine electorum habebit laudem, et inter benedictos benedicetur, dicens:

verses.textEn: “I went forth from the mouth of the Most High, as the first-born before all creatures.
verses.textLa: Ego ex ore Altissimi prodivi primogenita ante omnem creaturam:

verses.textEn: I caused an unfailing light to arise in the heavens. And I covered all the earth like a cloud.
verses.textLa: Ego feci in cælis ut oriretur lumen indeficiens, et sicut nebula texi omnem terram:

verses.textEn: I lived in the highest places, and my throne is in the pillar of a cloud.
verses.textLa: Ego in altissimis habitavi, et thronus meus in columna nubis.

verses.textEn: I alone have encompassed the circuit of heaven, and have penetrated to the depths of the abyss, and have walked upon the waves of the sea,
verses.textLa: Gyrum cæli circuivi sola, et profundum abyssi penetravi, in fluctibus maris ambulavi,

verses.textEn: and have stood upon the whole earth. And among every people,
verses.textLa: et in omni terra steti: et in omni populo,

verses.textEn: and in every nation, I have held primacy.
verses.textLa: et in omni gente primatum habui:

verses.textEn: And by virtue, I have tread upon the hearts of all, the great and the lowly. And I have sought my rest in all of them. And I will continue, as the inheritance of the Lord.
verses.textLa: et omnium excellentium et humilium corda virtute calcavi: et in his omnibus requiem quæsivi, et in hereditate Domini morabor.

verses.textEn: Then the Creator of all things instructed and spoke with me. And the One who created me rested in my tabernacle.
verses.textLa: Tunc præcepit, et dixit mihi Creator omnium: et qui creavit me, requievit in tabernaculo meo,

verses.textEn: And he said to me: ‘Let your dwelling place be with Jacob, and let your inheritance be in Israel, for you shall take root among my elect.’
verses.textLa: et dixit mihi: In Iacob inhabita, et in Israel hereditare, et in electis meis mitte radices.

verses.textEn: From the beginning, and before the world, I was created. And even unto the future world, I will not cease to exist. For I have ministered before him in the holy habitation.
verses.textLa: Ab initio, et ante sæcula creata sum, et usque ad futurum sæculum non desinam, et in habitatione sancta coram ipso ministravi.

verses.textEn: And in this way, I was established in Zion. And likewise, in the holy city, I found rest. And my authority was in Jerusalem.
verses.textLa: Et sic in Sion firmata sum, et in civitate sanctificata similiter requievi, et in Ierusalem potestas mea.

verses.textEn: And I took root among an honorable people, within the portion of my God, within his inheritance. And so my abode is in the full assembly of the saints.
verses.textLa: Et radicavi in populo honorificato, et in parte Dei mei hereditas illius, et in plenitudine sanctorum detentio mea.

verses.textEn: I was exalted like a cedar in Lebanon and like a cypress on Mount Zion.
verses.textLa: Quasi cedrus exaltata sum in Libano, et quasi cypressus in monte Sion:

verses.textEn: I was exalted like a palm tree in Kadesh and like a rose bush in Jericho.
verses.textLa: quasi palma exaltata sum in Cades, et quasi plantatio rosæ in Iericho:

verses.textEn: I was exalted like a beautiful olive tree in the plains, and like a sycamore tree beside the waters along a wide road.
verses.textLa: Quasi oliva speciosa in campis, et quasi platanus exaltata sum iuxta aquam in plateis.

verses.textEn: I gave off an aromatic fragrance like cinnamon or balsam. I produced a sweet odor like the best myrrh.
verses.textLa: Sicut cinnamomum, et balsamum aromatizans odorem dedi: quasi myrrha electa dedi suavitatem odoris:

verses.textEn: And I perfumed my dwelling place with sweet gum, and aromatic resin, and flower petals, and aloe, as well as the finest cedar from Lebanon. And my fragrance is like undiluted balsam.
verses.textLa: et quasi storax, et galbanus, et ungula, et gutta, et quasi Libanus non incisus vaporavi habitationem meam, et quasi balsamum non mistum odor meus.
verses.notes: The word ‘ungula’ literally means claw or talon, but is also used in botany to refer to the claw-shaped base of certain flower petals. Galbanum is a type of aromatic resin. Sweet gum is the closest translation which preserves the figurative meaning of the text and also is easily understandable in English. Challoner translates ‘gutta’ (lit. a droplet) as aloe. The phrase ‘Libanus non incisus’ refers to cedar wood from Lebanon (see previous verse). The phrase ‘non incisus’ means uncut, but certainly it is not an uncut tree; rather, it is an expression referring to the excellence of the cedar wood.

verses.textEn: I have extended my branches like a terebinth tree, and my branches are of honor and grace.
verses.textLa: Ego quasi terebinthus extendi ramos meos, et rami mei honoris et gratiæ.

verses.textEn: Like the vine, I have born the fruit of a sweet fragrance. And my flowers are the fruit of honor and integrity.
verses.textLa: Ego quasi vitis fructificavi suavitatem odoris: et flores mei fructus honoris et honestatis.

verses.textEn: I am the mother of the beauty of love, and of fear, and of knowledge, and of holy hope.
verses.textLa: Ego mater pulchræ dilectionis, et timoris, et agnitionis, et sanctæ spei.

verses.textEn: All grace of the way and of the truth is in me. All hope of life and of virtue is in me.
verses.textLa: In me gratia omnis viæ et veritatis, in me omnis spes vitæ et virtutis.

verses.textEn: Journey toward me, all you who desire me, and be filled by my harvest.
verses.textLa: Transite ad me omnes qui concupiscitis me, et a generationibus meis implemini:

verses.textEn: For my spirit is sweeter than honey, and my inheritance is better than honey and the honeycomb.
verses.textLa: spiritus enim meus super mel dulcis, et hereditas mea super mel et favum:

verses.textEn: My memory is for the generations of all ages.
verses.textLa: Memoria mea in generatione sæculorum.

verses.textEn: Whoever consumes me will hunger still. And whoever drinks me will thirst still.
verses.textLa: Qui edunt me, adhuc esurient: et qui bibunt me, adhuc sitient.

verses.textEn: Whoever listens to me will not be confounded. And whoever acts in me will not sin.
verses.textLa: Qui audit me, non confundetur: et qui operantur in me, non peccabunt:

verses.textEn: Whoever elucidates me will have eternal life.”
verses.textLa: Qui elucidant me, vitam æternam habebunt.

verses.textEn: All this is a book of life, and a covenant of the Most High, and an acknowledgement of truth.
verses.textLa: Hæc omnia liber vitæ, et testamentum Altissimi, et agnitio veritatis.

verses.textEn: Moses commanded the law by the precepts of justice, and an inheritance to the house of Jacob, and the promises to Israel.
verses.textLa: Legem mandavit Moyses in præceptis iustitiarum, et hereditatem domui Iacob, et Israel promissiones.

verses.textEn: God appointed David as his servant, in order to raise up from him a most mighty King, who would sit upon the throne of honor forever.
verses.textLa: Posuit David puero suo excitare Regem ex ipso fortissimum, et in throno honoris sedentem in sempiternum.

verses.textEn: It is he who fulfills wisdom, like the Phison river and the Tigris river in the first days.
verses.textLa: Qui implet quasi Phison sapientiam, et sicut Tigris in diebus novorum.

verses.textEn: It is he who fulfills understanding, like the river Euphrates. It is he who multiplies understanding, like the river Jordan in the time of the harvest.
verses.textLa: Qui adimplet quasi Euphrates sensum: qui multiplicat quasi Iordanis in tempore messis.

verses.textEn: He sends forth discipline like the light, and he stands forth like the river Gehon in the time of the vintage.
verses.textLa: Qui mittit disciplinam sicut lucem, et assistens quasi Gehon in die vindemiæ.
verses.notes: The Greek and Latin read 'like the light' and the Hebrew and Neo-Vulgate read 'like the Nile'.

verses.textEn: He first had perfect knowledge of her, for a weaker one would not search for her.
verses.textLa: Qui perficit primus scire ipsam, et infirmior non investigabit eam.

verses.textEn: For her thoughts abound like the sea, and her counsels abound like the great abyss.
verses.textLa: A mari enim abundavit cogitatio eius, et consilium illius ab abysso magna.

verses.textEn: “I, wisdom, have poured forth rivers.
verses.textLa: Ego sapientiam effudi flumina.

verses.textEn: I am like a brook leading to a river of immense waters. I am like a channel flowing from a river. And I went forth from Paradise like an aqueduct.
verses.textLa: Ego quasi trames aquæ immensæ de fluvio, ego quasi fluvii dioryx, et sicut aquæductus exivi de Paradiso.

verses.textEn: I said: I will irrigate my garden of plantings, and I will thoroughly water the fruits of my field.
verses.textLa: Dixi: Rigabo hortum meum plantationum, et inebriabo prati mei fructum.

verses.textEn: And behold, my brook became overflowing, and my river drew near to the sea.
verses.textLa: Et ecce factus est mihi trames abundans, et fluvius meus appropinquavit ad mare:

verses.textEn: For I illuminate doctrine to all, like the first light. And I will announce doctrine, even to those who are far away.
verses.textLa: quoniam doctrinam quasi antelucanum illumino omnibus, et enarrabo illam usque ad longinquum.

verses.textEn: I will reach to all the lower parts of the earth, and I will gaze upon all who sleep, and I will illuminate all who hope in the Lord.
verses.textLa: Penetrabo omnes inferiores partes terræ, et inspiciam omnes dormientes, et illuminabo omnes sperantes in Domino.

verses.textEn: Even now, I pour forth doctrine like prophecy. And even now, I bequeath doctrine to those who seek wisdom. And I will not cease from their progeny, even unto the holy time.
verses.textLa: Adhuc doctrinam quasi prophetiam effundam, et relinquam illam quærentibus sapientiam, et non desinam in progenies illorum usque in ævum sanctum.

verses.textEn: See how I have not labored for myself alone, but for all who are seeking truth!”
verses.textLa: Videte quoniam non soli mihi laboravi, sed omnibus exquirentibus veritatem.

verses.textEn: My spirit is pleased with three things; these are approved in the sight of God and men:
verses.textLa: In tribus placitum est spiritui meo, quæ sunt probata coram Deo, et hominibus:

verses.textEn: the harmony of brothers, and the love of neighbors, and a husband and wife agreeing well together.
verses.textLa: Concordia fratrum, et amor proximorum, et vir et mulier bene sibi consentientes.

verses.textEn: My soul hates three kinds of things; and I am greatly distressed over their souls:
verses.textLa: Tres species odivit anima mea, et aggravor valde animæ illorum:

verses.textEn: an arrogant pauper, a wealthy liar, a foolish and senseless elder.
verses.textLa: Pauperem superbum: divitem mendacem: senem fatuum et insensatum.

verses.textEn: The things that you have not obtained in your youth, how will you find them in your old age?
verses.textLa: Quæ in iuventute tua non congregasti, quomodo in senectute tua invenies?

verses.textEn: How beautiful it is for a grey head to have judgment, and for elders to know counsel!
verses.textLa: Quam speciosum canitiei iudicium, et presbyteris cognoscere consilium!

verses.textEn: How beautiful it is for those who are aged to have wisdom, and for those who are honored to have understanding and counsel!
verses.textLa: Quam speciosa veteranis sapientia, et gloriosus intellectus, et consilium!

verses.textEn: Great experience is the crown of the aged, and the fear of God is their glory.
verses.textLa: Corona senum multa peritia, et gloria illorum timor Dei.

verses.textEn: I have magnified nine things, overlooked by the heart; and a tenth, I will declare to men with my tongue:
verses.textLa: Novem insuspicabilia cordis magnificavi, et decimum dicam in lingua hominibus:

verses.textEn: a man who finds joy in his children, and one who lives to see the undoing of his enemies.
verses.textLa: Homo, qui iucundatur in filiis, vivens et videns subversionem inimicorum suorum.

verses.textEn: Blessed is he who lives with a wise wife, and he who has not slipped with his tongue, and he who has not served those unworthy of himself.
verses.textLa: Beatus, qui habitat cum muliere sensata, et qui lingua sua non est lapsus, et qui non servivit indignis se.

verses.textEn: Blessed is he who finds a true friend, and he who describes justice to an attentive ear.
verses.textLa: Beatus, qui invenit amicum verum, et qui enarrat iustitiam auri audienti.

verses.textEn: How great is he who finds wisdom and knowledge! But there is no one above him who fears the Lord.
verses.textLa: Quam magnus, qui invenit sapientiam et scientiam! Sed non est super timentem Dominum.

verses.textEn: The fear of God has set itself above all things.
verses.textLa: Timor Dei super omnia se superposuit:

verses.textEn: Blessed is the man to whom it has been given to have the fear of God. He who holds to it, to whom can he be compared?
verses.textLa: Beatus homo, cui donatum est habere timorem Dei: qui tenet illum, cui assimilabitur?

verses.textEn: The fear of God is the beginning of his love; and the beginning of faith has been joined closely to the same.
verses.textLa: Timor Dei initium dilectionis eius: fidei autem initium agglutinandum est ei.

verses.textEn: The sadness of the heart is every wound. And the wickedness of a wife is every malice.
verses.textLa: Omnis plaga tristitia cordis est: et omnis malitia, nequitia mulieris.

verses.textEn: And a man will choose any wound, but the wound of the heart,
verses.textLa: Et omnem plagam, et non plagam videbit cordis:

verses.textEn: and any wickedness, but the wickedness of a wife,
verses.textLa: et omnem nequitiam, et non nequitiam mulieris:

verses.textEn: and any obstacle, but the obstacle of those who hate him,
verses.textLa: et omnem obductum, et non obductum odientium:

verses.textEn: and any vindication, but the vindication of his enemies.
verses.textLa: et omnem vindictam, et non vindictam inimicorum.

verses.textEn: There is no head worse than the head of a serpent,
verses.textLa: Non est caput nequius super caput colubri:
verses.notes: The Greek and Latin read 'head' and the Hebrew and Neo-Vulgate read 'poison'.

verses.textEn: and there is no anger above the anger of a wife. It would be more agreeable to abide with a lion or a dragon, than to live with a wicked wife.
verses.textLa: et non est ira super iram mulieris. Commorari leoni et draconi placebit, quam habitare cum muliere nequam.

verses.textEn: A wicked wife changes her face. And she darkens her countenance like a bear. And she displays it like sackcloth. In the midst of her neighbors,
verses.textLa: Nequitia mulieris immutat faciem eius: et obcæcat vultum suum tamquam ursus: et quasi saccum ostendit. In medio proximorum eius

verses.textEn: her husband groans, and hearing of this, he sighs a little.
verses.textLa: ingemuit vir eius, et audiens suspiravit modicum.

verses.textEn: All malice is brief compared to the malice of a wife. Let the fate of sinners fall upon her!
verses.textLa: Brevis omnis malitia super malitiam mulieris, sors peccatorum cadat super illam.

verses.textEn: As climbing over sand is to the feet of the aged, so is a talkative wife to a quiet man.
verses.textLa: Sicut ascensus arenosus in pedibus veterani, sic mulier linguata homini quieto.

verses.textEn: You should not favor a woman’s beauty, and you should not desire a wife for her beauty.
verses.textLa: Ne respicias in mulieris speciem, et non concupiscas mulierem in specie.

verses.textEn: The anger and disrespect and shame from a wife can be great.
verses.textLa: Mulieris ira, et irreverentia, et confusio magna.

verses.textEn: The wife, if she has primacy, is set against her husband.
verses.textLa: Mulier si primatum habeat, contraria est viro suo.

verses.textEn: A wicked wife debases the heart, and saddens the face, and wounds the heart.
verses.textLa: Cor humile, et facies tristis, et plaga cordis, mulier nequam.

verses.textEn: A wife who does not make her husband happy enfeebles the hands and weakens the knees.
verses.textLa: Manus debiles, et genua dissoluta, mulier quæ non beatificat virum suum.

verses.textEn: The beginning of sin came from a woman; and through her, we all die.
verses.textLa: A muliere initium factum est peccati, et per illam omnes morimur.

verses.textEn: You should not provide an exit to your water, not even a little; nor should you give permission for a wicked wife to exceed the limit.
verses.textLa: Non des aquæ tuæ exitum, nec modicum: nec mulieri nequam veniam prodeundi.
verses.notes: The word ‘prodeundi’ usually refers to travel beyond a certain point; but here it is used figuratively, to mean exceeding a certain limit.

verses.textEn: If she will not walk at your hand, she will confound you in the sight of your enemies.
verses.textLa: Si non ambulaverit ad manum tuam, confundet te in conspectu inimicorum.

verses.textEn: Tear her away from your body, lest she abuse you continually.
verses.textLa: A carnibus tuis abscinde illam, ne semper te abutatur.

verses.textEn: Blessed is the husband of a good wife. For the number of his years is doubled.
verses.textLa: Mulieris bonæ beatus vir: numerus enim annorum illius duplex.

verses.textEn: A good wife delights her husband, and she will fill up the years of his life with peace.
verses.textLa: Mulier fortis oblectat virum suum, et annos vitæ illius in pace implebit.

verses.textEn: A good wife is a good portion. She will be given the portion of those who fear God, like a man who has done good deeds.
verses.textLa: Pars bona, mulier bona, in parte timentium Deum dabitur viro pro factis bonis:

verses.textEn: But, rich or poor, with a good heart, his countenance will be cheerful at all times.
verses.textLa: divitis autem, et pauperis cor bonum, in omni tempore vultus illorum hilaris.

verses.textEn: Of three things, my heart has been afraid, and at a fourth, my face has shown dread:
verses.textLa: A tribus timuit cor meum, et in quarto facies mea metuit:

verses.textEn: an accusation made by a city, and the gathering of a mob,
verses.textLa: Delaturam civitatis: et collectionem populi:

verses.textEn: and a deceitful false accusation. All these are more grievous than death.
verses.textLa: calumniam mendacem, super mortem, omnia gravia:

verses.textEn: A jealous wife is a grief and a mourning to the heart.
verses.textLa: dolor cordis et luctus, mulier zelotypa.

verses.textEn: In a jealous wife, there is a scourge of the tongue, which communicates with everyone.
verses.textLa: In muliere zelotypa flagellum linguæ, omnibus communicans.

verses.textEn: Like a yoke of oxen being provoked, so also is a wicked wife. He who has hold of her is like one who has taken hold of a scorpion.
verses.textLa: Sicut boum iugum, quod movetur, ita et mulier nequam: qui tenet illam, quasi qui apprehendit scorpionem.

verses.textEn: An inebriated wife is a great wrath. And her disgrace and indecency will not be covered.
verses.textLa: Mulier ebriosa ira magna: et contumelia, et turpitudo illius non tegetur.

verses.textEn: The fornication of a wife will become known by the haughtiness of her eyes and by her eyelids.
verses.textLa: Fornicatio mulieris in extollentia oculorum, et in palpebris illius agnoscetur.

verses.textEn: So that her daughter will not also turn away, keep a strict watch; otherwise, having found an opportunity, she may enjoy herself.
verses.textLa: In filia non avertente se, firma custodiam: ne inventa occasione utatur se.

verses.textEn: Be wary of the irreverence of her eyes, and you should not wonder if she might disregard you.
verses.textLa: Ab omni irreverentia oculorum eius cave, et ne mireris si te neglexerit.

verses.textEn: Like a thirsty traveler, she will open her mouth to the fountain, and she will drink from every water nearby, and she will sit down beside every fencepost, and she will open her quiver to every arrow, until she becomes weary.
verses.textLa: Sicut viator sitiens, ad fontem os aperiet, et ab omni aqua proxima bibet, et contra omnem palum sedebit, et contra omnem sagittam aperiet pharetram donec deficiat.

verses.textEn: The grace of an attentive wife will delight her husband, and will fatten his bones.
verses.textLa: Gratia mulieris sedulæ delectabit virum suum, et ossa illius impinguabit.

verses.textEn: Her discipline is a gift from God.
verses.textLa: Disciplina illius datum Dei est.

verses.textEn: Such is an understanding and quiet wife. For there is no substitution for a well-instructed soul.
verses.textLa: Mulier sensata et tacita, non est immutatio eruditæ animæ.

verses.textEn: A holy and contrite wife is grace upon grace.
verses.textLa: Gratia super gratiam mulier sancta, et pudorata.

verses.textEn: And no amount of money is equal to the value of a soul with self-restraint.
verses.textLa: Omnis autem ponderatio non est digna continentis animæ.

verses.textEn: Like the sun rising over the world in the high places of God, so the beauty of a good wife is the adornment of her house.
verses.textLa: Sicut sol oriens mundo in altissimis Dei, sic mulieris bonæ species in ornamentum domus eius.

verses.textEn: Like a lamp shining atop a holy lampstand, so is the beauty of a face in the mature stage of life.
verses.textLa: Lucerna splendens super candelabrum sanctum, et species faciei super ætatem stabilem.

verses.textEn: Like golden pillars upon bases of silver, so are the firm feet of a mature wife upon the soles of her feet.
verses.textLa: Columnæ aureæ super bases argenteas, et pedes firmi super plantas stabilis mulieris.

verses.textEn: Like everlasting foundations upon a solid rock, so are the commandments of God in the heart of a holy wife.
verses.textLa: Fundamenta æterna supra petram solidam, et mandata Dei in corde mulieris sanctæ.

verses.textEn: By two things, my heart is greatly saddened, and at a third, anger overwhelms me:
verses.textLa: In duobus contristatum est cor meum, et in tertio iracundia mihi advenit:

verses.textEn: a man of war failing because of dire need, and an understanding man treated with contempt,
verses.textLa: Vir bellator deficiens per inopiam: et vir sensatus contemptus:

verses.textEn: and anyone who crosses over from justice to sin. God has prepared such a one for the spear.
verses.textLa: et qui transgreditur a iustitia ad peccatum, Deus paravit eum ad rhomphæam.

verses.textEn: Two kinds of things have seemed difficult and dangerous to me: a merchant will not be easily freed from his negligence, and a shopkeeper will not be justified by the sins of his lips.
verses.textLa: Duæ species difficiles et periculosæ mihi apparuerunt, difficile exuitur negotians a negligentia: et non iustificabitur caupo a peccatis labiorum.

verses.textEn: Because of need, many have sinned. And whoever seeks to be enriched, averts his eye.
verses.textLa: Propter inopiam multi deliquerunt: et qui quærit locupletari, avertit oculum suum.

verses.textEn: Like a post fixed in the middle of adjoining stones, so also will sin become wedged between selling and buying.
verses.textLa: Sicut in medio compaginis lapidum palus figitur, sic et inter medium venditionis et emptionis angustiabitur peccatum.

verses.textEn: Sin will be crushed with the one who sins.
verses.textLa: Conteretur cum delinquente delictum.

verses.textEn: If you do not hold yourself steadfastly to the fear of the Lord, your house will be quickly overthrown.
verses.textLa: Si non in timore Domini tenueris te instanter, cito subvertetur domus tua.

verses.textEn: Just as the dust remains when one shakes a sieve, so will the doubt of a man remain in his thoughts.
verses.textLa: Sicut in percussura cribri remanebit pulvis, sic aporia hominis in cogitatu illius.

verses.textEn: The furnace tests the potter’s vessels, and the trial of the tribulation tests just men.
verses.textLa: Vasa figuli probat fornax, et homines iustos tentatio tribulationis.

verses.textEn: As the pruning of a tree reveals its fruit, so does a word reveal the thoughts in the heart of a man.
verses.textLa: Sicut rusticatio de ligno ostendit fructum illius, sic verbum ex cogitatu cordis hominis.

verses.textEn: You should not praise a man before he speaks; for such is the testing of men.
verses.textLa: Ante sermonem non laudes virum: hæc enim tentatio est hominum.

verses.textEn: If you pursue justice, you will obtain it. And you will be clothed with justice, as with a long robe of honor. And you will live with justice. And justice will protect you continually. And on the day of reckoning, you will find a strong foundation.
verses.textLa: Si sequaris iustitiam, apprehendes illam: et indues quasi poderem honoris, et inhabitabis cum ea, et proteget te in sempiternum, et in die agnitionis invenies firmamentum.

verses.textEn: Birds flock to their own kind. And truth will return to those who practice it.
verses.textLa: Volatilia ad sibi similia conveniunt: et veritas ad eos, qui operantur illam, revertetur.

verses.textEn: The lion lies in wait for its prey continually. So also do sins lie in wait for those who work iniquity.
verses.textLa: Leo venationi insidiatur semper: sic peccata operantibus iniquitates.

verses.textEn: A holy man persists in wisdom like the sun. But a senseless man changes like the moon.
verses.textLa: Homo sanctus in sapientia manet sicut sol: nam stultus sicut luna mutatur.

verses.textEn: In the midst of the senseless, retain a word for the proper time. But be continually in the midst of those who are thoughtful.
verses.textLa: In medio insensatorum serva verbum tempori: in medio autem cogitantium assiduus esto.

verses.textEn: The discussions of sinners are hateful, and their laughter is a delight in sin.
verses.textLa: Narratio peccantium odiosa, et risus illorum in deliciis peccati.

verses.textEn: The speech that swears many oaths will cause the hair of the head to stand upright; and its irreverence will cause the ears to be blocked.
verses.textLa: Loquela multum iurans, horripilationem capiti statuet: et irreverentia ipsius obturatio aurium.

verses.textEn: The shedding of blood is in the quarrels of the arrogant; and their evil talk is grievous to hear.
verses.textLa: Effusio sanguinis in rixa superborum: et maledictio illorum auditus gravis.

verses.textEn: Whoever discloses the secret of a friend breaks faith; and he will not find a friend for his soul.
verses.textLa: Qui denudat arcana amici, fidem perdit, et non inveniet amicum ad animum suum.

verses.textEn: Love your neighbor, and be united with him faithfully.
verses.textLa: Dilige proximum, et coniungere fide cum illo.

verses.textEn: But if you disclose his secrets, you should not continue to follow after him.
verses.textLa: Quod si denudaveris absconsa illius, non persequeris post eum.

verses.textEn: For like a man who destroys his friend, so also is he who destroys the friendship of his neighbor.
verses.textLa: Sicut enim homo, qui perdit amicum suum, sic et qui perdit amicitiam proximi sui.

verses.textEn: And like someone releasing a bird from his hand, so have you abandoned your neighbor, and you will not obtain him again.
verses.textLa: Et sicut qui dimittit avem de manu sua, sic dereliquisti proximum tuum, et non eum capies.

verses.textEn: You should no longer seek him, for he is now far away; he has fled like a roe-deer from a snare. For his soul has been wounded.
verses.textLa: non illum sequaris, quoniam longe abest: effugit enim quasi caprea de laqueo: quoniam vulnerata est anima eius.

verses.textEn: You will no longer be able to bind his wound. For there may be a reconciliation from cursing.
verses.textLa: Ultra eum non poteris colligare: et maledicti est concordatio:

verses.textEn: But to disclose the secrets of a friend is the hopeless act of an unhappy soul.
verses.textLa: denudare autem amici mysteria, desperatio est animæ infelicis.

verses.textEn: One who winks with the eye fabricates iniquity, and no one will cast him aside.
verses.textLa: Annuens oculo fabricat iniqua, et nemo eum abiiciet:

verses.textEn: In the sight of your eyes, he will sweeten his mouth, and he will admire your talk. But at the very end, he will pervert his mouth, and he will offer a scandal from your own words.
verses.textLa: in conspectu oculorum tuorum condulcabit os suum, et super sermones tuos admirabitur: novissime autem pervertet os suum, et in verbis tuis dabit scandalum.

verses.textEn: I have hated many things, but I have not done as he has done, and the Lord will hate him.
verses.textLa: Multa odivi, et non coæquavi ei, et Dominus odiet illum.

verses.textEn: Whoever throws a stone straight up will find that it falls on his own head. And a deceitful wound will return to wound the deceitful.
verses.textLa: Qui in altum mittit lapidem, super caput eius cadet: et plaga dolosa dolosi dividet vulnera.

verses.textEn: And whoever digs a pit will fall into it. And whoever positions a stone against his neighbor will stumble over it. And whoever lays a trap for another will perish by it.
verses.textLa: Et qui foveam fodit, incidet in eam: et qui statuit lapidem proximo, offendet in eo: et qui laqueum alii ponit, peribit in illo.

verses.textEn: Whoever sets in motion a wicked plan will find that it rolls back over him, and he will not know from which direction it will arrive.
verses.textLa: Facienti nequissimum consilium, super ipsum devolvetur, et non agnoscet unde adveniat illi.

verses.textEn: Mockery and derision are of the arrogant, and vengeance will lie in wait for them, like a lion.
verses.textLa: Illusio, et improperium superborum, et vindicta sicut leo insidiabitur illi.

verses.textEn: Whoever enjoys the fall of the just will perish in a snare, and grief will consume them before they die.
verses.textLa: Laqueo peribunt qui oblectantur casu iustorum: dolor autem consumet illos antequam moriantur.

verses.textEn: Anger and fury are both abominable, and the sinful man will be held by them.
verses.textLa: Ira et furor, utraque execrabilia sunt, et vir peccator continens erit illorum.

verses.textEn: Whoever wishes for vengeance will find vengeance from the Lord, and he will surely be attentive to his sins.
verses.textLa: Qui vindicari vult, a Domino inveniet vindictam, et peccata illius servans servabit.

verses.textEn: Forgive your neighbor, if he has harmed you, and then your sins will be forgiven you when you pray.
verses.textLa: Relinque proximo tuo nocenti te: et tunc deprecanti tibi peccata solventur.

verses.textEn: A man holds on to anger against another man, and does he then seek a remedy from God?
verses.textLa: Homo homini reservat iram, et a Deo quærit medelam?

verses.textEn: He has no mercy on a man like himself, and does he then entreat for his own sins?
verses.textLa: In hominem similem sibi non habet misericordiam, et de peccatis suis deprecatur?

verses.textEn: He who is but flesh holds on to anger, and does he then request forgiveness from God? Who can obtain pardon for his sins in this way?
verses.textLa: Ipse cum caro sit, reservat iram, et propitiationem petit a Deo? Quis exorabit pro delictis illius?

verses.textEn: Remember your very end, and let animosities cease.
verses.textLa: Memento novissimorum, et desine inimicari:

verses.textEn: For corruption and death are suspended over his commandments.
verses.textLa: tabitudo enim et mors imminent in mandatis eius.

verses.textEn: Remember the fear of God, and do not be angry with your neighbor.
verses.textLa: Memorare timorem Dei, et non irascaris proximo.

verses.textEn: Remember the covenant of the Most High, and overlook the ignorant offenses of your neighbor.
verses.textLa: Memorare testamentum Altissimi, et despice ignorantiam proximi.

verses.textEn: Refrain from strife, and you will diminish your sins.
verses.textLa: Abstine te a lite, et minues peccata:

verses.textEn: For an ill-tempered man enflames conflict, and a sinful man troubles his friends, and he casts hostility into the midst of those who have peace.
verses.textLa: homo enim iracundus incendit litem, et vir peccator turbabit amicos, et in medio pacem habentium immittet inimicitiam.

verses.textEn: For the fire burns according to the wood of the forest. And the anger of a man burns according to the strength of the man. And according to his resources, he will exalt his anger.
verses.textLa: Secundum enim ligna silvæ sic ignis exardescit: et secundum virtutem hominis, sic iracundia illius erit, et secundum substantiam suam exaltabit iram suam.

verses.textEn: A hasty contention kindles a fire. And a hasty quarrel sheds blood. And an accusatory tongue brings death.
verses.textLa: Certamen festinatum incendit ignem: et lis festinans effundit sanguinem: et lingua testificans adducit mortem.

verses.textEn: If you blow on a spark, it will increase to a fire. But if you spit on it, it will be extinguished. Both of these proceed from the mouth.
verses.textLa: Si sufflaveris in scintillam, quasi ignis exardebit: et si expueris super illam, extinguetur: utraque ex ore proficiscuntur.

verses.textEn: The double-tongued whisperer is accursed. For he has disturbed many who had peace.
verses.textLa: Susurro et bilinguis maledictus: multos enim turbabit pacem habentes.

verses.textEn: A third tongue has stirred up many, and has scattered them from nation to nation.
verses.textLa: Lingua tertia multos commovit, et dispersit illos de gente in gentem.

verses.textEn: It has destroyed the walled cities of the wealthy, and has undermined the houses of the great.
verses.textLa: Civitates muratas divitum destruxit, et domus magnatorum effodit.

verses.textEn: It has cut down the virtues of the peoples, and has broken strong nations.
verses.textLa: Virtutes populorum concidit, et gentes fortes dissolvit.

verses.textEn: A third tongue has cast down virtuous women, and has deprived them of their labors.
verses.textLa: Lingua tertia mulieres viratas eiecit, et privavit illas laboribus suis.

verses.textEn: Whoever favors it will not have rest, nor will he have a friend in whom he may find peace.
verses.textLa: Qui respicit illam, non habebit requiem, nec habebit amicum, in quo requiescat.

verses.textEn: The wound of a whip causes a bruise, but the wound of the tongue will crush the bones.
verses.textLa: Flagelli plaga livorem facit: plaga autem linguæ comminuet ossa.

verses.textEn: Many have fallen by the mouth of the sword, but not as many as have perished by their own tongue.
verses.textLa: Multi ceciderunt in ore gladii, sed non sic quasi qui interierunt per linguam suam.

verses.textEn: Blessed is he who is protected from a wicked tongue, who has not gone over to its wrath, and has not pulled its yoke, and has not been bound by its chains.
verses.textLa: Beatus qui tectus est a lingua nequam, qui in iracundiam illius non transivit, et qui non attraxit iugum illius, et in vinculis eius non est ligatus:

verses.textEn: For its yoke is a yoke of iron. And its chains are chains of brass.
verses.textLa: iugum enim illius, iugum ferreum est: et vinculum illius, vinculum æreum est.

verses.textEn: Its death is a most wicked death. And hell is more useful than it is.
verses.textLa: Mors illius, mors nequissima: et utilis potius infernus quam illa.

verses.textEn: Its continuance will not be permanent, but it will take hold of the ways of the unjust. And the just will not be burned by its flame.
verses.textLa: Perseverantia illius non permanebit, sed obtinebit vias iniustorum: et in flamma sua non comburet iustos.

verses.textEn: Those who abandon God will fall by it, and it will burn within them and not be quenched. And it will be sent upon them, like a lion, and it will wound them, like a leopard.
verses.textLa: Qui relinquunt Deum, incident in illam, et exardebit in illis, et non extinguetur, et immittetur in illos quasi leo, et quasi pardus lædet illos.

verses.textEn: Hedge your ears with thorns. Do not be willing to listen to a wicked tongue. And make doors and bars for your mouth.
verses.textLa: Sepi aures tuas spinis, linguam nequam noli audire, et ori tuo facito ostia, et seras.

verses.textEn: Melt down your gold and your silver. And make a scale for your words, and an upright bridle for your mouth.
verses.textLa: Aurum tuum et argentum tuum confla, et verbis tuis facito stateram, et frenos ori tuo rectos:

verses.textEn: And be attentive, lest perhaps you may slip with your tongue, and fall in the sight of your enemies, who are lying in wait for you, and then your fall may be incurable unto death.
verses.textLa: et attende ne forte labaris in lingua, et cadas in conspectu inimicorum insidiantium tibi, et sit casus tuus insanabilis in mortem.

verses.textEn: He shows mercy who lends to his neighbor, for he keeps the commandments by strengthening him.
verses.textLa: Qui facit misericordiam, fœneratur proximo suo: et qui prævalet manu, mandata servat.

verses.textEn: Lend to your neighbor in his time of need, and receive it again from your neighbor in his time.
verses.textLa: Fœnerare proximo tuo in tempore necessitatis illius, et iterum redde proximo in tempore suo.

verses.textEn: Keep your word, and act faithfully with him, and then you will find whatever you need in every time.
verses.textLa: Confirma verbum, et fideliter age cum illo: et in omni tempore invenies quod tibi necessarium est.

verses.textEn: Many have treated a loan like found money, and they offered trouble to those who helped them.
verses.textLa: Multi quasi inventionem æstimaverunt fœnus, et præstiterunt molestiam his, qui se adiuverunt.

verses.textEn: Until they receive, they kiss the hands of the giver, and they humble their voice in promises.
verses.textLa: Donec accipiant, osculantur manus dantis, et in promissionibus humiliant vocem suam:

verses.textEn: But at the time of repayment, they will ask for more time, and they will speak annoying and complaining words, and they will make excuses for the time.
verses.textLa: et in tempore redditionis postulabit tempus, et loquetur verba tædii et murmurationum, et tempus causabitur:

verses.textEn: Then, if he is able to repay, he will turn away. He will pay barely one half, and he will consider it as if he had found it.
verses.textLa: si autem potuerit reddere, adversabitur, solidi vix reddet dimidium, et computabit illud quasi inventionem:

verses.textEn: But if not, then he will defraud him of his money, and he will have him as an enemy without cause.
verses.textLa: sin autem fraudabit illum pecunia sua, et possidebit illum inimicum gratis:

verses.textEn: And he will repay him with accusations and curses, and he will repay him with contempt, instead of with honor and kindness.
verses.textLa: et convitia et maledicta reddet illi, et pro honore et beneficio reddet illi contumeliam.

verses.textEn: Many have refused to lend, not because of wickedness, but because they were afraid to be defrauded without cause.
verses.textLa: Multi non causa nequitiæ non fœnerati sunt, sed fraudari gratis timuerunt.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, be more steadfast toward the humble, and you should not delay in acts of mercy toward them.
verses.textLa: Verumtamen super humilem animo fortior esto, et pro eleemosyna non trahas illum.

verses.textEn: Assist the poor because of the commandment. And you should not send him away empty because of his dire need.
verses.textLa: Propter mandatum assume pauperem: et propter inopiam eius ne dimittas eum vacuum.

verses.textEn: Lose your money to your brother and your friend. For you should not hide it under a stone to be lost.
verses.textLa: Perde pecuniam propter fratrem et amicum tuum: et non abscondas illam sub lapide in perditionem.

verses.textEn: Let your treasure be in the precepts of the Most High, and it will benefit you more than gold.
verses.textLa: Pone thesaurum tuum in præceptis Altissimi, et proderit tibi magis quam aurum.

verses.textEn: Store your alms in the hearts of the poor, and it will obtain help for you against all evil.
verses.textLa: Conclude eleemosynam in corde pauperis, et hæc pro te exorabit ab omni malo.

verses.textEn: Better than the shield or the lance of a powerful man,
verses.textLa: Super scutum potentis, et super lanceam

verses.textEn: it will fight for you against your enemy.
verses.textLa: adversus inimicum tuum pugnabit.

verses.textEn: A good man offers credit for the sake of his neighbor. But one who abandons him to himself will perish in shame.
verses.textLa: Vir bonus fidem facit pro proximo suo: et qui perdiderit confusionem, derelinquet sibi.

verses.textEn: You should not forget the kindness of your benefactor. For he has offered his life on your behalf.
verses.textLa: Gratiam fideiussoris ne obliviscaris: dedit enim pro te animam suam.

verses.textEn: The sinner and the unclean flee from such promises.
verses.textLa: Repromissorem fugit peccator et immundus.

verses.textEn: A sinner attributes to himself the goods of his loan. And an ungrateful mind will abandon the one who has freed him.
verses.textLa: Bona repromissoris sibi ascribit peccator: et ingratus sensu derelinquet liberantem se.

verses.textEn: A man offers credit to his neighbor. But when he will have lost respect, he will abandon him.
verses.textLa: Vir repromittit de proximo suo: et cum perdiderit reverentiam, derelinquetur ab eo.

verses.textEn: A wicked promise has destroyed many who had good intentions, and has tossed them like a wave on the ocean.
verses.textLa: Repromissio nequissima multos perdidit dirigentes, et commovit illos quasi fluctus maris.

verses.textEn: It has caused powerful men to travel around, and they have wandered amid foreign nations.
verses.textLa: Viros potentes gyrans migrare fecit, et vagati sunt in gentibus alienis.

verses.textEn: A sinner transgressing the commandment of the Lord will fall into a wicked promise. And he who undertakes many things will fall into judgment.
verses.textLa: Peccator transgrediens mandatum Domini incidet in promissionem nequam: et qui conatur multa agere, incidet in iudicium.

verses.textEn: Help your neighbor to recover according to your ability, but attend to yourself, lest you also fall.
verses.textLa: Recupera proximum secundum virtutem tuam, et attende tibi ne incidas.

verses.textEn: The primary need in a man’s life is water and bread, and clothing, and a house to protect modesty.
verses.textLa: Initium vitæ hominis aqua et panis, et vestimentum, et domus protegens turpitudinem.

verses.textEn: A pauper’s food under a roof of boards is better than a splendid feast on a sojourn away from home.
verses.textLa: Melior est victus pauperis sub tegmine asserum, quam epulæ splendidæ in peregre sine domicilio.

verses.textEn: Let yourself be pleased with little instead of much, and you will not hear the reproach of being away from home.
verses.textLa: Minimum pro magno placeat tibi, et improperium peregrinationis non audies.

verses.textEn: It is a wicked life to go from house to house as a guest. For wherever he is a guest, he will not act confidently, nor open his mouth.
verses.textLa: Vita nequam hospitandi de domo in domum: et ubi hospitabitur, non fiducialiter aget, nec aperiet os.

verses.textEn: He will entertain, and feed, and give drink to the ungrateful, and beyond this, he will listen to bitter words:
verses.textLa: Hospitabitur, et pascet, et potabit ingratos, et ad hæc amara audiet.

verses.textEn: “Go, my guest, and set the table, and let others eat from what you have in your hand.”
verses.textLa: Transi hospes, et orna mensam: et quæ in manu habes, ciba ceteros.

verses.textEn: “Depart from the honored face of my friends. For it has become necessary for my house to host my brother instead.”
verses.textLa: Exi a facie honoris amicorum meorum: necessitudine domus meæ hospitio mihi factus est frater.

verses.textEn: These things are grievous to a man having understanding: to take advantage of a household, and to reproach a lender.
verses.textLa: Gravia hæc homini habenti sensum: correptio domus, et improperium fœneratoris.

verses.textEn: He who loves his son will frequently chastise him, so that he may be happy in the very end, and not grope for the doors of his neighbors.
verses.textLa: Qui diligit filium suum, assiduat illi flagella, ut lætetur in novissimo suo, et non palpet proximorum ostia.

verses.textEn: He who instructs his son will be praised over him and will glory in him, in the midst of his household.
verses.textLa: Qui docet filium suum, laudabitur in illo, et in medio domesticorum in illo gloriabitur.

verses.textEn: He who teaches his son will make his enemy jealous, and in the midst of his friends, he will glory in him.
verses.textLa: Qui docet filium suum, in zelum mittit inimicum, et in medio amicorum gloriabitur in illo.

verses.textEn: When his father has died, it will be as if he were not dead. For he will have left behind someone who is like himself.
verses.textLa: Mortuus est pater eius, et quasi non est mortuus: similem enim reliquit sibi post se.

verses.textEn: In his life, he saw him and rejoiced in him. And at his passing, he was not sorrowful, nor was he confounded in the sight of his enemies.
verses.textLa: In vita sua vidit, et lætatus est in illo: in obitu suo non est contristatus, nec confusus est coram inimicis.

verses.textEn: For he left behind himself a defender of his house against his enemies, and someone who will repay his friends with kindness.
verses.textLa: Reliquit enim defensorem domus contra inimicos, et amicis reddentem gratiam.

verses.textEn: For the sake of the souls of his sons, he will bind up his wounds, and at every voice, his gut will be stirred up.
verses.textLa: Pro animabus filiorum colligabit vulnera sua, et super omnem vocem turbabuntur viscera eius.

verses.textEn: An untamed horse becomes stubborn, and a child left to himself becomes headstrong.
verses.textLa: Equus indomitus evadit durus, et filius remissus evadet præceps.

verses.textEn: Coddle a son, and he will make you afraid. Play with him, and he will make you sorrowful.
verses.textLa: Lacta filium, et paventem te faciet: lude cum eo, et contristabit te.

verses.textEn: You should not laugh with him; otherwise you may have grief, and in the end, your teeth will be clenched.
verses.textLa: Non corrideas illi: ne doleas, et in novissimo obstupescent dentes tui.

verses.textEn: You should not give him power in his youth, but you should not despise his thoughts.
verses.textLa: Non des illi potestatem in iuventute, et ne despicias cogitatus illius.

verses.textEn: Bow down his neck in his youth, and slap his sides while he is a child, lest perhaps he may become stubborn, and then he will not trust you, and so he will bring sorrow to your soul.
verses.textLa: Curva cervicem eius in iuventute, et tunde latera eius dum infans est, ne forte induret, et non credat tibi, et erit tibi dolor animæ.

verses.textEn: Instruct your son, and work with him, lest you give offense by his shameful behavior.
verses.textLa: Doce filium tuum, et operare in illo, ne in turpitudinem illius offendas.

verses.textEn: Better is a healthy pauper with a strong constitution, than a wealthy man who is weak and afflicted by maladies.
verses.textLa: Melior est pauper sanus, et fortis viribus, quam dives imbecillis et flagellatus malitia.

verses.textEn: A healthy soul with the sanctity of justice is better than all the gold and silver. And a sound body is better than immense revenues.
verses.textLa: Salus animæ in sanctitate iustitiæ melior est omni auro et argento: et corpus validum quam census immensus.

verses.textEn: There is no revenue above the revenue of a healthy body. And there is no delight above a joyful heart.
verses.textLa: Non est census super censum salutis corporis: et non est oblectamentum super cordis gaudium.

verses.textEn: Death is better than a bitter life. And eternal rest is better than continual sickness.
verses.textLa: Melior est mors quam vita amara: et requies æterna quam languor perseverans.

verses.textEn: Good things hidden in a closed mouth are like seats at a feast placed around a grave.
verses.textLa: Bona abscondita in ore clauso, quasi appositiones epularum circumpositæ sepulchro.

verses.textEn: What benefit is there in an offering to an idol? For it can neither eat, nor smell.
verses.textLa: Quid proderit libatio idolo? Nec enim manducabit, nec odorabit:

verses.textEn: So is he who flees from the Lord, carrying the wages of his iniquity.
verses.textLa: Sic qui effugatur a Domino, portans mercedes iniquitatis:

verses.textEn: He sees with his eyes and groans, like a eunuch who embraces a virgin and sighs.
verses.textLa: videns oculis, et ingemiscens, sicut spado complectens virginem, et suspirans.

verses.textEn: You should not give your soul to sadness, and you should not afflict yourself by your own counsel.
verses.textLa: Tristitiam non des animæ tuæ, et non affligas temetipsum in consilio tuo.

verses.textEn: The gladness of the heart is the life of a man, and it is a treasure of sanctity without defect. And the exultation of a man is length of life.
verses.textLa: Iucunditas cordis hæc est vita hominis, et thesaurus sine defectione sanctitatis: et exultatio viri est longævitas.

verses.textEn: Take pity on your own soul by pleasing God, and show self-restraint. Gather your heart into his sanctity, and drive sadness far away from yourself.
verses.textLa: Miserere animæ tuæ placens Deo, et contine: congrega cor tuum in sanctitate eius, et tristitiam longe repelle a te.

verses.textEn: For sadness has killed many, and there is no usefulness in it.
verses.textLa: Multos enim occidit tristitia, et non est utilitas in illa.

verses.textEn: Envy and anger will diminish your days, and pensiveness will bring old age before its time.
verses.textLa: Zelus et iracundia minuunt dies, et ante tempus senectam adducet cogitatus.

verses.textEn: A cheerful and good heart is like a feast. And its feasts are formed by diligence.
verses.textLa: Splendidum cor, et bonum in epulis est: epulæ enim illius diligenter fiunt.

verses.textEn: Watching for wealth consumes the flesh, and thinking about it takes away sleep.
verses.textLa: Vigilia honestatis tabefaciet carnes, et cogitatus illius auferet somnum.

verses.textEn: Anticipation in thought distracts the mind, and a grievous infirmity makes the soul sober.
verses.textLa: Cogitatus præscientiæ avertit sensum, et infirmitas gravis sobriam facit animam.

verses.textEn: The rich man has labored in gathering wealth, and in his rest, he will be filled with his goods.
verses.textLa: Laboravit dives in congregatione substantiæ, et in requie sua replebitur bonis suis.

verses.textEn: The poor man has labored in his lowly way, and in the end, he may still be in need.
verses.textLa: Laboravit pauper in diminutione victus, et in fine inops fit.

verses.textEn: Whoever loves gold will not be justified. And whoever pursues consumption will be consumed by it.
verses.textLa: Qui aurum diligit, non iustificabitur: et qui insequitur consumptionem replebitur ex ea.

verses.textEn: Many have been caused to fall because of gold, and it became their ruin by its beauty.
verses.textLa: Multi dati sunt in auri casus, et facta est in specie ipsius perditio illorum.

verses.textEn: Gold is a stumbling block to those who sacrifice for it. Woe to those who pursue it eagerly, for all the imprudent will perish by it.
verses.textLa: Lignum offensionis est aurum sacrificantium: væ illis, qui sectantur illud, et omnis imprudens deperiet in illo.

verses.textEn: Blessed is the rich man who is found to be without blemish. And blessed is he who has not gone after gold, nor placed his hope in money or treasures.
verses.textLa: Beatus dives, qui inventus est sine macula: et qui post aurum non abiit, nec speravit in pecunia, et thesauris.

verses.textEn: Who is he? For we should praise him. For he has done wonderful things in his life.
verses.textLa: Quis est hic, et laudabimus eum? Fecit enim mirabilia in vita sua.

verses.textEn: He has been tested by it, and has become perfect; he will have eternal glory. He was able to transgress, but he has not transgressed. He was able to do evil, but he has not done evil.
verses.textLa: Qui probatus est in illo, et perfectus est, erit illi gloria æterna: qui potuit transgredi, et non est transgressus: facere mala, et non fecit:

verses.textEn: Therefore, his good things are established in the Lord, and the entire Church of the saints will proclaim his almsgiving.
verses.textLa: ideo stabilita sunt bona illius in Domino, et eleemosynas illius enarrabit omnis Ecclesia sanctorum.

verses.textEn: Are you seated at a great table? You should not open your mouth over it first.
verses.textLa: Supra mensam magnam sedisti? Non aperias super illam faucem tuam prior.

verses.textEn: You should not speak in this way: “There are many things that are upon it.”
verses.textLa: Non dicas sic: Multa sunt, quæ super illam sunt:

verses.textEn: Remember that a wicked eye is evil.
verses.textLa: memento quoniam malus est oculus nequam.

verses.textEn: What has been made more wicked than the eye? Therefore, when it sees, it will shed tears over the entire face.
verses.textLa: Nequius oculo quid creatum est? Ideo ab omni facie sua lacrymabitur, cum viderit:

verses.textEn: You should not extend your hand first, for then, having been corrupted by envy, you would be ashamed.
verses.textLa: ne extendas manum tuam prior, et invidia contaminatus erubescas.

verses.textEn: You should not press forward at a feast.
verses.textLa: Ne comprimaris in convivio.

verses.textEn: Understand which things are your neighbor’s and not your own.
verses.textLa: Intellige quæ sunt proximi tui ex teipso:

verses.textEn: Make use of the things that are set before you, just as a frugal man would. Otherwise, if you eat much, you will be hated.
verses.textLa: utere quasi homo frugi his, quæ tibi apponuntur: ne, cum manducas multum, odio habearis.

verses.textEn: Cease eating first, for the sake of discipline. And do not eat to excess, lest you offend.
verses.textLa: Cessa prior causa disciplinæ: et noli nimius esse, ne forte offendas.

verses.textEn: And if you sit in the midst of many, you should not extend your hand before they do, and you should not be the first to ask for a drink.
verses.textLa: Et si in medio multorum sedisti, prior illis ne extendas manum tuam, nec prior poscas bibere.

verses.textEn: How sufficient is a little wine for a well-taught man! For in sleep, you will not labor because of it, and you will not feel pain.
verses.textLa: Quam sufficens est homini eruditio vinum exiguum, et in dormiendo non laborabis ab illo, et non senties dolorem.

verses.textEn: Worry, and disease, and torment are with an intemperate man.
verses.textLa: Vigilia, cholera, et tortura viro infrunito:

verses.textEn: A healthy sleep is with a temperate man. He will sleep until morning, and his soul will be delighted with him.
verses.textLa: somnus sanitatis in homine parco. Dormiet usque mane, et anima illius cum ipso delectabitur.

verses.textEn: And if you have been coaxed into eating too much, rise up, go outside, and vomit. And it will refresh you, and you will not bring sickness upon your body.
verses.textLa: Et si coactus fueris in edendo multum, surge e medio, evome: et refrigerabit te, et non adduces corpori tuo infirmitatem.

verses.textEn: Listen to me, son, for you should not spurn me. And in the very end, you will discover my words.
verses.textLa: Audi me fili, et ne spernas me: et in novissimo invenies verba mea.

verses.textEn: In all your works, be prompt, and then no infirmity will befall you.
verses.textLa: In omnibus operibus tuis esto velox, et omnis infirmitas non occurret tibi.

verses.textEn: The lips of many will bless the splendid in bread. For the testimony of his truthfulness is faithful.
verses.textLa: Splendidum in panibus benedicent labia multorum, et testimonium veritatis illius fidele.

verses.textEn: The city will murmur against the wicked in bread. For the testimony against his wickedness is true.
verses.textLa: Nequissimo in pane murmurabit civitas, et testimonium nequitiæ illius verum est.

verses.textEn: Do not choose to provoke those who love wine. For wine has destroyed many.
verses.textLa: Diligentes in vino noli provocare: multos enim exterminavit vinum.

verses.textEn: Fire tests the hardness of iron; similarly, drinking wine to inebriation will rebuke the hearts of the arrogant.
verses.textLa: Ignis probat ferrum durum: sic vinum corda superborum arguet in ebrietate potatum.

verses.textEn: Drinking wine in sobriety gives a contented life to men. If you drink it in moderation, you will be sober.
verses.textLa: Æqua vita hominibus vinum in sobrietate: si bibas illud moderate, eris sobrius.

verses.textEn: What is life to him who is diminished by wine?
verses.textLa: Quæ vita est ei, qui minuitur vino?

verses.textEn: What can cheat him of his life? Death.
verses.textLa: Quid defraudat vitam? Mors.

verses.textEn: From the beginning, wine was created for cheerfulness, but not for inebriation.
verses.textLa: Vinum in iucunditatem creatum est, et non in ebrietatem, ab initio.

verses.textEn: Wine taken in moderation lifts up the mind and the heart.
verses.textLa: Exultatio animæ et cordis vinum moderate potatum.

verses.textEn: Sober drinking is healthful to mind and body.
verses.textLa: Sanitas est animæ et corpori sobrius potus.

verses.textEn: Wine taken in excess stirs up conflict and anger, and brings many to ruin.
verses.textLa: Vinum multum potatum irritationem, et iram, et ruinas multas facit.

verses.textEn: Wine taken in excess is bitter to the soul.
verses.textLa: Amaritudo animæ vinum multum potatum.

verses.textEn: The effects of inebriation are a stumbling block to the imprudent, diminishing strength and causing wounds.
verses.textLa: Ebrietatis animositas, imprudentis offensio, minorans virtutem, et faciens vulnera.

verses.textEn: You should not argue with your neighbor during a banquet of wine. And you should not spurn him in his cheerfulness.
verses.textLa: In convivio vini non arguas proximum: et non despicias eum in iucunditate illius:

verses.textEn: You should not speak words of reproach to him. And you should not press him with repeated requests.
verses.textLa: verba improperii non dicas illi: et non premas illum repetendo.

verses.textEn: Have they appointed you as a leader? Do not be willing to be extolled. Be among them as one of them.
verses.textLa: Rectorem te posuerunt? Noli extolli: esto in illis quasi unus ex ipsis.

verses.textEn: Have concern for them, and in this way sit down with them, and when you have explained all your concerns, sit back.
verses.textLa: Curam illorum habe, et sic conside, et omni cura tua explicita recumbe:

verses.textEn: Then you may rejoice because of them, and you may receive a crown as an adornment of grace, and so obtain the dignity of the assembly.
verses.textLa: ut læteris propter illos, et ornamentum gratiæ accipias coronam, et dignationem consequaris corrogationis.

verses.textEn: Speak, you who are greater by birth. For it is fitting for you
verses.textLa: Loquere maior natu: decet enim te

verses.textEn: to speak the first word with careful knowledge. But you should not hinder the music.
verses.textLa: primum verbum diligenti scientia, et non impedias musicam.

verses.textEn: Where no one is listening, you should not pour out words. And do not choose to be extolled improperly for your wisdom.
verses.textLa: Ubi auditus non est, non effundas sermonem, et importune noli extolli in sapientia tua.

verses.textEn: A gemstone of garnet is set amid an ornament of gold, and a concert of music is set amid a banquet of wine.
verses.textLa: Gemmula carbunculi in ornamento auri, et comparatio musicorum in convivio vini.

verses.textEn: Just as a signet of emerald is set amid a work of gold, so is a melody of music set amid delightful and moderate wine.
verses.textLa: Sicut in fabricatione auri signum est smaragdi, sic numerus musicorum in iucundo et moderato vino.

verses.textEn: Listen silently, and for your reverence, good graces will be added to you.
verses.textLa: Audi tacens, et pro reverentia accedet tibi bona gratia.

verses.textEn: Young man, speak in your own case only reluctantly.
verses.textLa: Adolescens loquere in tua causa vix.

verses.textEn: If you have been asked twice, let your response be concise.
verses.textLa: Si bis interrogatus fueris, habeat caput responsum tuum.

verses.textEn: In many matters, be as if you lack knowledge, and listen silently as well as intently.
verses.textLa: In multis esto quasi inscius, et audi tacens simul et quærens.

verses.textEn: In the midst of great men, you should not be presumptuous. And where the elders are present, you should not speak much.
verses.textLa: In medio magnatorum non præsumas: et ubi sunt senes, non multum loquaris.

verses.textEn: Lightning goes before a hailstorm, and grace goes before modesty. And so, for your reverence, good graces will be added to you.
verses.textLa: Ante grandinem præibit coruscatio: et ante verecundiam præibit gratia, et pro reverentia accedet tibi bona gratia.

verses.textEn: And at the hour for rising, you should not be lax. Later, be the first to run ahead to your house, and there withdraw, and there take your pastime.
verses.textLa: Et hora surgendi non te trices: præcurre autem prior in domum tuam, et illic avocare, et illic lude,

verses.textEn: And act according to your intentions, but not in sin and not in arrogant speech.
verses.textLa: et age conceptiones tuas, et non in delictis et verbo superbo.

verses.textEn: And for all these things, bless the Lord, who made you, and who fills you to overflowing with all his good things.
verses.textLa: Et super his omnibus benedicito Dominum, qui fecit te, et inebriantem te ab omnibus bonis suis.

verses.textEn: Whoever fears the Lord will accept his doctrine. And whoever watches for him diligently will find a blessing.
verses.textLa: Qui timet Dominum, excipiet doctrinam eius: et qui vigilaverint ad illum, invenient benedictionem.

verses.textEn: Whoever seeks the law will be filled from the law. But whoever acts with treachery will be scandalized by treachery.
verses.textLa: Qui quærit legem, replebitur ab ea: et qui insidiose agit, scandalizabitur in ea.

verses.textEn: Those who fear the Lord will find just judgment, and they will kindle justice like a light.
verses.textLa: Qui timent Dominum, invenient iudicium iustum, et iustitias quasi lumen accendent.

verses.textEn: A sinful man will shun correction, and he will find a rationalization in accord with his own will.
verses.textLa: Peccator homo vitabit correptionem, et secundum voluntatem suam inveniet comparationem.

verses.textEn: A man of counsel will not reject understanding. A strange and arrogant man will not be disturbed by fear.
verses.textLa: Vir consilii non disperdet intelligentiam, alienus et superbus non pertimescet timorem:

verses.textEn: Even so, after he has acted out of fear and without counsel, he will be rebuked by his own criticism.
verses.textLa: etiam postquam fecit cum eo sine consilio, et suis insectationibus arguetur.

verses.textEn: Son, you should do nothing without counsel, and then you will not regret what you have done.
verses.textLa: Fili sine consilio nihil facias, et post factum non pœnitebis.

verses.textEn: You should not go into the way of ruin, and you then will not stumble on stones. You should not commit yourself to a laborious way; otherwise, you may set up a scandal against your own soul.
verses.textLa: In via ruinæ non eas, et non offendes in lapides: nec credas te viæ laboriosæ, ne ponas animæ tuæ scandalum:

verses.textEn: And be cautious concerning your own sons. And be attentive to those of your own household.
verses.textLa: et a filiis tuis cave, et a domesticis tuis attende.

verses.textEn: In all of your works, trust your soul to faith. For this is the keeping of the commandments.
verses.textLa: In omni opere tuo crede ex fide animæ tuæ: hoc est enim conservatio mandatorum.

verses.textEn: Whoever believes God attends to the commandments. And whoever trusts in him will not be diminished.
verses.textLa: Qui credit Deo, attendit mandatis: et qui confidit in illo, non minorabitur.

verses.textEn: No evils will befall one who fears the Lord. Instead, God will preserve him during temptation and will free him from evils.
verses.textLa: Timenti Dominum non occurrent mala, sed in tentatione Deus illum conservabit, et liberabit a malis.

verses.textEn: A wise man does not hate the commandments and the justices, and so he will not be thrown about violently, like a ship in a storm.
verses.textLa: Sapiens non odit mandata et iustitias, et non illidetur quasi in procella navis.

verses.textEn: A man of understanding puts his faith in the law of God, and so the law is faithful to him.
verses.textLa: Homo sensatus credit legi Dei, et lex illi fidelis.

verses.textEn: Whoever would resolve a dispute will prepare a word, and so, having prayed, he will be heard. And he will observe discipline, and then he will respond.
verses.textLa: Qui interrogationem manifestat, parabit verbum, et sic deprecatus exaudietur, et conservabit disciplinam, et tunc respondebit.

verses.textEn: The heart of a fool is like the wheel of a cart. And his thoughts are like a turning axel.
verses.textLa: Præcordia fatui quasi rota carri: et quasi axis versatilis cogitatus illius.

verses.textEn: A friend who is a whisperer is like an untamed horse: he neighs under anyone who sits upon him.
verses.textLa: Equus emissarius, sic et amicus subsannator, sub omni suprasedente hinnit.
verses.notes: The word ‘emissarius’ literally refers to something that his sent away, but in this context it refers to something that is uncontrollable or unmanageable.

verses.textEn: Why does day follow after day, and light follow after light, and year follow after year, in accord with the sun?
verses.textLa: Quare dies diem superat, et iterum lux lucem, et annus annum a sole?

verses.textEn: By the knowledge of the Lord, they were arranged, after the sun was made, in keeping with his command.
verses.textLa: A Domini scientia separati sunt, facto sole, et præceptum custodiente.

verses.textEn: And so, the seasons changed, with their feast days. And according to them, they celebrated the feast days, in their hour.
verses.textLa: Et immutavit tempora, et dies festos ipsorum, et in illis dies festos celebraverunt ad horam.

verses.textEn: Some of them, God exalted and magnified. And some of them, he set amid the ordinary days. And all men are from the ground, and from the earth, from which Adam was created.
verses.textLa: Ex ipsis exaltavit et magnificavit Deus, et ex ipsis posuit in numerum dierum. Et omnes homines de solo, et ex terra, unde creatus est Adam.

verses.textEn: With a multitude of disciplines, the Lord has distinguished them and diversified their ways.
verses.textLa: In multitudine disciplinæ Dominus separavit eos, et immutavit vias eorum.

verses.textEn: Some of them, he has blessed and exalted. And some of them he has sanctified and placed close to himself. And some of them, he has cursed and brought low, and he has turned them from their station.
verses.textLa: Ex ipsis benedixit, et exaltavit: et ex ipsis sanctificavit, et ad se applicavit: et ex ipsis maledixit, et humiliavit, et convertit illos a separatione ipsorum.

verses.textEn: Just as the clay is in the potter’s hand, so as to form and to shape it,
verses.textLa: Quasi lutum figuli in manu ipsius, plasmare illud et disponere.

verses.textEn: so are all his ways in accord with his dispensation, and so is man in the hand of the One who made him. And he will repay him according to his judgment.
verses.textLa: Omnes viæ eius secundum dispositionem eius: sic homo in manu illius, qui se fecit, et reddet illi secundum iudicium suum.

verses.textEn: Good is against evil, and life is against death; so also is a sinner against a just man. And so should you consider all the works of the Most High: two and two, and one against another.
verses.textLa: Contra malum bonum est, et contra mortem vita: sic et contra virum iustum peccator. Et sic intuere in omnia opera Altissimi. Duo et duo, et unum contra unum.

verses.textEn: And I awakened at the very end, and I was like one who gathers grapes after the grape-gatherers.
verses.textLa: Et ego novissimus evigilavi, et quasi qui colligit acinos post vindemiatores.

verses.textEn: I, too, have hoped in the blessing of God. And I have filled the winepress like one who gathers grapes.
verses.textLa: In benedictione Dei et ipse speravi: et quasi qui vindemiat, replevi torcular.

verses.textEn: Consider how I have not labored for myself alone, but for all who are seeking discipline.
verses.textLa: Respicite quoniam non mihi soli laboravi, sed omnibus exquirentibus disciplinam.

verses.textEn: Listen to me, you great ones, with all the peoples. And incline your ears, you rulers of the Church.
verses.textLa: Audite me magnates, et omnes populi, et rectores Ecclesiæ auribus percipite.

verses.textEn: You should not give authority over yourself to a son or wife, to a brother or friend, in your life. And you should not give your estate to another, lest perhaps you may regret it, and then you would be begging for the same.
verses.textLa: Filio et mulieri, fratri et amico non des potestatem super te in vita tua: et non dederis alii possessionem tuam: ne forte pœniteat te, et depreceris pro illis.
verses.notes: The leaders of the Church should not give up their authority to another, lest they bitterly regret it.

verses.textEn: While you are still living and breathing, let no one among all flesh change you.
verses.textLa: Dum adhuc superes et aspiras, non immutabit te omnis caro.

verses.textEn: For it is better if your children petition you, than if you look toward the hands of your children.
verses.textLa: Melius est enim ut filii tui te rogent, quam te respicere in manus filiorum tuorum.

verses.textEn: In all your works, be pre-eminent.
verses.textLa: In omnibus operibus tuis præcellens esto.

verses.textEn: You should not allow a blemish upon your glory. On the day of the consummation of the days of your life, at the time of your passing, distribute your inheritance.
verses.textLa: Ne dederis maculam in gloria tua. In die consummationis dierum vitæ tuæ, et in tempore exitus tui distribue hereditatem tuam.

verses.textEn: Fodder and a rod and a burden are for a donkey; bread and discipline and work are for a servant.
verses.textLa: Cibaria, et virga, et onus asino: panis, et disciplina, et opus servo.

verses.textEn: He works under discipline, and he seeks rest. Allow his hands to be idle, and he seeks liberty.
verses.textLa: Operatur in disciplina, et quærit requiescere: laxa manus illi, et quærit libertatem.

verses.textEn: The yoke and the strap bend a stiff neck, and continual labors bend a servant.
verses.textLa: Iugum et lorum curvant collum durum, et servum inclinant operationes assiduæ.

verses.textEn: Torture and chains are for a malevolent servant; send him to work, so that he may not be idle.
