verses.textLa: Servo malevolo tortura et compedes, mitte illum in operationem, ne vacet:

verses.textEn: For idleness has taught much evil.
verses.textLa: multam enim malitiam docuit otiositas.

verses.textEn: Appoint him to a task. For this is fitting for him. And if he will not be obedient, bend him with chains. But you should do no more than any flesh can bear. Truly, you should do nothing grievous without judgment.
verses.textLa: In opera constitue eum: sic enim condecet illum. Quod si non obaudierit, curva illum compedibus, et non amplifices super omnem carnem: verum sine iudicio nihil facias grave.

verses.textEn: If you have a faithful servant, let him be to you like your own soul. Treat him like a brother. For you have obtained him by the blood of your soul.
verses.textLa: Si est tibi servus fidelis, sit tibi quasi anima tua: quasi fratrem sic eum tracta: quoniam in sanguine animæ comparasti illum.

verses.textEn: If you harm him unjustly, he will turn away and flee.
verses.textLa: Si læseris eum iniuste, in fugam convertetur:

verses.textEn: And then, when he lifts himself up and departs, you will not know whom to ask, or in what way to seek him.
verses.textLa: et si extollens discesserit: quem quæras, et in qua via quæras illum, nescis.

verses.textEn: The hopes of a senseless man are empty and false; and dreams extol the imprudent.
verses.textLa: Vana spes, et mendacium viro insensato: et somnia extollunt imprudentes.

verses.textEn: Like one who chases a shadow and pursues the wind, so also is one who pays attention to lying visions.
verses.textLa: Quasi qui apprehendit umbram, et persequitur ventum: sic et qui attendit ad visa mendacia.

verses.textEn: In the vision of dreams, one thing represents another, as when a mask is before the face of a man.
verses.textLa: Hoc secundum hoc visio somniorum: ante faciem hominis similitudo hominis.

verses.textEn: What can be cleansed by the unclean? And what truth can be spoken from a lie?
verses.textLa: Ab immundo quid mundabitur? Et a mendace quid verum dicetur?

verses.textEn: Erroneous divinations and false signs and the dreams of evildoers are emptiness.
verses.textLa: Divinatio erroris, et auguria mendacia, et somnia malefacientium, vanitas est.

verses.textEn: For your heart suffers from imagination, like a woman suffering in childbirth. Unless it is a visitation sent from the Most High, you should not set your heart upon it.
verses.textLa: Et sicut parturientis, cor tuum phantasias patitur. Nisi ab Altissimo fuerit emissa visitatio, ne dederis in illis cor tuum:

verses.textEn: For dreams have caused many to go astray, and those who have hoped in them have fallen away.
verses.textLa: multos enim errare fecerunt somnia, et exciderunt sperantes in illis.

verses.textEn: The word of the law will be fulfilled without a lie, and wisdom will be made plain in the mouths of the faithful.
verses.textLa: Sine mendacio consummabitur verbum legis, et sapientia in ore fidelis complanabitur.

verses.textEn: He who has not been tested, what does he know? A man with much experience will consider many things. And whoever has learned much will explain with understanding.
verses.textLa: Qui non est tentatus, quid scit? Vir in multis expertus, cogitabit multa: et qui multa didicit, enarrabit intellectum.

verses.textEn: He who has no experience knows little. And he who has done many things has made many mistakes.
verses.textLa: Qui non est expertus, pauca recognoscit: qui autem in multis factus est, multiplicat malitiam.
verses.notes: In the context of a passage extolling the benefits of experience, the word ‘malitiam’ refers to faults, not to wickedness. Experience brings wisdom, but who can be free from fault who has much experience?

verses.textEn: He who has not been tested, what kind of things can he know? He who has been deceived will be more cunning.
verses.textLa: Qui tentatus non est, qualia scit? Qui implanatus est, abundabit nequitia.

verses.textEn: I have seen much by wandering, and the customs of many things.
verses.textLa: Multa vidi errando, et plurimas verborum consuetudines.

verses.textEn: At times, I have even been in danger of death because of these things, but I was freed by the grace of God.
verses.textLa: Aliquoties usque ad mortem periclitatus sum horum causa, et liberatus sum gratia Dei.

verses.textEn: The spirit of those who fear God is sought, and they will be blessed by his providence.
verses.textLa: Spiritus timentium Deum quæritur, et in respectu illius benedicetur.

verses.textEn: For their hope is in him who saves them, and the eyes of God are on those who love him.
verses.textLa: Spes enim illorum in salvantem illos, et oculi Dei in diligentes se.

verses.textEn: Those who fear the Lord will tremble at nothing, and they will not be terrified. For he is their hope.
verses.textLa: Qui timet Dominum nihil trepidabit, et non pavebit: quoniam ipse est spes eius.

verses.textEn: The soul of him who fears the Lord is blessed.
verses.textLa: Timentis Dominum beata est anima eius.

verses.textEn: To whom should he look, and who is his strength?
verses.textLa: Ad quem respicit, et quis est fortitudo eius?

verses.textEn: The eyes of the Lord are upon those who fear him. He is a powerful Protector, a Firmament of virtue, a Shelter from the heat, and a Covering from the midday sun,
verses.textLa: Oculi Domini super timentes eum, protector potentiæ, firmamentum virtutis, tegimen ardoris, et umbraculum meridiani,

verses.textEn: a Guardian from offenses, and a Helper from falling, who exalts the soul and illuminates the eyes, and who gives health and life and blessing.
verses.textLa: deprecatio offensionis, et adiutorium casus, exaltans animam, et illuminans oculos, dans sanitatem, et vitam et benedictionem.

verses.textEn: An immolation from iniquity is a stained oblation, and the derisions of the unjust are not well pleasing.
verses.textLa: Immolantis ex iniquo oblatio est maculata, et non sunt beneplacitæ subsannationes iniustorum.

verses.textEn: The Lord is only for those who persevere for him in the way of truth and justice.
verses.textLa: Dominus solus sustinentibus se in via veritatis et iustitiæ.

verses.textEn: The Most High does not approve of the gifts of the iniquitous. Neither does he have respect for the oblations of the unjust; neither will he forgive their sins because of the multitude of their sacrifices.
verses.textLa: Dona iniquorum non probat Altissimus, nec respicit in oblationes iniquorum: nec in multitudine sacrificiorum eorum propitiabitur peccatis.

verses.textEn: Whoever offers a sacrifice from the substance of the poor is like one who sacrifices the son in the sight of his father.
verses.textLa: Qui offert sacrificium ex substantia pauperum, quasi qui victimat filium in conspectu patris sui.

verses.textEn: The bread of the indigent is the life of the poor. Whoever cheats them out of it is a man of blood.
verses.textLa: Panis egentium vita pauperum est: qui defraudat illum, homo sanguinis est.

verses.textEn: Whoever takes away the bread of sweat is like one who kills his neighbor.
verses.textLa: Qui aufert in sudore panem, quasi qui occidit proximum suum.

verses.textEn: He who sheds blood, and he who cheats the hired hand out of his wages, are brothers.
verses.textLa: Qui effundit sanguinem, et qui fraudem facit mercenario, fratres sunt.

verses.textEn: When one builds and another destroys, what benefit do they have from their labor?
verses.textLa: Unus ædificans, et unus destruens: quid prodest illis nisi labor?

verses.textEn: When one prays and another curses, whose voice will God heed?
verses.textLa: Unus orans, et unus maledicens: cuius vocem exaudiet Deus?

verses.textEn: He who washes himself after touching the dead, and then touches him again, what was the benefit of his washing?
verses.textLa: Qui baptizatur a mortuo, et iterum tangit eum, quid proficit lavatio illius?

verses.textEn: Similarly, a man who fasts for his sins, and then does the same again, what was the benefit of his humbling himself? Who will heed his prayer?
verses.textLa: Sic homo qui ieiunat in peccatis suis: et iterum eadem faciens, quid proficit humiliando se? Orationem illius quis exaudiet?

verses.textEn: Whoever observes the law multiplies oblations.
verses.textLa: Qui conservat legem, multiplicat oblationem.

verses.textEn: It is a salutary sacrifice to attend to the commandments and to withdraw from all iniquity.
verses.textLa: Sacrificium salutare est attendere mandatis, et discedere ab omni iniquitate.

verses.textEn: And to depart from injustice is to offer a propitiatory sacrifice for injustices and a supplication for sins.
verses.textLa: Et propitiationem litare sacrificii super iniustitias, et deprecatio pro peccatis, recedere ab iniustitia.

verses.textEn: Whoever gives thanks, offers a gift of fine flour, and whoever acts with mercy, offers a sacrifice.
verses.textLa: Retribuet gratiam qui offert similaginem: et qui facit misericordiam, offert sacrificium.

verses.textEn: To withdraw from iniquity is well-pleasing to the Lord. And to withdraw from injustice is a supplication for sins.
verses.textLa: Beneplacitum est Domino recedere ab iniquitate: et deprecatio pro peccatis recedere ab iniustitia.

verses.textEn: You should not appear empty before the sight of the Lord.
verses.textLa: Non apparebis ante conspectum Domini vacuus.

verses.textEn: For all these things are to be done because of the commandment of God.
verses.textLa: Hæc enim omnia propter mandatum Dei fiunt.

verses.textEn: The oblation of the just fattens the altar, and is a fragrance of sweetness in the sight of the Most High.
verses.textLa: Oblatio iusti impinguat altare, et odor suavitatis est in conspectu Altissimi.

verses.textEn: The sacrifice of the just is acceptable, and the Lord will never forget the memorial of it.
verses.textLa: Sacrificium iusti acceptum est, et memoriam eius non obliviscetur Dominus.

verses.textEn: Render glory to God with a good heart. And you should not reduce the first-fruits of your hands.
verses.textLa: Bono animo gloriam redde Deo: et non minuas primitias manuum tuarum.

verses.textEn: With every gift, have a cheerful countenance, and sanctify your tithes with exultation.
verses.textLa: In omni dato hilarem fac vultum tuum, et in exultatione sanctifica decimas tuas.

verses.textEn: Give to the Most High according to his gifts to you, and act with a good eye toward the creations of your hands.
verses.textLa: Da Altissimo secundum datum eius, et in bono oculo adinventionem facito manuum tuarum:

verses.textEn: For the Lord gives recompense, and he will repay you seven times as much.
verses.textLa: quoniam Dominus retribuens est, et septies tantum reddet tibi.

verses.textEn: Do not be willing to offer corrupt gifts. For he will not accept them.
verses.textLa: Noli offerre munera prava, non enim suscipiet illa.

verses.textEn: And do not be willing to consider an unjust sacrifice. For the Lord is the judge, and with him there is no favoritism toward anyone.
verses.textLa: Et noli inspicere sacrificum iniustum, quoniam Dominus iudex est, et non est apud illum gloria personæ.

verses.textEn: The Lord will not accept favoritism against the poor, but he will heed the prayer of one who has been harmed.
verses.textLa: Non accipiet Dominus personam in pauperem, et deprecationem læsi exaudiet.

verses.textEn: He will not despise the prayers of the orphan, nor of the widow, if she utters a lamenting complaint.
verses.textLa: Non despiciet preces pupilli: nec viduam, si effundat loquelam gemitus.

verses.textEn: Do a widow’s tears not run down her cheek? And will her outcry not cause their downfall?
verses.textLa: Nonne lacrymæ viduæ ad maxillam descendunt, et exclamatio eius super deducentem eas?

verses.textEn: For from her cheek, her tears ascend even to heaven. And the Lord, the One who listens, will not take delight in them.
verses.textLa: A maxilla enim ascendunt usque ad cælum, et Dominus exauditor non delectabitur in illis.

verses.textEn: Whoever adores God with joy will be accepted, and his prayer will reach even to the clouds.
verses.textLa: Qui adorat Deum in oblectatione suscipietur, et deprecatio illius usque ad nubes propinquabit.

verses.textEn: The prayer of one who humbles himself will pierce the clouds. And it will not be consoled until it draws near; and it will not withdraw until the Most High beholds.
verses.textLa: Oratio humiliantis se, nubes penetrabit: et donec propinquet non consolabitur: et non discedet donec Altissimus aspiciat.

verses.textEn: And the Lord will not delay, and he will judge for those who are just, and he will accomplish judgment. And the Almighty will not have patience with them, so that he may crush their back.
verses.textLa: Et Dominus non elongabit, et iudicabit iustos, et faciet iudicium: et Fortissimus non habebit in illis patientiam, ut contribulet dorsum ipsorum:

verses.textEn: And he will repay vengeance to the Gentiles, until he has taken away the multitude of the arrogant, and broken the scepters of the iniquitous,
verses.textLa: et Gentibus reddet vindictam donec tollat plenitudinem superborum: et sceptra iniquorum contribulet,

verses.textEn: until he has rendered to men according to their deeds, and according to the works of Adam, and according to his presumption,
verses.textLa: donec reddat hominibus secundum actus suos, et secundum opera Adæ, et secundum præsumptionem illius,

verses.textEn: until he has judged the judgment of his people. And he will delight the just with his mercy.
verses.textLa: donec iudicet iudicium plebis suæ, et oblectabit iustos misericordia sua.

verses.textEn: The mercy of God is beautiful in the time of tribulation, like a rain cloud in the time of drought.
verses.textLa: Speciosa misericordia Dei, in tempore tribulationis, quasi nubes pluviæ in tempore siccitatis.

verses.textEn: O God of all, take pity on us, and look with favor on us, and show us the light of your compassion.
verses.textLa: Miserere nostri Deus omnium, et respice nos, et ostende nobis lucem miserationum tuarum:

verses.textEn: And send your fear upon the Gentiles, who have not sought you, so that they may acknowledge that there is no God except you, and so that they may declare your great deeds.
verses.textLa: et immitte timorem tuum super Gentes, quæ non exquisierunt te, ut cognoscant quia non est Deus nisi tu, et enarrent magnalia tua.

verses.textEn: Lift up your hand over unbelieving nations, so that they may see your power.
verses.textLa: Alleva manum tuam super gentes alienas, ut videant potentiam tuam.
verses.notes: The word ‘gentes’ in this context refers to those who are unbelieving; in the context of the Jews of Old Testament times, this would refer to non-Jews, but in the context of the present-day, this would refer to non-Catholic, especially non-Christians. The word ‘alienas’ is often translated as strangers or foreigners, but here it refers more to nations or peoples other than those who believe.

verses.textEn: For just as, in their sight, you have been sanctified in us, so also, in our sight, you will be magnified in them.
verses.textLa: Sicut enim in conspectu eorum sanctificatus es in nobis, sic in conspectu nostro magnificaberis in eis,

verses.textEn: So may they know you, as we also have known you. For there is no God apart from you, O Lord.
verses.textLa: ut cognoscant te, sicut et nos cognovimus quoniam non est Deus præter te Domine.

verses.textEn: Renew your signs, and work new wonders.
verses.textLa: Innova signa, et immuta mirabilia.

verses.textEn: Glorify your hand and your right arm.
verses.textLa: Glorifica manum, et brachium dextrum.

verses.textEn: Stir up your fury, and pour out your wrath.
verses.textLa: Excita furorem, et effunde iram.

verses.textEn: Take away our adversary, and afflict our enemy.
verses.textLa: Tolle adversarium, et afflige inimicum.

verses.textEn: Hasten the time, and remember the end, so that they may declare your miracles.
verses.textLa: Festina tempus, et memento finis, ut enarrent mirabilia tua.

verses.textEn: Let those who escape be devoured by the wrath of fire. And let those who harass your people find perdition.
verses.textLa: In ira flammæ devoretur qui salvatur: et qui pessimant plebem tuam, inveniant perditionem.

verses.textEn: Crush the head of the leaders of the enemies, for they say: “There is no other beside us.”
verses.textLa: Contere caput principum inimicorum, dicentium: Non est alius præter nos.

verses.textEn: Gather together all the tribes of Jacob, so that they may acknowledge that there is no God except you, and so that they may declare your great deeds. And you will inherit them, as from the beginning.
verses.textLa: Congrega omnes tribus Iacob: ut cognoscant quia non est Deus nisi tu, et enarrent magnalia tua: et hereditabis eos, sicut ab initio.

verses.textEn: Take pity on your people, over whom your name has been invoked, and on Israel, whom you have treated as your firstborn.
verses.textLa: Miserere plebi tuæ, super quam invocatum est nomen tuum: et Israel, quem coæquasti primogenito tuo.

verses.textEn: Take pity on Jerusalem, the city of your sanctification, the city of your rest.
verses.textLa: Miserere civitati sanctificationis tuæ Ierusalem, civitati requiei tuæ.

verses.textEn: Fill Zion with your ineffable words, and fill your people with your glory.
verses.textLa: Reple Sion inenarrabilibus verbis tuis, et gloria tua populum tuum.

verses.textEn: Give testimony to those who have been your creations from the beginning, and lift up the prophecies which the former prophets spoke in your name.
verses.textLa: Da testimonium his, qui ab initio creaturæ tuæ sunt, et suscita prædicationes, quas locuti sunt in nomine tuo prophetæ priores.

verses.textEn: Give a reward to those who endure for you, so that your prophets may be found to be faithful. And heed the prayers of your servants,
verses.textLa: Da mercedem sustinentibus te, ut prophetæ tui fideles inveniantur: et exaudi orationes servorum tuorum

verses.textEn: in accord with the blessing of Aaron over your people. And direct us in the way of justice, and let all who inhabit the earth know that you are God, the Beholder of all ages.
verses.textLa: secundum benedictionem Aaron de populo tuo, et dirige nos in viam iustitiæ, et sciant omnes qui habitant terram, quia tu es Deus conspector sæculorum.

verses.textEn: The belly can devour any food, yet one meal is better than another.
verses.textLa: Omnem escam manducabit venter, et est cibus cibo melior.

verses.textEn: The palate tests the meat of wild animals, and the understanding heart tests false words.
verses.textLa: Fauces contingunt cibum feræ, et cor sensatum verba mendacia.

verses.textEn: A corrupt heart will cause grief, and a man of experience will resist it.
verses.textLa: Cor pravum dabit tristitiam, et homo peritus resistet illi.

verses.textEn: A woman can receive any male, yet one daughter is better than another.
verses.textLa: Omnem masculum excipiet mulier: et est filia melior filia.

verses.textEn: The beauty of a wife cheers the face of her husband, and rises above his desire, above all the desires of man.
verses.textLa: Species mulieris exhilarat faciem viri sui, et super omnem concupiscentiam hominis superducit desiderium.

verses.textEn: If she offers healing words, then she both comforts and shows mercy; and so her husband is not like other men.
verses.textLa: Si est lingua curationis, est et mitigationis et misericordiæ: non est vir illius secundum filios hominum.

verses.textEn: He who holds to a good wife establishes a possession. She is a helper in agreement with him, and she is a pillar of rest.
verses.textLa: Qui possidet mulierem bonam, inchoat possessionem: adiutorium secundum illum est, et columna ut requies.

verses.textEn: Where there is no hedge, a possession will be trampled. And where there is no wife, he will mourn her absence.
verses.textLa: Ubi non est sepes, diripietur possessio: et ubi non est mulier, ingemiscit egens.

verses.textEn: Who will trust one who has no nest, and who conceals himself wherever his course may take him, like a well-equipped robber passing from city to city?
verses.textLa: Quis credit ei, qui non habet nidum, et deflectens ubicumque obscuraverit, quasi succinctus latro exiliens de civitate in civitatem?

verses.textEn: Every friend will say: “I also am a close friend.” But there is a friend who is a friend in name only. Is this not a grief even unto death?
verses.textLa: Omnis amicus dicet: Et ego amicitiam copulavi. Sed est amicus solo nomine amicus. Nonne tristitia inest usque ad mortem?

verses.textEn: But a companion and friend may turn into an enemy.
verses.textLa: Sodalis autem et amicus ad inimicitiam convertentur.

verses.textEn: O wicked presumption! From what were you created that you would cover the dry land with your malice and deceitfulness?
verses.textLa: O præsumptio nequissima, unde create es cooperire aridam malitia, et dolositate illius?

verses.textEn: A companion may rejoice with his friend in good times, but in a time of tribulation, he will be an adversary.
verses.textLa: Sodalis amico coniucundatur in oblectationibus, et in tempore tribulationis adversarius erit.

verses.textEn: There is a companion who commiserates with a friend for the sake of the stomach, but he will shield himself from the enemy.
verses.textLa: Sodalis amico condolet causa ventris, et contra hostem accipiet scutum.

verses.textEn: You should not forget your friend in your soul, and you should not be unmindful of him in your wealth.
verses.textLa: Non obliviscaris amici tui in animo tuo, et non immemor sis illius in opibus tuis.

verses.textEn: Do not choose to consult with someone who waits in ambush for you. And hide your counsel from those who rival you.
verses.textLa: Noli consiliari cum eo, qui tibi insidiatur, et a zelantibus te absconde consilium.

verses.textEn: Every counselor offers advice, but some are counselors only for themselves.
verses.textLa: Omnis consiliarius prodit consilium, sed est consiliarius in semetipso.

verses.textEn: Guard your soul from a counselor. And know beforehand what his interests are. For he will form thoughts from his own soul.
verses.textLa: A consiliario serva animam tuam. Prius scito quæ sit illius necessitas: et ipse enim animo suo cogitabit:

verses.textEn: Otherwise, he may set a signpost in the ground, and he may say to you:
verses.textLa: ne forte mittat sudem in terram, et dicat tibi:

verses.textEn: “Your own way is good.” But then he will stand at a distance to see what befalls you.
verses.textLa: Bona est via tua; et stet e contrario videre quid tibi eveniat.

verses.textEn: Do not discuss holiness with an irreligious man, nor justice with one who is unjust. You should not speak with a woman about her who is a rival, nor with a coward about war, nor with a merchant about exaggeration, nor with a buyer about selling, nor with a spiteful man about giving thanks,
verses.textLa: Cum viro irreligioso tracta de sanctitate, et cum iniusto de iustitia, et cum muliere de ea, quæ æmulatur: cum timido de bello: cum negotiatore de traiectione, cum emptore de venditione, cum viro livido de gratiis agendis,
verses.notes: In the context of a merchant trying to sell his wares, the word ‘trajectione’ refers to exaggeration, to advertising hyperbole.

verses.textEn: nor with the impious about piety, nor with the dishonest about honesty, nor with the field worker about other kinds of work,
verses.textLa: cum impio de pietate, cum inhonesto de honestate, cum operario agrario de omni opere,

verses.textEn: nor with a worker hired for a year about the end of the year, nor with a lazy servant about great works. You should pay no heed to these persons in any matter of counsel.
verses.textLa: cum operario annuali de consummatione anni, cum servo pigro de multa operatione: non attendas his in omni consilio.

verses.textEn: But be continually with a holy man, with anyone whom you know to observe the fear of God,
verses.textLa: Sed cum viro sancto assiduus esto, quemcumque cognoveris observantem timorem Dei,

verses.textEn: whose soul is in agreement with your own soul, and who, when you falter in the dark, will share your sorrows.
verses.textLa: cuius anima est secundum animam tuam: et qui, cum titubaveris in tenebris, condolebit tibi.

verses.textEn: And establish a heart of good counsel within yourself. For there is nothing of greater usefulness to you than this.
verses.textLa: Cor boni consilii statue tecum: non est enim tibi aliud pluris illo.
verses.notes: In this context, ‘delaturam’ does not refer to a fear of detraction if one does not mourn, but to a sinking down into bitterness, willingly, for a day or so, and then accepting consolation.

verses.textEn: At any time, the soul of a holy man declares more truths than seven vigilant watchmen sitting in a high place.
verses.textLa: Anima viri sancti enunciat aliquando vera, quam septem circumspectores sedentes in excelso ad speculandum.
verses.notes: In this context ‘detractionem’ does not refer to slander or to the fear of detraction, but to a removal, that is, to a loss of a human person created by God. The reason for mourning is not fear of accusation, but because of the loss to the world.

verses.textEn: But concerning all things, pray to the Most High, so that he may direct your way in truth.
verses.textLa: Et in his omnibus deprecare Altissimum ut dirigat in veritate viam tuam.

verses.textEn: In all your works, let a true word precede you, with steadfast counsel before every deed.
verses.textLa: Ante omnia opera verbum verax præcedat te, et ante omnem actum consilium stabile.

verses.textEn: A wicked word can change the heart. From the heart four kinds of things arise: good and evil, life and death. And the tongue is continually their ruler. There is a man who is an astute teacher of many, and yet this is useless to his own soul.
verses.textLa: Verbum nequam immutabit cor: ex quo partes quattuor oriuntur, bonum et malum, vita et mors: et dominatrix illorum est assidua lingua. Est vir astutus multorum eruditor, et animæ suæ inutilis est.

verses.textEn: A man of experience has taught many, and this is pleasant to his own soul.
verses.textLa: Vir peritus multos erudivit, et animæ suæ suavis est.

verses.textEn: Whoever speaks mere rhetoric is hateful; he will be deceived in every matter.
verses.textLa: Qui sophistice loquitur, odibilis est: in omni re defraudabitur.

verses.textEn: Grace is not given to him from the Lord. For he has been deprived of all wisdom.
verses.textLa: Non est illi data a Domino gratia: omni enim sapientia defraudatus est.

verses.textEn: There is a wise man who is wise within his own soul, and the fruit of his understanding is praiseworthy.
verses.textLa: Est sapiens animæ suæ sapiens: et fructus sensus illius laudabilis.

verses.textEn: A wise man instructs his own people, and the fruit of his understanding is faithful.
verses.textLa: Vir sapiens plebem suam erudit, et fructus sensus illius fideles sunt.

verses.textEn: A wise man will be filled with blessings, and those who see will praise him.
verses.textLa: Vir sapiens implebitur benedictionibus, et videntes illum laudabunt.

verses.textEn: The life of a man is in the number of his days. But the days of Israel are innumerable.
verses.textLa: Vita viri in numero dierum: dies autem Israel innumerabiles sunt.

verses.textEn: A wise man will inherit honor among the people, and his name will live in eternity.
verses.textLa: Sapiens in populo hereditabit honorem, et nomen illius erit vivens in æternum.

verses.textEn: Son, test your own mind in your life, and if it is lacking, you should not give it authority.
verses.textLa: Fili in vita tua tenta animam tuam: et si fuerit nequam, non des illi potestatem:

verses.textEn: For not all things are fitting for all persons, and not every kind of thing is agreeable to every soul.
verses.textLa: non enim omnia omnibus expediunt, et non omni animæ omne genus placet.

verses.textEn: Do not choose to be eager during any feast, and you should not act with excess toward any food.
verses.textLa: Noli avidus esse in omni epulatione, et non te effundas super omnem escam:

verses.textEn: For in excessive eating there will be infirmity, and gluttony will continue even unto illness.
verses.textLa: in multis enim escis erit infirmitas, et aviditas appropinquabit usque ad choleram.

verses.textEn: By excessive drinking, many have passed away. But he who abstains will add to his life.
verses.textLa: Propter crapulam multi obierunt: qui autem abstinens est, adiiciet vitam.

verses.textEn: Honor the physician because of necessity, and because the Most High created him.
verses.textLa: Honora medicum propter necessitatem: etenim illum creavit Altissimus.

verses.textEn: For all healing is from God, and so he will receive gifts from the King.
verses.textLa: A Deo est enim omnis medela, et a rege accipiet donationem.

verses.textEn: The expertise of the physician will lift up his head, and in the sight of great men, he will be praised.
verses.textLa: Disciplina medici exaltabit caput illius, et in conspectu magnatorum collaudabitur.

verses.textEn: The Most High has created medicines from the earth, and a prudent man will not abhor them.
verses.textLa: Altissimus creavit de terra medicamenta, et vir prudens non abhorrebit illa.

verses.textEn: Was not bitter water made sweet with wood?
verses.textLa: Nonne a ligno indulcata est aqua amara?

verses.textEn: The benefits of these things is recognized by men, and the Most High has given this knowledge to men, so that he may be honored in his wonders.
verses.textLa: Ad agnitionem hominum virtus illorum, et dedit hominibus scientiam Altissimus, honorari in mirabilibus suis.

verses.textEn: By these things, he will cure or mitigate their suffering, and the pharmacist will make soothing ointments, and he will form healing medicines, and there will be no end to his works.
verses.textLa: In his curans mitigabit dolorem, et unguentarius faciet pigmenta suavitatis, et unctiones conficiet sanitatis, et non consummabuntur opera eius.

verses.textEn: For the peace of God is upon the surface of the earth.
verses.textLa: Pax enim Dei super faciem terræ.

verses.textEn: Son, in your infirmity, you should not neglect yourself, but pray to the Lord, and he will cure you.
verses.textLa: Fili in tua infirmitate ne despicias te ipsum, sed ora Dominum, et ipse curabit te.

verses.textEn: Turn away from sin, and direct your hands, and cleanse your heart from every offense.
verses.textLa: Averte a delicto, et dirige manus, et ab omni delicto munda cor tuum.

verses.textEn: Give a sweet offering, and a memorial of fine flour, and fatten your oblation, but also give a place to the physician.
verses.textLa: Da suavitatem et memoriam similaginis, et impingua oblationem, et da locum medico:

verses.textEn: For the Lord created him. And so, do not let him depart from you, for his works are necessary.
verses.textLa: etenim illum Dominus creavit: et non discedat a te, quia opera eius sunt necessaria.

verses.textEn: For there is a time when you may fall into their hands.
verses.textLa: Est enim tempus quando in manus illorum incurras:

verses.textEn: Truly, they will beseech the Lord, so that he may direct their treatments and cures, for the sake of their way of life.
verses.textLa: ipsi vero Dominum deprecabuntur, ut dirigat requiem eorum, et sanitatem, propter conversationem illorum.

verses.textEn: He who sins in the sight of the One who made him will fall into the hands of the physician.
verses.textLa: Qui delinquit in conspectu eius, qui fecit eum, incidet in manus medici.

verses.textEn: Son, shed tears over the dead, and begin to weep, as if you had suffered dreadfully. And according to judgment, cover his body, and you should not neglect his burial.
verses.textLa: Fili in mortuum produc lacrymas, et quasi dira passus incipe plorare, et secundum iudicium contege corpus illius, et non despicias sepulturam illius.

verses.textEn: And though you will sink down into bitterness, bear his mourning for one day, and then be consoled in your sadness.
verses.textLa: Propter delaturam autem amare fer luctum illius uno die, et consolare propter tristitiam,

verses.textEn: And carry out his mourning, according to his merit, for one or two days because of this loss.
verses.textLa: et fac luctum secundum meritum eius uno die, vel duobus propter detractionem.

verses.textEn: Yet sadness hastens death and overwhelms strength, and the sorrow of the heart bows down the neck.
verses.textLa: A tristitia enim festinat mors, et cooperit virtutem, et tristitia cordis flectit cervicem.

verses.textEn: When one is taken away, sorrow remains. But the resources of a destitute man is found in his heart.
verses.textLa: In abductione permanet tristitia: et substantia inopis secundum cor eius.

verses.textEn: You should not give your heart over to sadness, but push it away from you. And remember the very end.
verses.textLa: Ne dederis in tristitia cor tuum, sed repelle eam a te: et memento novissimorum,

verses.textEn: Do not be willing to forget this; for there is no turning back. Otherwise, it will not benefit you, and you will cause great harm to yourself.
verses.textLa: noli obliviscari: neque enim est conversio, et huic nihil proderis, et teipsum pessimabis.

verses.textEn: Call to mind my judgment. For so shall it be for you also. Yesterday is mine, and today is yours.
verses.textLa: Memor esto iudicii mei: sic enim erit et tuum: mihi heri, et tibi hodie.

verses.textEn: When the deceased is at rest, let his memory rest also. And console him at the departure of his spirit.
verses.textLa: In requie mortui requiescere fac memoriam eius, et consolare illum in exitu spiritus sui.

verses.textEn: The wisdom of a scribe is found in his time of leisure. So whoever has less to do will gain wisdom.
verses.textLa: Sapientia scribæ in tempore vacuitatis: et qui minoratur actu, sapientiam percipiet:

verses.textEn: With what wisdom will someone be filled who holds the plow, and who boasts of the cattle prod that drives the oxen forward, and who is occupied in these labors, and whose only conversation is about the offspring of bulls?
verses.textLa: qua sapientia replebitur qui tenet aratrum, et qui gloriatur in iaculo, stimulo boves agitat, et conversatur in operibus eorum, et enarratio eius in filiis taurorum.

verses.textEn: He will give his mind over to the plowing of furrows, and his vigilance to the fattening of the cows.
verses.textLa: Cor suum dabit ad versandos sulcos, et vigilia eius in sagina vaccarum.

verses.textEn: Similarly, every craftsman and artisan, who crafts in the night as well as in the day, who sculpts graven seals, and who, by his diligence, varies the image, will give his mind over to the likeness of the image. And he will complete the work by his vigilance.
verses.textLa: Sic omnis faber et architectus, qui noctem tamquam diem transigit, qui sculpit signacula sculptilia, et assiduitas eius variat picturam: cor suum dabit in similitudinem picturæ, et vigilia sua perficiet opus.

verses.textEn: The blacksmith, sitting by his anvil and considering a work of iron, is similar. The steam from the fire singes his flesh, and he struggles against the heat of the furnace.
verses.textLa: Sic faber ferrarius sedens iuxta incudem, et considerans opus ferri: Vapor ignis uret carnes eius, et in calore fornacis concertatur:

verses.textEn: The voice of the hammer is ever in his ears, and his eye is upon the pattern of the ironwork.
verses.textLa: Vox mallei innovat aurem eius, et contra similitudinem vasis oculus eius:

verses.textEn: He gives his heart to the completion of his work, and his vigilance adorns it to perfection.
verses.textLa: Cor suum dabit in consummationem operum, et vigilia sua ornabit in perfectionem.

verses.textEn: The potter, sitting at his work and turning the wheel with his feet, is similar. He has settled into a continual concern for his work, and there is a rhythm in all that he does.
verses.textLa: Sic figulus sedens ad opus suum, convertens pedibus suis rotam, qui in solicitudine positus est semper propter opus suum, et in numero est omnis operatio eius.

verses.textEn: He forms the clay with his arm, and he bends his strength over his feet.
verses.textLa: In brachio suo formabit lutum, et ante pedes suos curvabit virtutem suam.

verses.textEn: He will give his heart over to the completion of the glazing, and his vigilance to the cleansing of the furnace.
verses.textLa: Cor suum dabit ut consummet linitionem, et vigilia sua mundabit fornacem.

verses.textEn: All these persons trust in their own hands, and each one is wise in his own art.
verses.textLa: Omnes hi in manibus suis speraverunt, et unusquisque in arte sua sapiens est.

verses.textEn: Without these persons, a city is not built.
verses.textLa: Sine his omnibus non ædificatur civitas.

verses.textEn: But they will neither inhabit nor walk around in the city. And they will not go across to the church.
verses.textLa: Et non inhabitabunt, nec inambulabunt, et in ecclesiam non transilient.

verses.textEn: They will not sit upon the seats of judges, and they will not understand a decree of judgment. And they will not make clear discipline and judgment, and they will not be found to understand parables.
verses.textLa: Super sellam iudicis non sedebunt, et testamentum iudicii non intelligent, neque palam facient disciplinam et iudicium, et in parabolis non invenientur:

verses.textEn: But they will strengthen the state of the world, and their prayer will be in their artistic works, applying their soul, and searching the law of the Most High.
verses.textLa: sed creaturam ævi confirmabunt, et deprecatio illorum in operatione artis, accomodantes animam suam, et conquirentes in lege Altissimi.

verses.textEn: A wise man will seek the wisdom of all the ancients, and he will be occupied in the prophets.
verses.textLa: Sapientiam omnium antiquorum exquiret sapiens, et in prophetis vacabit.

verses.textEn: He will preserve the words of renowned men, and he will enter with them into the subtleties of parables.
verses.textLa: Narrationem virorum nominatorum conservabit, et in versutias parabolarum simul introibit.

verses.textEn: He will search for the hidden meanings of proverbs, and he will become familiar with the mysteries of parables.
verses.textLa: Occulta proverbiorum exquiret, et in absconditis parabolarum conversabitur.

verses.textEn: He will minister in the midst of great men, and he will appear in the sight of the foremost leader.
verses.textLa: In medio magnatorum ministrabit, et in conspectu præsidis apparebit.

verses.textEn: He will pass through the land of foreign nations. For he will test good and evil among men.
verses.textLa: In terram alienigenarum gentium pertransiet: bona enim et mala in hominibus tentabit.

verses.textEn: At first light, he will offer his heart with watchfulness to the Lord who made him, and he will pray in the sight of the Most High.
verses.textLa: Cor suum tradet ad vigilandum diluculo ad Dominum, qui fecit illum, et in conspectu Altissimi deprecabitur.

verses.textEn: He will open his mouth in prayer, and he will make supplication for his offenses.
verses.textLa: Aperiet os suum in oratione, et pro delictis suis deprecabitur.

verses.textEn: For if the great Lord is willing, he will fill him with the Spirit of understanding.
verses.textLa: Si enim Dominus magnus voluerit, spiritu intelligentiæ replebit illum:

verses.textEn: And he will send forth the eloquence of his wisdom like rain showers, and in his prayer, he will confess to the Lord.
verses.textLa: et ipse tamquam imbres mittet eloquia sapientiæ suæ, et in oratione confitebitur Domino:

verses.textEn: And he will direct his counsel and his discipline, and he will meditate on his mysteries.
verses.textLa: et ipse diriget consilium eius, et disciplinam, et in absconditis suis consiliabitur.

verses.textEn: He will make the discipline of his doctrine clear, and he will glory in the law of the covenant of the Lord.
verses.textLa: Ipse palam faciet disciplinam doctrinæ suæ, et in lege testamenti Domini gloriabitur.

verses.textEn: Many persons will together praise his wisdom, and it will never be abolished, for all ages.
verses.textLa: Collaudabunt multi sapientiam eius, et usque in sæculum non delebitur.

verses.textEn: The memory of him will not fade away, and his name will be sought from generation to generation.
verses.textLa: Non recedet memoria eius, et nomen eius requiretur a generatione in generationem.

verses.textEn: The peoples will declare his wisdom, and the Church will announce his praise.
verses.textLa: Sapientiam eius enarrabunt gentes, et laudem eius enunciabit Ecclesia.

verses.textEn: While he remains, he leaves behind a name greater than a thousand, and when he will rest, it will be to his benefit.
verses.textLa: Si permanserit, nomen derelinquet plus quam mille: et si requieverit, proderit illi.

verses.textEn: I will meditate further, so that I may explain. For I have been filled with a passion.
verses.textLa: Adhuc consiliabor ut enarrem: ut furore enim repletus sum.

verses.textEn: In a voice, he says: Listen to me, divine fruits. You shall bear fruit, like roses planted beside streams of waters.
verses.textLa: In voce dicit: Obaudite me divini fructus, et quasi rosa plantata super rivos aquarum fructificate.

verses.textEn: You shall have a sweet fragrance, like the cedars of Lebanon.
verses.textLa: Quasi Libanus odorem suavitatis habete.

verses.textEn: Blossom with flowers, like the lily, and diffuse a fragrance, and sprout leaves in grace, and give praise with canticles, and bless the Lord in his works.
verses.textLa: Florete flores, quasi lilium, et date odorem, et frondete in gratiam, et collaudate canticum, et benedicite Dominum in operibus suis.

verses.textEn: Give magnificence to his name, and confess to him with the voice of your lips and with the canticles of your mouth and with stringed instruments. And in so praising him, you will confess:
verses.textLa: Date nomini eius magnificentiam, et confitemini illi in voce labiorum vestrorum, et in canticis labiorum, et citharis, et sic dicetis in confessione:

verses.textEn: All the works of the Lord are very good.
verses.textLa: Opera Domini universa bona valde.

verses.textEn: At his word, the waters stood still, as if piled together. And at the words of his mouth, the waters were contained, as if in basins of water.
verses.textLa: In verbo eius stetit aqua sicut congeries: et in sermone oris illius sicut exceptoria aquarum:

verses.textEn: For it is made pleasing by his precept, and there is no decrease in his salvation.
verses.textLa: quoniam in præcepto ipsius placor fit, et non est minoratio in salute ipsius.

verses.textEn: The works of all flesh are in his sight, and there is nothing hidden from his eyes.
verses.textLa: Opera omnis carnis coram illo, et non est quidquam absconditum ab oculis eius.

verses.textEn: His gaze is from eternity to eternity, and nothing is a wonder in his sight.
verses.textLa: A sæculo usque in sæculum respicit, et nihil est mirabile in conspectu eius.

verses.textEn: Let it not be said: “What is this?” or, “What is that?” For all things will be sought in their time.
verses.textLa: Non est dicere: Quid est hoc, aut quid est istud? Omnia enim in tempore suo quærentur.

verses.textEn: His blessing has overflowed like a river.
verses.textLa: Benedictio illius quasi fluvius inundavit.

verses.textEn: In the same way that a flood inundates the dry land, so also will his wrath inherit the peoples that have not sought him.
verses.textLa: Quomodo cataclysmus aridam inebriavit, sic ira ipsius gentes, quæ non exquisierunt eum, hereditabit.

verses.textEn: In the same way that he turned the waters into dry land, and made the earth dry, and just as his ways have been directed for their journey, so also will sinners stumble before his wrath.
verses.textLa: Quomodo convertit aquas in siccitatem, et siccata est terra: et viæ illius viis illorum directæ sunt: sic peccatoribus offensiones in ira eius.

verses.textEn: From the beginning, good things were created for those who are good, and similarly, good and evil things are for those who are wicked.
verses.textLa: Bona bonis creata sunt ab initio, sic nequissimis bona et mala.

verses.textEn: The principal things necessary for the life of men are: water, fire, and iron, salt, milk, and flour for bread, and honey, and the grape cluster, and oil, and clothing.
verses.textLa: Initium necessariæ rei vitæ hominum, aqua, ignis, et ferrum, sal, lac, et panis similagineus, et mel et botrus uvæ, et oleum, et vestimentum.

verses.textEn: All these things will be used for good by those who are holy, but they will be turned to evil use by the impious and by sinners.
verses.textLa: Hæc omnia sanctis in bona, sic et impiis et peccatoribus in mala convertentur.

verses.textEn: There are spirits that have been created for vengeance, and they strengthen their torments by their fury.
verses.textLa: Sunt spiritus, qui ad vindictam creati sunt, et in furore suo confirmaverunt tormenta sua:

verses.textEn: In the time of the consummation, they will pour forth their strength. And they will appease the fury of the One who made them.
verses.textLa: in tempore consummationis effundent virtutem: et furorem eius, qui fecit illos, placabunt.

verses.textEn: Fire, hail, famine, and death: all these were created for vengeance.
verses.textLa: Ignis, grando, fames, et mors, omnia hæc ad vindictam creata sunt:

verses.textEn: The teeth of wild beasts, and scorpions, and serpents, and the spear: all these take vengeance upon the impious, unto utter destruction.
verses.textLa: bestiarum dentes, et scorpii, et serpentes, et rhomphæa vindicans in exterminium impios.

verses.textEn: At his command, they will feast. And they will be prepared upon the earth until they are needed. And in their time, they will not ignore his word.
verses.textLa: In mandatis eius epulabuntur, et super terram in necessitatem præparabuntur, et in temporibus suis non præterient verbum.

verses.textEn: For this reason, from the beginning, I was strengthened, and I have meditated, and I have considered, and I have put these things in writing.
verses.textLa: Propterea ab initio confirmatus sum, et consiliatus sum, et cogitavi, et scripta dimisi.

verses.textEn: All the works of the Lord are good, and he will provide for each work in its own hour.
verses.textLa: Omnia opera Domini bona, et omne opus hora sua subministrabit.

verses.textEn: Let it not be said: “This is worse than that.” For all things will be tested in their time.
verses.textLa: Non est dicere: Hoc illo nequius est: omnia enim in tempore suo comprobabuntur.

verses.textEn: And now, with the whole heart and mouth, give praise to him, and bless the name of the Lord.
verses.textLa: Et nunc in omni corde et ore collaudate, et benedicite nomen Domini.

verses.textEn: A great occupation was created for all men, and a heavy yoke is upon the sons of Adam, from the day of their departure from their mother’s womb, even until the day of their burial into the mother of all:
verses.textLa: Occupatio magna creata est omnibus hominibus, et iugum grave super filios Adam, a die exitus de ventre matris eorum, usque in diem sepulturæ, in matrem omnium.

verses.textEn: their thoughts, and the fears of their heart, their imagined expectations, and the day of their end,
verses.textLa: Cogitationes eorum, et timores cordis, adinventio expectationis, et dies finitionis:

verses.textEn: from him who sits upon a glorious throne, even to him who is humbled in earth and ashes,
verses.textLa: a residente super sedem gloriosam, usque ad humiliatum in terra et cinere:

verses.textEn: from him who wears hyacinth and bears a crown, even to him who is covered with rough linen: wrath, envy, tumult, restlessness, and the fear of death, continual anger and contention.
verses.textLa: ab eo, qui utitur hyacintho, et portat coronam, usque ad eum, qui operitur lino crudo: furor, zelus, tumultus, fluctuatio, et timor mortis, iracundia perseverans, et contentio,

verses.textEn: And in the time of rest upon his bed, the sleep of the night changes his knowledge.
verses.textLa: et in tempore refectionis in cubili, somnus noctis immutat scientiam eius.

verses.textEn: There is little or no rest, and sleep is taken from him, as if on a day of keeping watch.
verses.textLa: Modicum tamquam nihil in requie, et ab eo in somnis, quasi in die respectus.

verses.textEn: He is disturbed by a vision of his heart, as if he had escaped in a day of warfare. In the time of his salvation, he rose up and wondered that there was no fear.
verses.textLa: Conturbatus est in visu cordis sui, tamquam qui evaserit in die belli. In tempore salutis suæ exurrexit, et admirans ad nullum timorem:

verses.textEn: This is so with all flesh, from man even to cattle, but upon sinners it is seven times as great.
verses.textLa: cum omni carne, ab homine usque ad pecus, et super peccatores septuplum.

verses.textEn: Add to this: death, bloodshed, contention, and the spear, oppression, famine, and affliction, and scourges.
verses.textLa: Ad hæc mors, sanguis, contentio, et romphæa, oppressiones, fames, et contritio, et flagella:

verses.textEn: All these things have been created because of iniquity, and it is due to iniquity that the great flood was made.
verses.textLa: super iniquos creata sunt hæc omnia, et propter illos factus est cataclysmus.

verses.textEn: All things that are of the earth shall return to the earth, and all waters shall return to the sea.
verses.textLa: Omnia, quæ de terra sunt, in terram convertentur, et omnes aquæ in mare revertentur.

verses.textEn: All bribery and iniquity will be wiped away, but faith shall stand forever.
verses.textLa: Omne munus, et iniquitas delebitur, et fides in sæculum stabit.

verses.textEn: The substance of the unjust will dry up like a river, and will pass away with a noise like loud thunder in a rainstorm.
verses.textLa: Substantiæ iniustorum sicut fluvius siccabuntur, et sicut tonitruum magnum in pluvia personabunt.

verses.textEn: When he opens his hands, he will rejoice. So will transgressors pass away at the consummation.
verses.textLa: In aperiendo manus suas lætabitur: sic prævaricatores in consummatione tabescent.

verses.textEn: The descendants of the impious will not produce many branches, for they may be compared to dirty roots at the edge of a rock.
verses.textLa: Nepotes impiorum non multiplicabunt ramos, et radices immundæ super cacumen petræ sonant.
verses.notes: The word ‘sonant’ can refer to either the making of a noise, or to a description or expression of something using the spoken word. In this case, the progeny of the impious are spoken of as being like dirty roots, rather than fruitful leafy branches.

verses.textEn: The weeds, which grow above every water and beside the banks of the river, will be uprooted before all the grass.
verses.textLa: Super omnem aquam viriditas, et ad oram fluminis ante omne fœnum evelletur.

verses.textEn: Grace is like a paradise of blessings, and mercy continues for eternity.
verses.textLa: Gratia sicut paradisus in benedictionibus, et misericordia in sæculum permanet.

verses.textEn: The life of a worker, when content with what is sufficient, will become sweet, and in it you will find a treasure.
verses.textLa: Vita sibi sufficientis operarii condulcabitur, et in ea invenies thesaurum.

verses.textEn: Sons, and the building of a city, will establish a name, but an immaculate wife will be ranked above these things.
verses.textLa: Filii, et ædificatio civitatis confirmabit nomen, et super hæc mulier immaculata computabitur.

verses.textEn: Wine and music rejoice the heart, but the love of wisdom is above them both.
verses.textLa: Vinum et musica lætificant cor: et super utraque dilectio sapientiæ.

verses.textEn: The flute and the psaltery make a sweet melody, but a pleasant word is above them both.
verses.textLa: Tibiæ, et psalterium suavem faciunt melodiam, et super utraque lingua suavis.

verses.textEn: Your eye desires elegance and beauty, but verdant fields are above these things.
verses.textLa: Gratiam, et speciem desiderabit oculus tuus, et super hæc virides sationes.

verses.textEn: A friend and a companion meet one another in time, but above them both is a wife with her husband.
verses.textLa: Amicus, et sodalis in tempore convenientes, et super utrosque mulier cum viro.

verses.textEn: Brothers are a help in time of tribulation, but mercy will liberate, more so than they will.
verses.textLa: Fratres in adiutorium in tempore tribulationis, et super eos misericordia liberabit.

verses.textEn: Gold and silver provide a firm position for the feet, but well-spoken counsel is above them both.
verses.textLa: Aurum et argentum est constitutio pedum: et super utrumque consilium beneplacitum.

verses.textEn: Ability and strength lift up the heart, but the fear of the Lord is above these things.
verses.textLa: Facultates et virtutes exaltant cor, et super hæc timor Domini.

verses.textEn: There is no loss in the fear of the Lord, and it has no need to ask for assistance.
verses.textLa: Non est in timore Domini minoratio, et non est in eo inquirere adiutorium.

verses.textEn: The fear of the Lord is like a paradise of blessings, and they have covered it above all glory.
verses.textLa: Timor Domini sicut paradisus benedictionis, et super omnem gloriam operuerunt illum.

verses.textEn: Son, in your lifetime you should not be indigent, for it is better to die than to be destitute.
verses.textLa: Fili in tempore vitæ tuæ ne indigeas: melius est enim mori, quam indigere.

verses.textEn: The life of him who looks to another man’s table should not be thought of as a way of life. For he feeds his life with another man’s food.
verses.textLa: Vir respiciens in mensam alienam, non est vita eius in cogitatione victus. Alit enim animam suam cibis alienis.

verses.textEn: But a disciplined and well-taught man will take care of himself.
verses.textLa: Vir autem disciplinatus, et eruditus custodiet se.

verses.textEn: Scarcity will seem sweet to the mouth of the imprudent, but a fire will burn in his belly.
verses.textLa: In ore imprudentis condulcabitur inopia, et in ventre eius ignis ardebit.

verses.textEn: O death, how bitter is the memory of you: to a man who has peace in his substance,
verses.textLa: O mors quam amara est memoria tua homini pacem habenti in substantiis suis:

verses.textEn: to a quiet man, and to him whose ways are directed properly in all things, and who still has the strength to take nourishment.
verses.textLa: viro quieto, et cuius viæ directæ sunt in omnibus, et adhuc valenti accipere cibum!

verses.textEn: O death, your judgment is good to the indigent man, and to him whose strength has diminished,
verses.textLa: O mors, bonum est iudicium tuum homini indigenti, et qui minoratur viribus,

verses.textEn: who is failing due to old age, and who is anxious about all things, and to the unbelieving man who has lost patience.
verses.textLa: defecto ætate, et cui de omnibus cura est, et incredibili, qui perdit patientiam!

verses.textEn: Do not choose to dread the judgment of death. Remember the things that occurred before you, and the things that will occur after you. This judgment is from the Lord upon all flesh.
verses.textLa: Noli metuere iudicium mortis. Memento quæ ante te fuerunt, et quæ superventura sunt tibi: hoc iudicium a Domino omni carni:

verses.textEn: And what will happen to you is well-pleasing to the Most High, whether in ten, or one hundred, or one thousand years.
verses.textLa: et quid superveniet tibi in beneplacito Altissimi: sive decem, sive centum, sive mille anni.

verses.textEn: For death is no indictment of life.
verses.textLa: Non est enim in inferno accusatio vitæ.
verses.notes: The word ‘inferno’ can refer to Hell, but it can also refer to death in general, even for the good.

verses.textEn: The sons of sinners, and those who pass their time in the manner of the houses of the impious, become sons of abominations.
verses.textLa: Filii abominationum fiunt filii peccatorum, et qui conversantur secus domos impiorum.

verses.textEn: The inheritance of the sons of sinners will perish, and continual disgrace will be with their offspring.
verses.textLa: Filiorum peccatorum periet hereditas, et cum semine illorum assiduitas opprobrii.

verses.textEn: The sons of an impious father will complain, for they are in disgrace because of him.
verses.textLa: De patre impio queruntur filii, quoniam propter illum sunt in opprobrio.

verses.textEn: Woe to you, impious men, who have abandoned the law of the Most High Lord!
verses.textLa: Væ vobis viri impii, qui dereliquistis legem Domini Altissimi!

verses.textEn: And when you are born, you will be born into a curse; and when you die, your portion will be in a curse.
verses.textLa: Et si nati fueritis, in maledictione nascemini: et si mortui fueritis, in maledictione erit pars vestra.

verses.textEn: All things that are from the earth shall return to the earth. Similarly, the impious will proceed from a curse unto perdition.
verses.textLa: Omnia, quæ de terra sunt, in terram convertentur: sic impii a maledicto in perditionem.

verses.textEn: The grieving of men is in their body, but the name of the impious will be wiped away.
verses.textLa: Luctus hominum in corpore ipsorum, nomen autem impiorum delebitur.

verses.textEn: Have concern for your good name. For this will continue with you, more so than a thousand precious and great treasures.
verses.textLa: Curam habe de bono nomine: hoc enim magis permanebit tibi, quam mille thesauri pretiosi et magni.

verses.textEn: A good life has its number of days, but a good name will continue forever.
verses.textLa: Bonæ vitæ numerus dierum: bonum autem nomen permanebit in ævum.

verses.textEn: Sons, practice discipline peacefully. For what use is there in either concealed wisdom, or undiscovered treasure?
verses.textLa: Disciplinam in pace conservate filii. Sapientia enim abscondita, et thesaurus invisus, quæ utilitas in utrisque?

verses.textEn: Better is the man who hides his foolishness than the man who hides his wisdom.
verses.textLa: Melior est homo, qui abscondit stultitiam suam, quam homo, qui abscondit sapientiam suam.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, have respect for these things which proceed from my mouth.
verses.textLa: Verumtamen reveremini in his, quæ procedunt de ore meo.

verses.textEn: For it is not good to observe every reverence. And all things do not please all persons in their beliefs.
verses.textLa: Non est enim bonum omnem reverentiam observare: et non omnia omnibus bene placent in fide.
verses.notes: You cannot please everyone, nor can you always avoid offending everyone. So respect for the opinions of others has its limits.

verses.textEn: Have shame of these things: of fornication before father and mother, and of a lie before the first leader and the powerful,
verses.textLa: Erubescite a patre et a matre de fornicatione: et a præsidente et a potente de mendacio:
verses.notes: Shame, in the Biblical context, does not merely mean to be ashamed of something sinful or wrong. It also refers to modesty, to a feeling of unworthiness before God, to a reverence of others and a humbling of one’s self. Thus, we should have shame before the truth of God, and the covenant, and the bread that we eat (especially the consecrated bread of the Eucharist), and the humble place where you live.

verses.textEn: of a crime before a ruler or a judge, of iniquity before a congregation or a people,
verses.textLa: a principe et a iudice de delicto: a synagoga et plebe de iniquitate:

verses.textEn: of injustice before a companion or a friend, and of the place in which you live,
verses.textLa: a socio et amico de iniustitia: et de loco, in quo habitas,

verses.textEn: of theft, and of the truth before God, and of the covenant, of reclining to eat bread, and of deceitfulness in giving or receiving,
verses.textLa: de furto, de veritate Dei, et testamento: de discubitu in panibus, et ab obfuscatione dati et accepti:

verses.textEn: of silence before those who greet you, of looking upon a woman of fornication, and of averting your face from a relative.
verses.textLa: a salutantibus de silentio: a respectu mulieris fornicariæ: et ab aversione vultus cognati.

verses.textEn: You should not avert your face from your neighbor, nor should you take away a portion and not restore it.
verses.textLa: Ne avertas faciem a proximo tuo, et ab auferendo partem et non restituendo.

verses.textEn: You should not stare at another man’s wife, nor pursue his handmaid, nor approach her bed.
verses.textLa: Ne respicias mulierem alieni viri, et ne scruteris ancillam eius, neque steteris ad lectum eius.

verses.textEn: Avoid reproachful speeches before friends, and when you give, you should not place blame.
verses.textLa: Ab amicis de sermonibus improperii: et cum dederis, ne improperes.

verses.textEn: You should not repeat a claim heard from the revealing of a hidden word. And then, truly, you will be without shame, and you will find favor in the sight of all men. You should not accept the reputation of someone, so that you would sin, nor should you be confounded in any of the following things:
verses.textLa: Non duplices sermonem auditus de revelatione sermonis absconditi, et eris vere sine confusione, et invenies gratiam in conspectu omnium hominum: ne pro his omnibus confundaris, et ne accipias personam ut delinquas:

verses.textEn: in the law of the Most High and his covenant, or by giving a judgment to justify the impious;
verses.textLa: de lege Altissimi, et testamento, et de iudicio iustificare impium,
verses.notes: Notice that the first thing one should not have shame in is good (the law and the covenant), and the second thing is bad (unjust judgment). So there is a two-fold meaning: the type of shame where one feels shame in something that is actually good, wherein there is no reason for shame, and the type of shame which one feels shame for an immoral act, wherein there is reason for shame. Do not have shame in God’s covenant and in His law; follow the covenant and the law without shame. But then, do not have shame in unjust judgment by avoiding unjust judgment (not by doing it without shame).

verses.textEn: in a word among companions and fellow travelers, or by distributing the inheritance of friends;
verses.textLa: de verbo sociorum et viatorum, et de datione hereditatis amicorum,

verses.textEn: in the fairness of scales and weights, or in acquiring much or little;
verses.textLa: de æqualitate stateræ et ponderum, de acquisitione multorum et paucorum,

verses.textEn: by the corruption of buying and negotiating, or in the ample discipline of children, or in causing the side of a wicked servant to bleed.
verses.textLa: de corruptione emptionis, et negotiatorum, et de multa disciplina filiorum, et servo pessimo latus sanguinare.

verses.textEn: A seal is good over a wicked wife.
verses.textLa: Super mulierem nequam bonum est signum.

verses.textEn: Where there are many hands, seal and deliver all things by number and weight; and truly, give and receive everything in writing.
verses.textLa: Ubi manus multæ sunt, claude, et quodcumque trades, numera, et appende: datum vero, et acceptum omne describe.

verses.textEn: You should not have shame in correcting the senseless, the foolish, and those youths who would judge their elders. And so shall you be well-instructed in all things and well-approved in the sight of all the living.
verses.textLa: De disciplina insensati et fatui, et de senioribus, qui iudicantur ab adolescentibus: et eris eruditus in omnibus, et probabilis in conspectu omnium vivorum.

verses.textEn: The vigilance of a father for his daughter is hidden, and his concern for her takes away his sleep. For perhaps, in her adolescence, she might be brought into adulthood. Or when she lives with her husband, she might become hateful.
verses.textLa: Filia patris abscondita est vigilia, et solicitudo eius aufert somnum, ne forte in adolescentia sua adulta efficiatur, et cum viro commorata odibilis fiat:

verses.textEn: In her virginity, she might be defiled, and then she may be found to be pregnant in her father’s house. Or perhaps, when she lives with her husband, she might stray, or at least become barren.
verses.textLa: nequando polluatur in virginitate sua, et in paternis suis gravida inveniatur: ne forte cum viro commorata transgrediatur, aut certe sterilis efficiatur.

verses.textEn: Keep a close watch over a self-indulgent daughter. Otherwise, at some time, she might bring you into disgrace before your enemies, and into disrepute in the city, and into reproach among the people, and so she may confound you before the multitude of the people.
verses.textLa: Super filiam luxuriosam confirma custodiam: ne quando faciat te in opprobrium venire inimicis, a detractione in civitate, et obiectione plebis, et confundat te in multitudine populi.

verses.textEn: She should not choose to gaze upon the beauty of every man, and she should not choose to spend her time in the midst of married women.
verses.textLa: Omni homini noli intendere in specie: et in medio mulierum noli commorari:
verses.notes: This passage is advice concerning how one’s young unmarried daughter should behave, in order to retain chastity. So, the verb was changed in translation to the third person singular, feminine, from the second person singular imperative. Looking at the attractiveness of every man is harmful to her chastity. So is spending time with married women, who might talk about marital relations, perhaps even in a crass manner.

verses.textEn: For a moth goes forth from garments, and iniquity over a man goes forth from a woman.
verses.textLa: de vestimentis enim procedit tinea, et a muliere iniquitas viri.
verses.notes: Iniquity pertaining to men, i.e. sins committed because of her attraction to a man, proceeds from a woman. Again, this advice pertains to a young unmarried daughter and is in the context of the previous verse about avoiding sins related to attraction of a young unmarried daughter to men.

verses.textEn: Yet iniquity over a man is better for her than if a married woman, seeking to benefit her, instead leads her into confusion and disgrace.
verses.textLa: Melior est enim iniquitas viri, quam mulier benefaciens, et mulier confundens in opprobrium.
verses.notes:
Yet the iniquity of a man [sins of women pertaining to men] is better than a woman [an older married woman] seeking to benefit [the younger unmarried woman] and yet confusing her to her disgrace.
 The sense of verse 14 is that even though the problems a daughter might encounter, which are warned against in verse 13, are harmful, there is a worse situation, that of married women influencing your daughter, leading her into confusion and disgrace. This passage is not saying that men's sins are better than women's sins. Rather, it is advice as to how to advise and govern a young unmarried daughter. If she hangs around older women, they might think to 'help' her by giving her advice about men which is not fitting to someone who is young and unmarried, so instead of benefiting her, they would lead her into confusion and disgrace. In other words, hanging around older married women might corrupt your virgin unmarried daughter, since they might talk about men in a licentious manner.

verses.textEn: And now, I will remember the works of the Lord, and I will announce what I have seen. The words of the Lord are in his works.
verses.textLa: Memor ero igitur operum Domini, et quæ vidi annunciabo. In sermonibus Domini opera eius.

verses.textEn: The sun illuminates and considers all things, and its work shows the fullness of the glory of the Lord.
verses.textLa: Sol illuminans per omnia respexit, et gloria Domini plenum est opus eius.

verses.textEn: Has not the Lord caused the holy ones to describe all his miracles, which the all-powerful Lord has firmly established in his glory?
verses.textLa: Nonne Dominus fecit sanctos enarrare omnia mirabilia sua, quæ confirmavit Dominus omnipotens stabiliri in gloria sua?

verses.textEn: He has examined the abyss and the hearts of men. And he has considered their astuteness.
verses.textLa: Abyssum, et cor hominum investigavit: et in astutia eorum excogitavit.

verses.textEn: For the Lord comprehends all knowledge, and he has gazed upon the signs of the times: announcing the things of the past, as well as the things of the future, and revealing the traces of hidden things.
verses.textLa: Cognovit enim Dominus omnem scientiam, et inspexit in signum ævi, annuncians quæ præterierunt, et quæ superventura sunt, revelans vestigia occultorum.

verses.textEn: No thought passes by him unnoticed, and no word can conceal itself from him.
verses.textLa: Non præterit illum omnis cogitatus, et non abscondit se ab eo ullus sermo.

verses.textEn: He has adorned the magnificent works of his wisdom. He is before eternity and even unto eternity. And nothing can be added,
verses.textLa: Magnalia sapientiæ suæ decoravit: qui est ante sæculum et usque in sæculum, neque adiectum est,

verses.textEn: and nothing can be taken away. And he has no need of any counselor.
verses.textLa: neque minuitur, et non eget alicuius consilio.

verses.textEn: O how desirable are all his works! And all that we consider is but a spark.
verses.textLa: Quam desiderabilia omnia opera eius! Et tamquam scintilla, quæ est considerare.

verses.textEn: All these works exist, and they remain in the present age, and they all obey him in every purpose.
verses.textLa: Omnia hæc vivunt, et manent in sæculum, et in omni necessitate omnia obaudiunt ei.

verses.textEn: All things are two-fold, one facing another, and he has not made anything to be lacking.
verses.textLa: Omnia duplicia, unum contra unum, et non fecit quidquam deesse.

verses.textEn: He has confirmed each thing as good. And who would tire of beholding his glory?
verses.textLa: Uniuscuiusque confirmavit bona. Et quis satiabitur videns gloriam eius?

verses.textEn: The firmament on high is his beauty; it is the beauty of heaven in a vision of glory.
verses.textLa: Altitudinis firmamentum pulchritudo eius est, species cæli in visione gloriæ.

verses.textEn: The sun, at its appearance, announces its journey; it is an instrument of wonder, a work of the Most High.
verses.textLa: Sol in aspectu annuncians in exitu, vas admirabile opus Excelsi.

verses.textEn: At midday, it scorches the earth. And in the presence of its heat, who would be able to endure? It is like the custodian of a furnace in its works of heat.
verses.textLa: In meridiano exurit terram, et in conspectu ardoris eius quis poterit sustinere? Fornacem custodiens in operibus ardoris:

verses.textEn: In three ways, the sun acts: scorching the mountains, emitting fiery rays, and shining with its beams that can blind the eyes.
verses.textLa: tripliciter sol exurens montes, radios igneos exsufflans, et refulgens radiis suis obcæcat oculos.

verses.textEn: Great is the Lord who made it, and at his word, it hurries on its journey.
verses.textLa: Magnus Dominus qui fecit illum, et in sermonibus eius festinavit iter.

verses.textEn: And the moon, in all its phases, serves to mark the seasons and to be a sign of the times.
verses.textLa: Et luna in omnibus in tempore suo, ostensio temporis, et signum ævi.

verses.textEn: From the moon is the sign of a feast day; it is a light which diminishes at its consummation.
verses.textLa: A luna signum diei festi, luminare quod minuitur in consummatione.
verses.notes: Feast days were often at the full moon (e.g. Passover, Feast of Tabernacles), and often lasted about 7 days, so that the feast ended as the moons light was diminishing. This verse also has an eschatological meaning, in that changes in the appearance of the moon is one of the signs of the consummation (the end times).

verses.textEn: A month is named according to its phases, increasing wonderfully at its culmination.
verses.textLa: Mensis secundum nomen eius est, crescens mirabiliter in consummatione.

verses.textEn: It is an instrument of the armies on high, shining gloriously in the firmament of heaven.
verses.textLa: Vas castrorum in excelsis, in firmamento cæli resplendens gloriose.

verses.textEn: The glory of the stars is the beauty of heaven; the Lord illuminates the world from on high.
verses.textLa: Species cæli gloria stellarum, mundum illuminans in excelsis Dominus.

verses.textEn: At the words of the Holy One, they stand for judgment, and they will never fail in their vigilance.
verses.textLa: In verbis Sancti stabunt ad iudicium, et non deficient in vigiliis suis.

verses.textEn: Consider the rainbow, and bless the One who made it; it is very beautiful in its splendor.
verses.textLa: Vide arcum, et benedic eum, qui fecit illum: valde speciosus est in splendore suo.

verses.textEn: It encompasses the heavens with the circle of its glory; the hands of the Most High made it appear.
verses.textLa: Gyravit cælum in circuitu gloriæ suæ, manus Excelsi aperuerunt illum.

verses.textEn: By his order, he hastens the snow, and he spurs on the lightning to express his judgment.
verses.textLa: Imperio suo acceleravit nivem, et accelerat coruscationes emittere iudicii sui.

verses.textEn: In like manner, his storehouses are opened, and the clouds fly out like birds.
verses.textLa: Propterea aperti sunt thesauri, et evolaverunt nebulæ sicut aves.

verses.textEn: By his greatness, he has positioned the clouds, and the hailstones have been broken.
verses.textLa: In magnitudine sua posuit nubes, et confracti sunt lapides grandinis.

verses.textEn: At his glance, the mountains will be shaken, and by his will, the south wind will blow.
verses.textLa: In conspectu eius commovebuntur montes, et in voluntate eius aspirabit Notus.

verses.textEn: The voice of his thunder will reverberate through the earth, by a storm from the north, and by a gathering of the whirlwind.
verses.textLa: Vox tonitrui eius verberavit terram, tempestas aquilonis, et congregatio spiritus:

verses.textEn: And like the birds landing in a flock upon the earth, he sends down the snow; and its descent is like the arrival of a swarm of locusts.
verses.textLa: et sicut avis deponens ad sedendum, aspergit nivem, et sicut locusta demergens descensus eius.

verses.textEn: The eye is in wonder at the beauty of its whiteness, and the heart is astonished at its falling.
verses.textLa: Pulchritudinem candoris eius admirabitur oculus, et super imbrem eius expavescet cor.

verses.textEn: He will pour out frost like salt upon the earth. And when it freezes, it will become like the tops of thistles.
verses.textLa: Gelu sicut salem effundet super terram: et dum gelaverit, fiet tamquam cacumina tribuli.

verses.textEn: The cold north wind blows, and the water freezes into crystals; it will rest upon every gathering of water, and it will clothe the water like a breastplate.
verses.textLa: Frigidus ventus aquilo flavit, et gelavit crystallus ab aqua, super omnem congregationem aquarum requiescet, et sicut lorica induet se aquis.

verses.textEn: And it will devour the mountains, and burn the wilderness, and extinguish the greenery, like a fire.
verses.textLa: Et devorabit montes, et exuret desertum, et extinguet viride, sicut igne.

verses.textEn: Relief for all is in the hurried arrival of a cloud. And the lowly dew will arrive to meet the heat and overpower it.
verses.textLa: Medicina omnium in festinatione nebulæ: et ros obvians ab ardore venienti humilem efficiet eum.
verses.notes: This is a prophetic figure for the Return of Jesus Christ on a cloud, and the return with Him of the lowly Virgin Mary; and at His Return, He will destroy the ardor of sin and of the sinful Antichrist (who will be of the kingdom of the North).

verses.textEn: At his word, the wind grows quiet, and by his thought, he appeases the abyss, for the Lord has planted islands in it.
verses.textLa: In sermone eius siluit ventus, et cogitatione sua placavit abyssum, et plantavit in illa Dominus insulas.

verses.textEn: Let those who navigate the sea describe its perils. And when we have heard it with our ears, we will wonder.
verses.textLa: Qui navigant mare, enarrent pericula eius: et audientes auribus nostris admirabimur.

verses.textEn: There are illustrious and wondrous works: the various kinds of wild animals, and all manner of cattle, and the great creatures of the sea.
verses.textLa: Illic præclara opera, et mirabilia: varia bestiarum genera, et omnium pecorum, et creatura belluarum.

verses.textEn: Through him, the end of their journey is confirmed, and by his word, all things fit together.
verses.textLa: Propter ipsum confirmatus est itineris finis, et in sermone eius composita sunt omnia.

verses.textEn: We can say much, and yet still lack for words. But the consummation of our words is this: He is in all things.
verses.textLa: Multa dicemus, et deficiemus in verbis; consummatio autem sermonum, ipse est in omnibus.

verses.textEn: What would we be able to do to glorify him? For the Almighty himself is above all his own works.
verses.textLa: Gloriantes ad quid valebimus? Ipse enim Omnipotens super omnia opera sua.

verses.textEn: The Lord is terrible, and exceedingly great, and his power is wonderful.
verses.textLa: Terribilis Dominus, et magnus vehementer, et mirabilis potentia ipsius.

verses.textEn: Glorify the Lord as much as you are able, yet still he will far exceed this. For his magnificence is beyond wonder.
verses.textLa: Glorificantes Dominum quantumcumque potueritis, supervalebit enim adhuc, et admirabilis magnificentia eius.

verses.textEn: Bless the Lord and exalt him, as much as you are able. But he is beyond all praise.
verses.textLa: Benedicentes Dominum, exaltate illum quantum potestis: maior enim est omni laude.

verses.textEn: When you exalt him, use all your ability, and do not cease in this labor. For you can never comprehend him.
verses.textLa: Exaltantes eum replemini virtute; ne laboretis: non enim comprehendetis.

verses.textEn: Who will see him and explain? And who will magnify him, as he is from the beginning?
verses.textLa: Quis videbit eum, et enarrabit? Et quis magnificabit eum sicut est ab initio?

verses.textEn: There are many things, hidden from us, which are greater than these things. For we have seen but a few of his works.
verses.textLa: Multa abscondita sunt maiora his: pauca enim vidimus operum eius.

verses.textEn: But the Lord has made all things, and he has given wisdom to those who act with piety.
verses.textLa: Omnia autem Dominus fecit, et pie agentibus dedit sapientiam.

verses.textEn: Let us praise the men of glory, and our ancestors in their generation.
verses.textLa: Laudemus viros gloriosos, et parentes nostros in generatione sua.

verses.textEn: The Lord has wrought great glory, by his own magnificence, from ancient times.
verses.textLa: Multam gloriam fecit Dominus magnificentia sua a sæculo:

verses.textEn: There are those who rule with their authority, men of great virtue, who are gifted with prudence. There are those who announce among the prophets, with the dignity of prophets.
verses.textLa: Dominantes in potestatibus suis, homines magni virtute, et prudentia sua præditi, nunciantes in prophetis dignitatem prophetarum,

verses.textEn: And there are those who rule over the present generation, by the virtue of prudence, with very holy words for the people.
verses.textLa: et imperantes in præsenti populo, et virtute prudentiæ populis sanctissima verba.

verses.textEn: There are those who, by their skill, compose musical themes, so as to set the verses of Scripture to music.
